The Letter you conveyed was in defiance,
A loose liv'd wanton, intended to a whore,
That impudently hopes an interest in me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: It was not so directed.

LG.L: I there was
(The Hell confound it on't) my giddines:
I seald both Letters e're I superscrib'd 'em,
And so gave each the contrary direction.
'Twas a grosse carelesnesse, and if you lose
A fortune by't, do not blame your friends.
That fortune should favour a whore before
An honest woman. 'Twas the sweetest Letter,
The daintiest winning things—(the Devills in't)
Shee must not carry't from the widow so.
Fetch mee the Letter againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Wat.
SP.P: Do you thinke shee'l part with't sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Cannot you beat it out of her sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Wat.
SP.P: I cannot tell how to do that.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Thus sir—i'le give you demonstration, you ma∣licious Rogue, you that conspirst with her to betray me, so good a Master I have beene to thee, and so good a friend to her, i'le recompence you both.

SP.SPEAKER: Wat.
SP.P: You have undone us both, and will discard us now you are warme in your Unkles bosome agen—but—

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: But what you Traitor you?

SP.SPEAKER: Wat.
SP.P: You put me in good minde, and if I do not some∣what.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: I owe you somewhat for your last-nights absence, too pernicious Villaine that kepst thy selfe out o' the way o' purpose that I should bee drunke, and abuse my self, and the house here all lay o' your absence, There's somewhat more for that.

SP.SPEAKER: Wat.
SP.P: 'Tis all upon account sit.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Who knowes an honest Servingman that wants a good Master.

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: Was it your mans fault Mr. Carelesse? if I be not reveng'd &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: No faith, To speak truth he was as much abus'd in it, as you in doing a thing as contrary to his vile con∣ditions, as you did to your noble Name. But I crave onely your pardon, I know not what I doe besides. This crosse blow of chance staggers my reason so—

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: Well sir, since I have found the errour, my reason reconciles me to you, and since it grew out of your equall intent to cast off the evill, as to embrace the good, I will re-mediate for you to the widow.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: But yet shee'l know I have had a whore. Yet then you may say, 'tis such a running Disease among young Gentlemen, that not one of a hundred has scap'd it, that have prov'd stay'd men afterwards, and very so∣ber husbands; As looke you yonders one may prove, whom now I have in good sooth a great desire to beate.

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: In your Aunts presence, and your Unkles house; Though I were not his friend; could you be so outragi∣ous? I muse I see him here though.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Cry you mercy sir, are you his friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: I make my selfe so, hee being dependent to my noblest Lord, whom I am bound to honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: What Lord I pray, that I may honour him too.

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: The Lord Lovely.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: That loves women above wine, wine above wealth, wealth above friend, and friends above himselfe. There's no scandall in all that sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: It goes so of him indeed, but he loves honor above all those.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Mr. Saveall a word.

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: Your servant Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: In the name of flesh, for what dos his Lordship employ that Angle-worme to my Aunt? Hee has had her this houre in private conference, close chamberd up together, not so much as Matron Nurse in the roome with 'em, 'Tis a fine sleeke thing, and almost pitty to hunt it, but sure I must beat it, as place and time conve∣nient may serve.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Pray Mr. Saveall move you my Husband for it, I would not medle in his money matters wil∣lingly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: Five hundred pound for my Lord upon the men∣tioned security, I will break it to sir Oliver.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Is that the businesse after so much privacy? very prety, my Aunts a woman too, and me Unkle may have as forked a fortune, as any of the City, that lend out mo∣ney to hedge in Lordships.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: I am his Lordships servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: And I your Lordships good Madam. And yours Mr. Saveall.

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: I am for your way Mr. Bellamy.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: And I sir, and't please you.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: George Carelesse, I would speak with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: May I not wait upon your Gentleman to the Gate Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: No good George, though I commend your cur∣tesie, yet would I not you should neglect your owne dignity.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Umh—I am under Government.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: The young man, if you have modesty will thinke you mock him, if not you'l make him become arrogant, know you not whose man he is?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: No tis apparent, this over-slighting of him pro∣claimes shee loves him, whose follower Madam, and I know Lords followers, Knights fellows.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Not all Lords followers to all Knights George.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: To as many as their faire Ladies will give way to, that are not faint-hearted.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: I understand you not George; something troubles you, you are not right to day.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: I am only as I am in your favour Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Come I know what perplexes you▪ and 'tis there∣fore that I desire to talke with you; I am not angry with you, but let mee tell you George, although not openly I tooke notice of the pickle you came home in last night, after your Unkle was in Bed; to whom, mer∣vayling at your absence I excus'd you, as gone at my request to visit some Ladies with whom you staid Supper, I told him, when you were with your Roucers.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: But did you never go?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Indeed I did, and he was satisfied.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: O my sweet Lady Aunt! I was indeed amongst'em, and deeply merry.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: And drunke as deeply!

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: I will abuse your goodnesse so no more.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Say and hold George, for your own good.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: What's now become of mee, I am under cor∣rection.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: I would you could have seene your selfe, and how your disguise became you, as I was told, I do but friend∣ly tell you of some passages, as they were to mee related, by those whom I have charm'd to speake no more on't. Be secure therefore in your Unkle.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: O my deare heavenly Aunt!

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: First, at the doore you bounc'd like a Giant at the Gate of an inchanted Castle, before which could be opened offence was taken by you at your Sedan-men; for asking money (as appeard afterwards) more then you brought from the Taverne, and leaving their office fouler by a distemper'd stomach-full, then you found it. In the strife for these sad causes your Sword being seiz'd on, you being unable to use it, were found by my servants at Luggs with your brace of Corps bearers, in the dirt, and their poore hovill Chaire turnd on his ridge in the Kennell.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: I'le never be drunk agen.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: I hope you will say so, when you have heard all George; but by the way your late stock being spent, here are ten peeces towards a supply.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: O sweet golden Aunt!

Well sir, the striefe appeas'd, you were tane in. Then hay is there no Sack i'the house? Tis for you in you Chamber is replid, up you are had, where is the Rogue my man? not seene since Yesterday; Fetch me a wench. Blesse us cries old Sim the Butler, wee have none i'th house, nor cannot send for any out o' dores. Dost—tell me that? is not my Ladies Woman, my Ladies Chamber-maide, the Laundry-maide, the wench under the Cooke, my Ladies Nurse old Winter plum, nor my Lady her selfe within? I know, or will know all the shee things in the house.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: But why me up in your bedroll George?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Peigh.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: You remember none o' this!

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: It is not worth it Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Nor how you scar'd Chamber-maid, whom I sent in love to see care taken for you, not dreaming of any ill thought in you, doe you remember how you told her, and what you would give her, when your Unkle died for a small present curtesie? she was faine to saisfie you with a false promise to steale to bed to you before foure men could force, or humor you into it.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: What an unhallowed Rascall was I!

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: 'Tis well you consider it now. And still consider George.
How ill excesse of Wine, Roaring and VVhoring be∣comes a Gentleman, and how well sobrietie, curtesie, and noble action, and dangers wait upon the one sort, and what safety accompanies the other!

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Wine, Roaring and Whoring, I will lay that say∣ing of yours Madam to my heart; but Wine is the great wheele that sets the rest a whirling.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: True George, for had you not first beene ullied with Wine, you would not have abus'd your selfe to ha tumbled in the dirt with your Litter-mules, nor offer'd to seduce my Chamber-maide. Suppose you had over∣come her, how could you have come off but with shame to your selfe, and the utter ruine of the poore Wench?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Still shee corrects me for my medling with base matters and people, shee is not angry shee sayes, though I call'd for her last night i'my drinke, shee gives me mo∣ny, I will now understand her, and whereunto all her former favours and her later admonitions are directed, and presently appeare a gratefull Nephew.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Nay, bee not sad upon it George, as I would win you from your faults, I would have you still be cheer∣full. If any thought troubles you, you may be free with me George.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: O Madam you have made me, and now take me to you.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: How meane you?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Freely and wholly, the truest, faithfullst servant, and I thinke the ablest that any Lady of your lacks and longings ever bestowd a favour on, though I say' my self. You'l swear't when you have tri'd me, and't be but houre∣ly for a month together.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Is the man sound troe?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: I defy Surgeon, or the Potecary can come against mee.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Sound i' your senses sir, I meane.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: O for blabbing Madam never feare mee, now I am resolv'd to live soberly, and be onely yours. And with such pleasure, with such safety, secresie, and fulnesse, I will so constantly supply you, that you shall not have time to dreame of the defects of your old man.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Doe you meane your Unkle, and not know whose wrong you unnaturally and sinfully pursue?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: No man living Madam can doe it for him, more naturally and lesse sinfully; I am of the same flesh and blood, and bring his youth to your pleasure, how can you thinke old Unkles children are got? or how came up the proverbe, Shee is one of mine Aunts, doe you thinke? You would have a child by him. All your Cawdells and Cock-broaths will never doe it, An old mans generative spirit runs all into braine, and that runs after covetousnesse too, get wealth, not children. Believe it, much Nephews helpe belongs to it, and then the chil∣dren are not degenerate, I cannot thinke but many Unkles know it, and give way to it, because stranger bloods shall not inherit their Lands, and so sweet Aunt if I live not to inherit his, my son may, in your first born. There will be a sweet comfort to you.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: But is all this in earnest?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: In earnest? yes, And I pray so take it, and let it be a bargaine, and now presently in the Chamber, I will make you my first payment for the purchace.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Fie, fie, you doe but say so?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: That shall be tri'd presently. Come sweet Ma∣dam, I finde you are willing, and I sweare I am resolute, and will be as secret as your own woman, if you will not goe I protest i'le carry you.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Nay preythee George set me down a little.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Psewgh—I need none o' these whesings I.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: But prathee tell mee, dost thou not all this onely to trie me, or am I a Rogue thinke you, or wouldst thou seriously that thine own naturall Unkle, thy bountifull Patron, nay thy father on the matter, should suffer such a wrong, and done by us?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Harke there againe, Madam have I not proved sufficiently and plainely, that I shall in doing the feate for him doe him the greatest right in the world, in getting him, and you an indubitable heire, and to give him both the comfort, and the glory of it?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Was ever such a Reprobate?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: And you can doe him no wrong (though you had not a Ladies priviledge) to Cuckold him, for assure your selfe hee Cuckqueanes you, now come Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: You speake not on your knowledge.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: I never was his Pimpe, but what I have heard, I have heard. Now come Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: I heard Mr. Saveall protest within these three days that hee thought my Husband the chastest man (of a Gentleman) that he knows.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: O did hee so, Madam, believe it they two have whor'd together, and that Saveall has pimpt for him of∣tener then you ever lay with my Unkle.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: What! since he married me?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: What else? Saveall is not onely his grave Para∣site, but his Pimpe, and has spent my Unkle more in these civill punctuall wayes, then I in all my whole de∣bauches, what did you thinke hee kept him for? O they are a brace of subtle dry Tweakes, come now Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: What an inhumane Villain's this▪

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: I'le tell you all now upon our inward acquain∣tance.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: You have told too much already to have any ac∣quaintance with me at all, nor shall you, unlesse you pre∣sently recant all that you have, or would have said upon this subject.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Madam—

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Stand further and replie not, lesse I call in those that shall sadly silence you. Have you abus'd your Unkle, and the next best friend you have i' the World, in hope thereby to abuse mee most, that was no enemy of yours till now you justly have provok'd me?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: I tooke not a right course.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Was this the best construction you could make of my love to you, or a fit requitall, to make me an incestu∣ous Whore?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Yes, yes, a pox my course was right enough, but I undertooke her at an ill season. Her spruce springall left her but now, i'le tell her so Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Come I perceive you are sorry; and that's a part of satisfaction. Therefore for once I'le winke at your transgression, especially before others. Here's one you see.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: I doe, the Devill blind her.

SP.SPEAKER: Nur.
SP.P: Madam—

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: But tempt me so againe, and i'le undoe you.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: I know how you'l undoe mee witty Madam, Ah—

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Nay be not sad George, discover not your selfe, and you are safe, for once I tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Shee'l come about I see.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: But will you Cozen goe, and doe that for me?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Most readily good Madam, I have your full di∣rections.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: All Cosen, if you forget not.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: I cannot be so negligent in your service Madam, I finde by this fain'd errand shee dares not trust her trol∣lop there, I love her wit now too.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: He is both schoold, and coold I hope. Now Closet what's your News?

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Of a Citizen Madam that intreats to speake with your Ladiship.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Doe you not know his Name, or Trade?

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Yes, I had both eene now, but I have such a Head.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: If you have lost 'em by the way pray go back and seeke 'em, or bring you his businesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: I ask'd his businesse Madam, and told him hee might trust mee with it without a hand to his booke, but he said it could not be delivered, but by his owne word o' mouth to your Ladiship.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: What strange matter is it troe? or what Citizen, is not his Name Saleware?

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Yes Madam, and he is a (O this head) a—

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: A Silkeman is he not?

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Yes Madam the same.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: I hope his impudent Wife has not told him all; if shee has, where's his remedy in this Womans Law∣case?

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: There's a Gentleman with him too Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P:
Then wee shall have it, 'Tis his Wife sure, well I
am prepar'd for the incounter. Bid 'em come up, if they grow violent or too bold with mee, i'le set my Nephew George upon 'em. 'Tis not his Wife, what Creature is it troe with me, Mr. Saleware?

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.P: Craving your pardon Madam, a few words in the behalfe of this poore Kinsewoman of mine, touching a Gentleman, who I heare lives in your House, Mr. George Carelesse, Madam, by whom shee has received much injury.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: How sir I pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.P: Pray Madam read this Letter, weepe not, but hold up thy head Cuz, wee will not be dasht, nor basht in a good cause; pray read you Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: I am now (Lady) in favour with my Ʋnkle, and in faire possibility of a good Estate, deporting my selfe (I intend to doe) a civill Gentleman. To which end (induc'd as well by reason, as by long continued affections) I tender my selfe to you in the holy con∣dition of Marriage. If you vouchsafe your consent, (which is my most earnest request) I shall not onely declare my selfe a good Husband, but the most happy,

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.P: Wherein appeares the injury to your Kinswo∣man?

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.P: In flying from his Word, and Deed Madam. He has borne her in hand these two yeares, and use her at his pleasure, detaining her from her choyce of many good fortunes, and at last sends her this to make amends for all, and denies his act the next day, sending his man to take the Letter from her, pretending 'twas directed to another. But never the sooner for a hasty word Cosen, we will not be dasht nor basht, I warrant thee.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Here's the direction. To the Lilly white Hands of Mistris Mariana Gymcrack, is that your Name Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Phe.
SP.P: I am the sorrowfull one that is knowne by it Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.P: Never the sooner for a hasty word Cosen.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: I conceive the businesse, and find the error, and my great doubt is over.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.P: Weepe not I say.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: What would you have me doe Mr. Saleware?

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.P: You have discretion Madam, and I made choice of your Ladiship to open this matter unto you, rather then to Sir Oliver himselfe, whom I would not willing∣ly exasperate against his Nephew, you may be pleased in a milder way to temper him, and worke a satisfaction for my Kinsewoman; Sir Oliver and your selfe Madam, are noble Customers to my Shop, and for your sakes I would not deale rigourously with your Kinseman, if a gentle end may be made. But, if you cannot so compound it, the Law lies open, money and friends are to be found, a good cause shall not be sterv'd, I will not be dasht not basht, Sapientia mea mihi is my word, and so good Madam you know my mind.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: 'Tis pity a Gentlewoman should suffer too much, and I like her so well at first sight, that I am easily mov'd to doe good for her, is shee your Kinsewoman in blood Mr. Saleware, or your wifes?

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.P: Mine I assure your Ladiship, though my wife can boast as great and noble friends I thank fortune, as the wife of any Tradesman that carries a head in the City, (but that's by the by) yet I came of a better house, and am a Gentleman borne, none disprais'd.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Well Mr. Saleware, leave your Kinsewoman with me a little while, you shall not be scene in my act, i'le try what I can doe for her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.P: With all my heart good Madam, and dee heare Marina, This is a noble Lady, beare your selfe discreetly in the businesse, and towards her: you may get a Hus∣band by't, or at least a composition that may purchace one to sholder you up. But carry it high and worthy of the house I brag of, or—Sapientia mea mihi, stultitia tua tibi, That's my sentence.

SP.SPEAKER: Phe.
SP.P: Well sir, you neede not doubt my high Car∣riage.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Take▪ this Gentlewoman to your Chamber, and I charge you let none see her, or take notice of her, but your selfe and me, till I give order.

DIV3.P: I shall doe something for her doubt not Master Sale∣ware.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.P:
I shall be bound to your Ladiship, now to my Shop, to which I thanke my Wife shee has beene a Wild∣cat these two dayes, which must be borne with as wee are friends. And from my House all Night, and yet no Greene-goose-faire-time; Nor though shee were so ab∣sent must I be so unfriendly as to question her, where, or with whom shee was; a new Article this twixt Man and Wife! But Sapientia mea mihi, stultitia sua sibi. Thus it must be where Man and Wife are friends, and will continue so in spight of chance, or high heeld shooes, that will awry sometimes with any Women. Shee is not yet come home heere. WhatThe Shop discover'd, Alicia, & Bellamy. Ladies that, and not my Wife there to handle her handsomely for her Money? My servants are such Assinegoes! stay, are mine eyes perfect? 'Tis shee, 'tis my Friend∣wife, and in the Courtly habit, which so long shee has long'd for. And my Lord Lovelies Gammed with her.
His Lordship lay not at home to Night, neither at his Lodging, I heard that by the way. I cannot thinke my Lord and shee both sate up all Night to see the Taylors at worke, and to hasten the finishing of those Cloaths, if shee were with him which I would not be so unfriend∣ly to inquire for the worth of a Wife. 'Twas right ho∣norably done of him to send her home as gallantly at∣tended as attir'd, if shee die—a—a—lie with him all Night, which I will not be such a beast to believe al∣though I knw it. I must come on her with a little wit though, for which I will precogitate.

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Once more your story, for I am not satisfied with thrice being told it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Can a Woman take so much delight in hearing of another Womans pleasure taken?

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: As it was given by you I can, for I am prepard by it to take pleasure from you, and shall with greedinesse expect it till I have it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Then know I pleas'd her so, that shee protest∣ed, (and I believe her) her Husband never pleas'd her so.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Or any other man you should ha' put her to that, her Husband's but a Bungler.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: How know you that?

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: I doe but guesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Nay shee swore deeply, and I believ'd her there too, no man besides her husband but my selfe had e're injoy'd her, but let me tell you Lady, as shee was amply pleas'd she may thanke you.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: For sending you, I know shee did and will.

LG.L: That was the first respect, but not the greatest:
For in our Act of love, our first and second Act—

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: In reall deed, I can speak now like an embolden'd Lover.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Well, but what in your Acts of Love?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: I had you still in my imagination, and that en∣abled mee to be more gratefull to her Ladyship, which wrought her thankfulnesse to you, exprest in a hundred pieces, sent by me, more then I tould before, which are your own shee sayes, since tother morning shee was here with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: That token confirmes all. Had I the spirit of Witchcraft, when puting upon chance for my Revenge, to find Reward! Have you the money?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Safe at my Chamber for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: O you are cunning, lesse I should breake with you you thought to oblige me by't.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: I'le rather run and fetch you twice the summe, I conceal'd it onely to give it you unexpectedly.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Sweete Bellamy I am yours, I could be sorry now I have lost so much of thee. This Kisse, and Name your time—

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.P: Would they had done whispering once, that I might enter safe in my manners.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: To morrow night.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Shall you be ready so soone thinke you after your plentifull Lady-feast.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: O with all fulnesse both of Delight and Ap∣petite.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: And with all faith and secresie I am undone else, you know my vowes unto my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: And can you thinke I dare be found your meane, to break'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: No more my husband comes. Pray Sir returne my thanks unto my Lord for his right noble bounty, and not mine alone, for so my husband in much duty bound also presents his thanks unto his Lordship.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.P: Yes, I beseech you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: I am your willing Messenger.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.P: Hee is my most honored Lord, and has so many wayes obliged me both by my wife, and in mine owne particular that—

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: I take my leave.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.P: Still this is an Assinego. I can never get him to stand a Conference, or a Complement with mee. But Sapientia mea mihi, what was that friend you made mee send thanks for to his Lordship, what new favour has hee done us, besides his councell—These Clothes, the cost was mine you told mee, out of the odd hundred pound you tooke, what late Honour has hee done us?

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: It not enough I know Friend? will you ever trans∣gresse in your impertinent inquisitions?

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.P: I cry you mercy friend, I am corrected justly.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Will you never be governd by my judgement, and receive that onely fit for you to understand, which I de∣liver to you undemanded? Doe not I know the weight of your floore thinke you? Or doe it you on pur∣pose to infringe friendship, or breake the peace you live in?

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.P: Never the sooner for a hasty word, I hope Friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Did you not Covenant with mee that I should weare what I pleased, and what my Lord lik'd, that I should be as Lady-like as I would, or as my Lord desir'd; that I should come, and go at mine own pleasure, or as my Lord requir'd; and that we should be alwayes friends and call so, not after the sillie manner of Citizen and Wife, but in the high courtly way?

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.P: All this, and what you please sweete Courtly∣friend I grant as I love Court-ship, it becomes thee bravely.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: O dos it so?

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.P:
And I am highly honor'd; And shall grow fat by
the envy of my repining Neighbours, that cannot main∣taine their Wives so like Court-Ladies, some perhaps (not knowing wee are friends) will say shee's but Tom Salewares Wife, and shee comes by this Gallantry the Lord knowes how, or so. But Sapientia mea mihi, let the Assinegos prate while others shall admire thee, sitting in thy Shop more glorious, then the Maiden-head in the Mercers armes, and say there is the Nonparrell, the Pa∣ragon of the Citie, the Flower-de-luce of Cheapside, the Shop Court-ladie, or the Courtshop Mistris, ha' my sweet Courtlie friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: How do you talke? As if you meant to instruct'em to abuse me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.P: Sapientia mea mihi.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: To prevent that I will remove out of their walke, and keepe shop no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.P: Never the lesse for a hasty word I hope Friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Fie, 'tis uncourtly, and now i'le tell you Friend, unaskd, what I have done for you besides in my late ab∣sence, and all under one.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.P: Under one! yes, I could tell her under whom if I durst.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: What's that you say Friend? mee thinkes you mutter.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.P: No Friend, I was guessing what that other thing might bee that you have done for mee, all under one. You have taken the House i'le warrant, that my Lord lik'd so.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: By my Lords favour and direction I have taken it, And I will furnish it so Courtly you'l ad∣mire.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.P: Must I then give up Shop, or lie so far remote?

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: No you must keepe your Shop Friend, and lie here if you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.P: And not with you but there?

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: No not with me at all Friend, that were most un∣courtly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.P: But I shall have a Chamber in your house, and next to yours. Then in my Gowne and Slippers Friend at Mid∣night—or the first Cock.—

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Softly for stumbling Friend, i'le doe you any honourable offices with my Lord, as by obtaining sutes for you, for which you must looke out, and finde what you may fitly beg out of his power, and by courtly fa∣vour. But keepe your Shop still Friend, and my Lord will bring and send you such custome, that your Neighbours shall envy your wealth, and not your Wife; you shall have such commings in abroad and at home, that you shall be the first head nominated i' the next Sheriffe sea∣son, but I with my Lord will keepe ▪you from prick∣ing. Bee you a Cittizen still Friend, 'tis enough I am Courtly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.P: Here's a new Courtlie humour, I see no remedy, unlesse I run my selfe out of credit, defie the life of a Cit∣tizen, and turn Courtly too.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: What's that you say? doe you not mutter now Friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.P: No, not a sillable Friend, but may not I give up Shop and turne Courtly too Friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: As you respect my Lord, and your own profit, you must be a Cittizen still, and I am no more a Cittizens Wife else, and shee must be a Cittizens Wife, that wust doe all in all with my Lord Friends. Though my Lord loves the Clothes of the Court, hee loves the diet of the City best Friend, what ever I weare outwardly hee must finde me Cittizens Wife, which Friend, O hee's a sweet Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.P: Well it shall be then as the sweete Lord will have it, Sapientia mea mihi.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.

LG.L: LAdy, 'tis true hee is a bashfull Lover,
Unskill'd to court a Widow, has not yet,
The Act methodicall to sweare he loves you,
Must and will have you, nor the moving boldnesse
To stirre your blood by putting of you to't,
Or shewing you how tis, before the Priest
Declares it lawfull. But he has love and sweetnesse,
Which you will find with full and rich content;
And look (look here) what a long, middle finger he has,
Which with thin Jawes, and Roman Nose,
Are never fayling signes of Widowes joyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Your Lordship is dispos'd to mirth;

LG.L: It is
My care to put you in a course of mirth,
Nay of felicity.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: In marrying of that stripling!

LG.L: Do not thinke slghtly of him, tho'he appeares
Modest and bashfully, if I have any judgement,
Hee's a fit match for you. His outward fortune
For his estate, I will make good to him,
And for his inward vertue never doubt
Hee'l make that good to you; However still
He holds his much commended Modesty.
My Lord you much commend his modestie,
And bashfulnesse, urging your confidence
Of his strange inward hid abilities
(I hope your Lordships pardon) can you tell,
If hee has with that bashfull modesty
Got any of his Mothers Maides with child?
Or of his Fathers Tenants Wifes, or Daughters?
I would have some assurance.
Then i'le tell you.
These Widowes love to heare of manly acts,
And choose their husbands by their backs, and faces.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: My Lord you said youl'd tell me.

LG.L: Yes, but I would not have you cunningly
To sift discoveries from me to his wrong.
I am loth to speake so plainely to you my Lord,
But by the worst that you can speake of him
I may the better like him.
That's her humor;
Then hearke you Widow, to avoid his blushes,
Suppose I tell hee has got a bastard.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: You may as well suppose i'l say 'twas well.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: What say you to two or three!

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: The more the merrier.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: He has no lesse then five old Gentlemens Young Wives with child this Moone, but got all in One weeke.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: Yes, in good deed, and lusty.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Good deed call you it, to get other Mens Children?

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: Suppose they have the husbands consents.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: I suppose they are wittalls then.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: No they are wisealls, and 'tis a thing in much request among landed men, when old and wanting issue of their owne, to keepe out riotous Kindred from in∣heritance, who else would turne the Land out of the Name.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: An excellent policie!

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: You know the Lady Thrivewell.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: And her old husband, and his riotous Kinseman too.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: You will heare more hereafter, but now to him agen, for whom I am spokesman.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: In a strange way me thinks.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: Hee is sent for farre and neere on those occasions, hee is of so sweete a Composure, and such sure taking mettall, that hee employes my care to have him well bestowd before he begins to wast.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Ist possible hee has done so much, and sayes so little?

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: The deepest waters are most silent,
But he can speake, and well to Bellamy.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: My Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: I have made your love knowne to this Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: My love my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: And have begun your suit; follow't your selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: My suit my Lord to her? I never mov'd your Lordship to't, Tho' I presume she may be a happy fortune to one of my condition; a poore and younger brother; onely made rich and happy in your Lordships service, and over-flowing favours.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: Which i'le take off o' you if you slight my care in seeking your preferment to this Lady, of beauty equall with her faire estate, in both which shee is great, and her atchievement will be the Crowne, and the continuance of all my favours to you, you are lost▪ if you pursue it not, I would thy old Unkle Bellamy saw thy Bash∣fulnesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Your Lordship seemes now to wooe for me, not him, however I am bound in thanks to your noblenesse, in your faire proportion, I hope, I shall not be so poore to require an advocate, when I shall yeild to have a hus∣band. But your mirth becomes your honor, and the young gentlemans reservednes him, Ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: How meane you Mistris Crostill?

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: I doe commend your mirth my Lord, for the lusty straine you spoke him in, that he had yet five children in one weeke, wherein I may presume you thought you had mov'd to my liking, ha, ha, ha—

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: I am glad I have made you merry, But you will wish if you reject him—

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: If I reject one that tenders not himselfe! yet I commend his caution.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: As how I pray?

LG.L: As thinking I am one of your cast peeces
(Knowing how well your Lordship loves the game)
And now would put mee on him,
But you misprise mee sinfully sweet Youth
In such a thought, how e're you should not scorne
To ride in your Lords cast boots, though you be Gentle∣man of's house.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: Come now he shall have none of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: I'le heare him say he will not first, by your Lord∣ships leave.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: Spirit of contradiction!

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Stay sir, would you be content to have me?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: You heard my Lord say I should not.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: But say he say agen you shall, speake, will you have mee?

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: Say no (I finde her now) that is the way to win her.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Without instructions good my Lord.

LG.L: Lady I finde so much your scorn already,
That to be wedded to't, I should dispaire
(My much unworthinesse consider'd) to convert it
Ever to love, and 'tis your love, before
Your Person or Estate, that my affection
Ought to direct mee to.
In answer therefore, to your will, you have mee,
I must say no, till I perceive some signe
Of love in you towards me.
I now he speakes!
Some signes of love in me? How would you have it?
Must I declare it to you, before you seeke it?
No; I would seeke it zealously, but my Lord
Is off on't now, and I may lose his favour.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Is your love limited by his favour then?

LG.L: Not limited: but (as it is as yet,
But in its infancy) a little checkt,
Though it still growes, and may extend beyond
All limitation to so faire an object
As is your selfe: But still my own demerit
Curbs my ambition more then love emboldens.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: He speakes within me now.

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: Stay, let us retire. Here is the Lord Lovely.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Be he a Lord of Lords i'le not retire a foot.

LG.L: What servants Mistris Crostill doe you keep.
To let intruders in?
O Mr. Saveall!

DIV3.STAGE: Carless salutes Crostill, & puts by Bellamy.

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: The humblest of your Lordships servants.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: What Gentlemen is that you bring with you?

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: It is the Newphew of the good Knight Sir Oliver Thrivewell, of which Sir Oliver, I have procured unto your Lordship the sum which you desired by your servant Mr. Bellamy.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: For that I thanke him and you, but I could wish you had not brought that Nephew hither now.

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: Certes my Lord I am sorry.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: My reason is, I have enter'd Bellamy a suitor to the Widow.

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: He also comes a suiter.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P:
And is in deepe discourse with her already,
I'le see faire play.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: But you shall heare mee Widow, and that to the point and purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: Lady at my request, doe this Gentleman (who made the first approach) the favour to be, heard, and answer'd first.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: As his approach was first my Lord, shee has heard him first already, and my request is to be heard now, and then let her answer both him, or me, or neither, what care I?

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: Your Name is Carelesse I take it.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: I came to talke with this Gentlewoman.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Pray my Lord forbeare him, and let him speake, what do you say sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: I say I love you, doe resolve to marry you, and then to use you as I list.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: I say I love you, doe resolve to marry you, and then to use you as I list.—To Bell.—

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: This to mee Lady? i'le take you at your word.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Stay, I doe but tell you what he sayes.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Take her at her word againe sir, and I shall take you by the luggs. I say againe you shall have none but me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: I say again, you shall have none but me,—To Bel.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: What, doe you foole mee, or him, your selfe, or all?

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Pray sir how old are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Are you good at that, pray sir, how old are you?—To Bel.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: You presse beyond your priviledge, which is only to speake to the Gentlewoman.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: My Lord I am a Gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: You may tell her so.

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: Let we beseech your Lordship.

LG.L: How can you use a Gentleman that loves you
Dearer then Life, and onely bends his study
By all meanes to deserve you, one that (can not?)
Will not, while there are wayes to die, live out of
Your favour, with so much despightfull scorne,
That when he speakes his soul to you through his lips,
You make his Language yours, and give't a Boy?

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: What Gentleman's that you speake of?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: The man that speakes it I am he.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: All this sir in effect, and more of my affection, can I speake to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Uns, but you shall not, you mistake the person to whom you are, or ought to direct your affection, you mistake strangely.

LG.L: No more then once a Lover, or at least,
A bold pretender, having in civill language
Exprest in writing his affection
To a chast Mistris sea'd, and directed it,
And on the contrary, courted his vertuous friend in bro∣thell language;
To a lewd strumpet. Have I hit you sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: What can I say now! Slife if that anger you after the errour found, and confest, i'le write worse to you, and in earnest.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Mr. Bellamy some other time I shall be glad to see you.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Shee meanes that to mee now, but i'le take no notice; i'le finde as good a Widow in a Taverne Chim∣ney, O shee's a dainty Widow!

LG.L: Hee lookes with scorne at mee, I must not lose him, yet dare not stay, for feare I tell him so.
I humbly crave your pardon good my Lord,
For my ill manners, and abrupt departure;
The cause is urgent, and I beseech your mercy,
Question it not.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: Let your will guide you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Mr. Saveall I thanke you for my Suitor.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Nay but Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Yes you shall controwle mee in my owne House.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Yes, yes, I meane so too, but you shall wooe mee hard first.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: 'Tis a mad Widow, which of these two now think you has the Better on't?

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: I thinke he shall in the end have the best my Lord, that can slight her most.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: 'Tis my opinion too, and heare mee—

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Sir, I have seene you but twice, and it has beene at places where I cannot allow of your resorts, first at my Aunts, and now here at my Widowes.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Your Widow sir! I thought shee had beene the Widow of one deceas'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Thou art a witty, pretty Child. But doe you here use your wit, out of the smell-reach of your Lords perfum'd Gloves, and I shall take you by the Nose.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Forbeare sir, I have a Handkercher.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: And let me finde you there no more, nor here I charge you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: I heare your charge sir, but you must leave it to my discretion to obey it, or not.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Trust to your discretion!

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: And so commend mee to my Lady Thrivewel Come Bellamy away, what's your discourse?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: All faire and friendly my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Very good.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: So should it be with Rivalls, fare you well Mr. Carelesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Your Lordships—with a whew.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: Will you walke homewards?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Excuse me sir I pray.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: It will not be convenient to returne this day un∣to the Widow.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Feare it not sir, I like her not so well now.

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: Doe your pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Ha' you crosse tricks Mistris Crostill? well I will goe drinke your Crotchets out of my Pate, then home, and doe that which mine Aunt and I must only know. This is her Night of Grace, if shee keepe touch with me.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: IN truth your story is pittifull, but your own folly has brought your scourge upon you.

SP.SPEAKER: Phe.
SP.P: 'Twas through the blindnesse of my love, and my credulity Madam, wrought by his strong Temp∣tations.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Well, for this once i'le straine a point of honour for you, chiefly indeed in answer of his rude unnaturall presumption in attempting mee. That a Villaine can still be so barbarously lustfull! If in this way I fit him not, and cause him to desist his beastly purpose, I will discover all to his undoing. Closet you know my minde, and ful directions for the conveyance of our designe.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Yes Madam, doubt not. Though I have but a naughty head at most, other matters, I dare not trust it for a sure one at such conveyances.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P:
I presume to further the matter, hee'l come
home Drunke by his not comming to Supper.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Then he may forget what he so much expected, or sleepe away his expectation.

SP.SPEAKER: Phe.
SP.P: No, hee will then be the more vehement till his desire be over.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: You know his humour best it seemes, away, away, my husband comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Thr.
SP.P: Well Wat, for this discovery i'le make thy re∣ward worth ten such masters services.

SP.SPEAKER: Thr.
SP.P: Sweet heart I have a suit to you—But first what Woman's that with Nurse?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: A Kinswoman of hers whom shee would pre∣ferre to mee, but I have answer'd her, I will not charge your purse with more attendants; onely I have given her leave to entertaine, and lodge her this night.

SP.SPEAKER: Thr.
SP.P: That's my good Girle.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Now what's your suite sir, (as you are pleas'd to call it) which I would have to be your free com∣mand?

SP.SPEAKER: Thr.
SP.P: 'Tis for my absence from thee, to accompany Mr. Saveall, to bring a deare friend on his way to Graves∣end to night, who is sodainly to depart the Land.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: These sodaine departures of friends out of the Land, are so frequent, and that I may believe you intend really, and no fained excuse; now will I thinke as long as you have good and substantiall Made-worke at home, that you will seeke abroad for any more slight sale-ware.

SP.SPEAKER: Thr.
SP.P: No more o'that Sweet heart, farewell, expect me early in the morning.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P:
I am glad of his absence to night, lest there should happen some cumbustion in the house by his un∣uly Nephew, in case hee should discover my deceipt in beguiling him with his own wench instead of me, I do even
tremble to thinke upon the unnaturall Villaine, that would offer so to wrong his Unkle. I thought I had school'd him sufficiently, and beaten him off at his first attempt, and hee to assaile me againe with more forcible temptations urging me to a promise.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: The young Gentleman is come in Madam, and as you foresaw very high flowne, but not so drunke as to forget your promise! Hee's going to bed in expectation of your approach.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: And have you put his Damsell into her night∣attire?

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Most Lady-like I assure you Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: And let her be sure to steale from him before Day.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Yes, with all silence Madam, she has promised.

LG.L: May Ladies that shall heare this story told,
Judge mildly of my act since hee's so bold.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: NAy but looke you Mr. Bellamy, it is not I protest that I am jealous, I make this inquiry for my wife. I jealous? I an Asinego then, I am as confident of my wife, as that she is in this house, how ere you deny her to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Why Lady, you are not jealous now? If you were not, you would believe me she is not here.

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P:
Without equivocation, Mr. Bellamy, shee is not here—indeed, under your foot, but shee's here in the house, and under some body for ought any body knows, but my selfe, that doe confide in her as I say, and will
know no such matter; And so my Lords will be done with her, I hope I shall see hr well to morrow, and at her own house.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Can such language proceed out of any but a jealous mouth?

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: What an Assinego's this! I say againe, I doe con∣fide in her, nor will I be dasht, or basht at what any man sayes of, or against her; And therefore me thinks tis very strange that you should deny her to me, that comes not to molest her.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: There you are againe. But since no denyall will serve your turne, indeed shee is here in this house, and in bed by this time.

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: Away, away, you mock ifaith, you are a wag shee's no more here then I am, if she were here can I thinke you would tell?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: How came you to thinke, or dreame shee was in this house at all?

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: I neither thought it, or dreamt it. I but sir, a wa∣terman brought me a Letter in hast from one Mr. Ano∣nimus, intimating that my Ally was with a private friend at this house, and to lie here all night (a very likely matter) what private friend has shee but my Lord, and that in a right honorable way, I confide in 'em both for that; but at this house is such a thing my Lord having divers Lodgings, and shee a house of her own at his dis∣pose and command, that is such a thing to be thought or dreamt on!

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Why came you to inquire then of such a thing?

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: Why sir, this Anonimus writ that I should come hastily hither, and aske to speake with you Mr. Bellamy, and I should know further; hither I came, here I finde you▪ you deny shee is here, and what doe I inquire any further?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: You heare mee say agen shee is here.

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: Goe you are a wag agen, shee here? is my Lord here? or any private friend? alas, alas you are too young Mr. Bellamy, and may as well perswade mee I am jealous.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Well sir, to put you out of all jealousie and doubt (if you be in any) I was the Anonimus that sent you the Letter to draw you hither and declare my selfe your friend, which shall instantly be manifest to you, if now you have a minde to lie with your own wife before any other man.

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: Then shee is here indeed belike.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Pray come with me into the next Chamber.

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: This is some waggery plotted by my wife, I smell it.

DIV3.STAGE: The Bed put forth, Alicia in it. Enter Bellamy, Saleware, with Light.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: But you must be sure to say when shee discovers you, that you came of your owne accord, unsent for, as inspir'd or possest by some Dreame or Vision, to finde her here.

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: Well, if this be not my wifes waggery in a maine proof of her chastity, I am not here. I will doe so sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: So then, obscure your selfe a while, while I ap∣proach her.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Who's there?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: 'Tis I, your servant Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Sweet Bellamy why come you not to Bed?

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: Good.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Dos the love that was so hot, and the desire that was so fervent, begin to coole in you?

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: Good agen, as if hee an Assinego had ever made love to her fine waggery!

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Has my meere consent to satisfie you, cloy'd you?

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: Consent to my Lords man, a likely matter!

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Or did you court me to a promise onely to try my fidelity to your Lord, and then betray me?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Deare Lady thinke not so, but that I am struck into stone with wonder, and amazement at the most un∣expected accident that ever crost a Lover.

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: Dainty waggery this, what little mad Rogues are these to plot this to make me jealous?

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Pray, are you serious? what is the accident?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: I will not be so crost, but kill him rather. To in∣joy such a Mistris, who would not kill a horn'd beast? yet blood is such a horror—

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: Very pretty.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Will you not tell mee?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Speak lower gentle Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Why prithee, who can heare us?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: I know not by what Magick your jealous hus∣band has made discovery of our being here, he wrought sure with the Devill!

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: I am undone then. He will tell my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P:
I shall undoe my selfe then Friend. No, Sapientia mea mihi. Be not dasht nor basht for that good Friend, if there were any such matter: but this is waggery, fine waggery plotted betwixt you▪ to tempt my jealousie, but never the sooner for a hasty word I warrant you. Mr. Bellamy that my Wife is here I thank you; But how I came to know it you shall never know from me; you sent not for mee, I am sure you were not the Anonimus. Indeed it should have been Anonima Friend-wife: for it was thy act I dare sweare; However you doe not heare mee say I was sent, or writ for at all, more then by a Dreame or Vision: But here I am and meane to remaine to night; I hope the house can afford you another Bed in't Mr. Bellamy, and you to leave mee to my owne Friend-wife, I like the lodging most curiously sweete Friend, and I prethee, lets try heartily what luck
we may have in a strange place, I would so faine have a little one like thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: I'le leave you to your wishes, a good night to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Pray sir a word first, husband be farther.

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: Faces about Tom Saleware, and march forwards.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: You told mee sir, of a hundred pound that your sweete Lady Thrivewell sent me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: 'Tis true I have it for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: But shee has since countermanded you to keepe it, has shee, and to mock my expectation of that, and you▪ why have you foold me thus?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: I rather should suspect your craft in this preven∣tion: but love forbids me, and I must conclude, 'tis witch∣craft in your husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Come let's kisse friends, and (sweet) to morrow night I will prevent his Witchcraft, in the full enjoyment of our free pleasures: be you true to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: May all that's Man in me forsake me else.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Another kisse and then good night.

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: Are you still whispering? no matter, let 'em whiswer.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Good night.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Now may the spirits of all injur'd women, be ad∣ded to mine owne, for my revenge, which I this night will dreame of slighted and mock'd, hee and his like shall know,

LG.L: That when a yeilding woman is so crost,
All thoughts but of revenge with her are lost.

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: O hee's gone—Ally, Friend I would say, And now I prithee tell mee how, or why thou cam'st hither.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Will you pardon me?

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: Yes faith, I were no friend else.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: 'Twas but to try if I could make thee jealous.

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: In waggery! did not I say so! when doe my pro∣phecies faile?

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: But what brought you hither thinke you?

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: A Letter from one Anonimus, but i'le eate Spi∣ders, and breake if you sent it not.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Give me the Letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.P: Where is it? facks I ha' lost it.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: 'Twas I indeed that sent it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: Did not I say so too? and that it should ha' been Anonima, Sapientia mea mihi, when doe my prophecies faile? i'le to bed instantly while the prophetick spirit is in mee, and get a small Prophet or a South∣sayer.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: No, i'le have no bed-fellow to night.

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: Nere the lesse for a hasty word, I hope Friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: I am at a word for that.

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: I'le lie upon thy feet then.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Well, you may draw the Curtaines, and sleepe by me.

LG.L: Sapientia mea mihi, stultitia tua tibi.
Puts in the bed,

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV.
DIV3.STAGE: Phebe passes over the stage in night attire, Carelesse followes her as in the darke.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: MAdam, Madam, sweet Madam, 'twill not be day these three houres, stay but three minuits longer, but a touch more, she's whipt into her Cham∣ber. Could I but finde the Dore—I know my Unkle's from home—O shee returnes with light: that's well.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: What aile you! Are you mad?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Would not any man be mad for losing such a Bed-fellow? sweet Madam, let us retire without any noise.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: What an insatiate beast are you? would you un∣doe for ever both me and your selfe?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Not with one doe more I warrant you, come away Madam, Madam, somebody knocks mainly at the gate; and I believe it is my Master return'd before his time!

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: I cannot thinke 'tis he.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: 'Tis the Rogue my man I warrant drunke, and has forgot I turnd him away, but he shall spoyl no sport. Come away Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Closet, goe your wayes downe, and hearke before you—

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: —I will Madam—

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: So now come Madam, I commend you in the charge you have given your watch-woman.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: What charge doe you guesse?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Why to tell my Unkle (if he be come) that hee must not come neare you, that you have had no rest to Night till just now you are fallen asleepe, and so forth.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Goe you are a wicked fellow; I am sorry for any the least favour I have done thee, and doe thou dare to attempt me once more, i'le ha' thee turnd headlong out of my dores.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: I have got her with child to night, with a sparke of mine owne spirit, and longs already to doe me mis∣chiefe. The boy will be like mee, therefore 'tis pity to knock't o'the head: But come Madam tother crash and good night, must I drag you to't?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Touch mee but with a finger, and I'le raise the House.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: You dare not sure, and now take heed you vex me not, have you not been my whore?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: You dare not say so, for spoyling your fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Faith but I dare, and if you will not obey me in a course of further pleasure to night, fetch me a hundred peeces to take a course abroad withall, doe yee looke? I'le make you fetch me hundred after hundred Huswife, when I want it, or shall be pleas'd to call for't. All comes out else, the gates of your fame flies open Lady, I will proclaime our Act.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Dare you forfit your own Reputation so?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: I shall gaine Reputation by't in the company I keepe abroad, and if the Cuckold my Unkle come to the knowledge of it at home, I shall possesse him that you lustfully tempted me to it.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Canst thou be so villanously impudent todestroy thine own fortune to ruine me?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: You may conceale all then, and so will I, and mend my fortune by yours, I will live bravely upon your fortune, and the heire which I have got to Night shall inherit it, my Unkles estate. And therefore indeed I would have all conceald; for my childs good, or rather for mine owne: for it shall goe hard if I put him not in∣to a course in his minority to consume the estate upon me before he come to age.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: I am undone.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: And O that ever I did it!

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Thou Villaine, hast undone me.

LG.L: Come i'le doe you agen, and then all's whole agen;
Y'are both undone, O you prodigious monsters
That have betwixt you made me monster too!
What's to be done, but that I kill you both,
Then fall upon my sword.
Sir, you resume the temper of humanity,
And let the Law distinguish you from them,
You neither are to be their Executioner,
Nor to fall with them.

SP.SPEAKER: Thr.
SP.P: Life to me is torment.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: O the Devill, what a case am I in now!

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Pray heare me sir?

LG.L: Can more be said to aggravate thy shame,
Or my affliction, then I have heard already?

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: Let me intreat you heare her.

LG.L: What shame did you, or what affliction I
Suffer, when you discoverd unto me
Your bargaine of a hundred pound in Saleware,
You understand me. How was life a torment
To me then think you?
Did you not vow forgements then? and thus,
You freely would forgive my act? and thus
Now to revenge it on me to my ruine,
And your own endlesse infamy? O 'tis horrid.
'Tis no revenge at all, onely a shew
To startle you, or try your manly temper,
And so neare to be even with yee as to let you know,
what some wife might perhaps ha' done being so mov'd,
It was my plot indeed to straine you hither to this false
fire discovery, for which i'le give you reasons.

SP.SPEAKER: Thr.
SP.P: O grosse dissimulation.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Mr. Saveall, you have done many faire offices for his Nephew, doe this for me, intreat him to a Confe∣rence a few minutes in my Chamber; if I cleare not my selfe in his and your opinion, and that by witnesses, let me be found the shame of all my Sex.

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: Sir, my councells have been prevalent with your judgement, let me perswade you.

SP.SPEAKER: Thr.
SP.P: But I will have that friend thrust out of dore first.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: I would not that you should, nor give a looke, or word to him till you have heard me; Then exercise your Justice.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: Sir be induc'd to it.

SP.SPEAKER: Thr.
SP.P: You have prevayl'd.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Goe to your Bed agen George, and sleepe, be not affraid of Bug-beares.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Hows this? Shee's come about agen, and has patch'd all up already. I hope shee'l worke mine Unkle to reward mee for my Night-worke, and bring him in time to hold my stirop while his George mounts her; Shee's a delicate well-going beast! I know but one to match her in a course, just the same pace and speede as if I had onely had the breaking, and managing of her my selfe, but the marke goes out of Phebes mouth now; and i'le play my Aunt against all the Town. But how shee thought to fright mee with villaine and impudent. And now goe to bed George, ha, ha, ha, I find her drift. No wit like womens at a sodaine shift.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.

SP.SPEAKER: Lov.
SP.P: BEllamy thou art welcome, and for thy Nephew I must ever thanke thee, he is my best companion.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Bel.
SP.P:
O my good Lord without boast be it spoken, I have ever beene right and straight to your honour, and never did you an ill office in Man, Woman, or Child, what I have said of 'em they have proved at first, or I have wrought 'em to at last. But what doe I speake on't, I
have ever beene for your Lordship, all things I have sworne for you, I have fought for you, I have brok'd for you; I have pimpt for you, but what doe I speake on't?

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: You need not Bellamy: for I know all.

SP.SPEAKER: Ol. B.
SP.P: Oh the Gentlemens Wives, and Farmers Daugh∣ters that I have presented to you in your Summer Pro∣gresses, and winter Journeys about the Countries. But what doe I speake on't—

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: Because thou lov'st to champ upon the bit to please thy old coltish tooth still, thou lov'st the memo∣ry of the former sweets which now thou canst not relish.

SP.SPEAKER: Ol. B.
SP.P: And here i' the City, I have pledg'd more of your severall Mistresses, then in my conscience there be honest Women in't. But what doe I speake on't?

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: I never had so many man.

SP.SPEAKER: Ol. B.
SP.P: Or if you had, what doe I speake on't? and in my conscience agen, I have drunke more to your Lord∣ships health in my dayes, then any Wine-cellar in the City at this day, containes of Spanish French, and Rhe∣nish; but what doe I speake of that either?

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: True Bellamy, fall then upon ome other subject.

SP.SPEAKER: Ol. B.
SP.P: Yes, my good Lord, and I pray your Lordship tell mee, dos not my Nephew drinke and wench pretty handsomely? I would faine have him take after me, and not his drunken father.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: How well hee shifts his subject, wicked old fel∣low!

SP.SPEAKER: Ol. B.
SP.P: Dos he not begin to fall to yet?

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: Not he.

SP.SPEAKER: Ol. B.
SP.P: Not a bit nor a soope? dos hee doe nothing by example? or has your Lordship left it? or dos he carry it like a Gentleman?

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: Discreetly and Virgin-like.

SP.SPEAKER: Ol. B.
SP.P: Pretty commendation for a young Courtier.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: I would for my deserved love to him have put him upon a faire young Widow of a great fortune, but could not make him looke upon her like a suitor.

SP.SPEAKER: Ol. B.
SP.P: Just such a bashfull puppy was my brother, his Father; I wonder how my Mother came by him; My Fa∣ther was right, and she was right, and I have beene right, but what doe I speake on't?

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: True Bellamy, speake of somewhat else.

SP.SPEAKER: Ol. B.
SP.P: The Boy will nere grow up to me, I thought to have left him somewhat, I must discard him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: If you do, he is in me provided for.

SP.SPEAKER: Ol. B.
SP.P: What can your Lordship love him for?

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: Come i'le tell thee, and be comforted. Hee has something of thee in him. Hee will pimpe most conve∣niently.

SP.SPEAKER: Ol. B.
SP.P: That's something indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: And for his modesty which is a rare benefit of na∣ture in him, I dare trust him with a Mistrisse, as I would an Eunuch.

SP.SPEAKER: Ol. B.
SP.P: Benefit! A defect I feare, yet I may hope in time some Mistris of your Lordships may tempt, and bring him forwards.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: No I am confident—Now your news.

DIV3.P: Good Bellamy walke in the Gallery a while.

SP.SPEAKER: Ol. B.
SP.P: Some Mistris is comming to him, but what doe I speake on't?

LG.L: Goe bid her come in. Exit. Page.
What brings her so unseasonably?

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Stay you at distance yet a while Friend, till I call you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.P: Faces about Tom Saleware.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: How now! How is it with my love? Ha! How comes a trouble on this Face, where my delights are ever wont to Revell?

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: O my Lord—

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: Say who has injur'd thee? Has thy husband taken up the uncivill boldnesse to abuse thee? or be it any other man, it shall be death, or an undoing to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: My Lord, I am wrong'd, but would be loth to ingage your noble person in my quarrell, some servant of yours may do it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: Of what condition is thy wrong? tell mee; and who of my Servants thou wouldst have to right thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: I would have Bellamy, how thinke you? is hee faith∣full to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: How canst thou question it? Has hee not ever been so?

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Your Lordship has well trusted him I know.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: I doe not know the man, I trust, or love so well.

SP.SPEAKER: Al:
SP.P: But would your Lordship part with any Jewell, or choyce thing you love, and have intended onely for your own particular use, to him, or let him be your own partner in it?

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: Troth I thinke I should; onely thy selfe excepted, but what's thy wrong I prithee, or wherein should Bella∣my right thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Bellamy has wrong'd mee to thinke me so unwor∣thy as to be tempted to his lust; Bellamy has wrong'd your honour in that ambitious attempt.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: Thou amazest me.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: And Bellamy must right me, and your honour; or you must cast off him or me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: Give mee at least some circumstance to make this probable.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Must not▪ I be believ'd? you shall have instance then to make it truth, Friend Thomas.
Pray verifie unto my Lord the discovery you made last night of me, and Mr. Bellamy.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.P: 'Twas thus my Lord an't like your Lordship, my wife was forth at evening ant like your Lordship, as shee may have often beene ant like your Lordship, and may be as oft agen ant like your Lordship.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: Well pray thee on.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.P: Forth shee was ant like your Lordship, I staid supper, and almost bed time for her ant like your Lord∣ship; And had even given her over for all night ant like your Lordship, as I may of any night ant like your Lordship.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: O I pray thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Sal.
SP.P: Yes ant like your Lordship upon some private notice given to me an't like your Lordship, that she was at a private lodging ant like your Lordship, with a pri∣vate friend ant like your Lordship, over I went, and found her abed ant like your Lordship, and Mr. Bellamy even ready to go to bed to her ant like your Lordship.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: Is this true?

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: As true as your Lordship lives ant like your Lordship.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: How could you be betrayd so?

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P:
The Villaine fetch'd mee forth, and lodg'd mee there as by your appointment, and for your own plea∣sure; but when 'twas late, and that your Lordship came not, thinking hee had an advantageous opportunity, hee soone discovers his love to me, and his treachery to your Lordship; I being in a strait onelyAside. (finding happy meanes to send for my husband
to prevent him) made him a false promise being secure in my husband; and what had follow'd your Lordship understands.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: I'le nere trust man can blush and weepe agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: Insooth ant like your Lordship I thought all had been but waggery ant like your Lordship, to tempt mee unto jealousy, and my wife knowing well enough that I was by, bade Sweet Bellamy come to Bed, O Wag!

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: What messenger brought you the notice Mr. Sale∣ware?

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: A waterman my Lord, and like your Lordship, here's the letter, and like your Lordship.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: You told me you had lost it, when I ask'd ort to burne it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: I thought I had Friend, but I found it now, and given it my Lord before I was aware Friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Hell take that Letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: Now abotts on't for mee, if thou beest angry Friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: You had better ha swallow'd it full of Ratsbane.

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: Nere the sooner for a hasty word I hope Friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: Mr. Saleware, if you will avoyd a new addition of hornes, come with this bearer over into Montagues close, where you shall finde your Wife with a private Friend, at a private lodging; Hast thither, and aske for one Bellamy.
What Ridles this? This is Bellamies owne hand, I know it, why should hee send to prevent himselfe? or how could shee write his Character? This Woman is not right.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Doe you note my art my Lord, to write as in a Mans Name, when I wrought it my self?

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: And did not I tell you Friend, it should ha' been Anonima? Sapientia mea mihi.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: Within there call Bellamy.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.P: Hee's not within my Lord, and has not beene to night.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: His absence is another circumstance to a probabi∣lity my Lord.
But hee was seene this morning to goe in at Sir Anthony Thrivewels.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: Goe let my Coach be ready presently.

DIV3.P: He should receive 500 l. there for me, I trust he will not urnish himselfe with it for a flight.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: My Lord I gave you an inkling of a familiarity be∣twixt him and the Lady Thrivewell, he has since declar'd their act of lust to me, and urg'd it for an instance to my yeilding.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: Can you affirme this?

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Yes, to his face and hers.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: O Mr. Saveall! welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.P: My Lord your servant Bellamy is receaving your money at Sir Anthony Thrivewells.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: I thanke you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: But my Lord, there is fallen an unhappy accident betweene Sir Anthony, his Lady and his Nephew, in which your servant Bellamy also is concern'd; And your Lord∣ship is much, and most humbly besought by the Lady to heare, and examine the difference.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: I was preparing thither. Oh Mr. Bellamy, you have not eavesdropt, have you?

SP.SPEAKER: Old Bel.
SP.P: Will you pardon me my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: Yes if thou hast.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Bel.
SP.P: I have my Lord, and am overjoyd to heare so well of my Nephew.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.P: You may heare more anon, come all along with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Bel.
SP.P: I may heare more anon, your Lordship tho' knowes not of what so well as I doe know.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Thrivewell, Carelesse, Lady, Pheb, Closet, Wat.

SP.SPEAKER: Thr.
SP.P: I Need not cast thee off, or bid thee goe Now, and for ever from me, thine own shame Will force thee hence.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: You are deceiv'd in that.

LG.L: What is thine own take with thee, here 'tis all Phebe.
Thou ever getst, or canst expect from me.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Shee was mine own before your wife became our coupler, in English plaine our Bawd.

SP.SPEAKER: Thr.
SP.P: Use no uncivill Language while you are well.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: For which you have your witnesses, this false Traytor, that brought you on.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: By my direction George.

SP.SPEAKER: Wat.
SP.P: No Traytor neither fince you left to be my Master, wounded and turnd me off.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: And this darke Lanthorne here, this old deceptio visus, That juggled the wrong party into my Bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Doe you grin Grim Malkin? But sweete Ma∣dam, if your fine Springall Bellamy had lien there in my stead she would ha brought the right party; your Ladi∣ships Lilly white selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Thr.
SP.P: How's that?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: No more o' that good George.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Nay, it shall out, since you have wrought my ruine, I will be the destruction of you all; And there∣fore now heare mee O Knight, and first resolve to make me rich in my reward, for wonders i'le unfold.

SP.SPEAKER: Thr.
SP.P: Canst thou expect reward from mee for any thing that can by thee be utterd?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Reward? why not? why should not you reward my good Offices as well as punish my ill? I must and will rely upon you for all the good that can befall mee; or if I must expect no further from you, i'le give't you gratis, And if you be any thing but a Wittall heare mee.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: What doe you meane?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: To set you out livelyer, then all your paintings: or dee heare, will you give mee a hundred pound a quarter for my silence?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Not a penny; if you seeke my undoing, heaven forgive you.

SP.SPEAKER: Thr.
SP.P: What (Villaine) canst thou speake to her pre∣judice?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: That which (if you are no Wittall) you'l be leath to hear, but you shall have it.

SP.SPEAKER: Thr.
SP.P: Darst thou talke so?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: And since you hold my attempt at her, so hay∣nous, you may be pleas'd to know I was incited to't by example of him I nam'd, that smooth Fac'd Bellamy.

SP.SPEAKER: Thr.
SP.P: Darst thou accuse her with him?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: You may aske her bolster there, her Madam Nurse old Mother Cock broth.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: O me.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P:
I, O you aske her sir, what shee did with him, or he with her, in their two houres privacy in her chamber,
when hee came to take up five hundred pound for his Lord, There was a sweet taking up, sir shee confessed all to me, and on purpose, I dare be sworn to embolden mee in my attempt to her Ladyship.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: I confesse?

SP.SPEAKER: Thr.
SP.P: What did shee confesse?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: That hee made use of your Bed with your wife, what language shall I utter't in? you were best fee it done before you believe it.

SP.SPEAKER: Thr.
SP.P: O me most miserable if this be true!

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Well, there's for them two.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Goe Closet till I call you.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Now for that Rogue (because I must expect no further good of you, but this which is mine owne you say) i'le lay him open to you, you remember how once I ingratiated my selfe to you by rescuing you from a Robbery and Murder (as you suppos'd) for which you took me into favour—

SP.SPEAKER: Thr.
SP.P: Yes, and have wish'd a thousand times since, that I had lost the thousand pound I had about me then, and tane some wounds for't in exchange rather then by that rescue to have taken thy Viperous selfe into my bo∣some.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: This Rogue plotted that businesse, 'twas a mere trick of his invention. The supposed Theeves were his companions, and wrought by him only to scare you and run away when wee came to your succour, onely to in∣deare mee to you. There was no hurt meant, but the slap I gave him over the Pate to colour the businesse, with little blood, I wish now I had cleft his braines.

SP.SPEAKER: Thr.
SP.P: Your wish tho' against your will is a good re∣ward to him, for I love him the better for his wit in that plot, and care of his then Master.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Doe you so sir? Then 'twas mine own invention, let him deny't if he can.

SP.SPEAKER: Wat.
SP.P: Indeed the plot was his sir, I onely found the Actors.

SP.SPEAKER: Thr.
SP.P: I cannot condemne the conceipt however; and am something taken with the wit on't, would all the rest were no worse.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: And now I have utterd my whole mind sir, and you declard I must expect no further good of you, come away Phib, I have injur'd thee long, i'le make the now amends for all; i'le marry thee, and sell Tobacco with thee.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Let him not go sir, I beseech you in this desperate way, nor till I answer to his accusation.

SP.SPEAKER: Thr.
SP.P: Sir you shall stay, and make your selfe good be∣fore authority, or cleare my wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: You'l have your house then known to have beene a bawdy-house?

SP.SPEAKER: Thr.
SP.P: The Courts of Princes and Religious Houses May so have been abus'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Under such Governesses.

SP.SPEAKER: Thr.
SP.P: You'l anon be silent, what's the matter? wee are busy.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P: Mistris Crostill, Madam is come in great hast to visit you, and a Kinseman of your Ladiships with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Thr.
SP.P: At such a time? excuse your selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P: They are here sir, enterd against all resistance.

LG.L: Mistris Crostill! you have much honord me—
Cozen Fitzgerrard! welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Fit.
SP.P: I have a private sute to you Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: Pray Mr. Thrivewell entertaine the Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Another sprunt youth.

LG.L: Sir, I perceave some discontent here, I hope your▪
Nephew has not againe displeas'd you?

SP.SPEAKER: Thr.
SP.P: He is a villaine, seekes my utter ruine,

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Pray say not so, for feare you force mee love him.

SP.SPEAKER: Thr.
SP.P: You are undone for ever if you doe.

LG.L: Doe not say so, for feare I fly to him,
The thought of him already breakes my sleeps,
I could not rest to night for thinking of him,
Which made my early hast to unload my minde,
Presuming that your judgement may excuse
A simple Womans weaknesse, what is shee
That hee courts so?

SP.SPEAKER: Thr.
SP.P: I tell you, shee's a Whore with Child by him, layes claime to him, and I think hee'l marry her.

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Still you speake better of him, and my love must not see him so lost, sir let me speake with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Me Lady? I am busy; I am busy.

LG.L: What mettall am I of? his scorne's a Load-stone;
No Courtship like his carelesnesse to mee;
And all dispraise speakes for him,
Sir I will speake with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: I blush for you, what would you say now, were it not too late?

SP.SPEAKER: Cros.
SP.P: Nay onely to your eare.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Stand off a while Phib.
