As you can carry, i'le along w'ye too.
Stay not to think, or thank me for my wit.

SP.SPEAKER: Fla.
SP.P: What shall we say?

SP.SPEAKER: Ast.
SP.P: Do as you are bidden, and say nothing.

LG.L: Lovers shall saint thee; and this day shall be
For ever callenderd to Love and thee.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter a Zaffie, taking up the Cabinet, to him Nicolo in a Zaffies habit.

SP.SPEAKER: Gua.
SP.P: Nanulo! The Key to let me forth.

SP.SPEAKER: Zaff.
SP.P: St. Marke and fortune make it a good prize.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: Hands off Sir, that's not yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Zaff.
SP.P: Nor yours I am sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: Halfe part then brother Zaffi.

SP.SPEAKER: Gua.
SP.P: The Key I saw.

SP.SPEAKER: Zaff.
SP.P: Sir you are none oth' Zaffi.

SP.SPEAKER: Gua
SP.P: Villaine slave! come open the dore.

SP.SPEAKER: Zaff.
SP.P: How came you by this habit?

LG.L: Perhaps to trie sit how it will become me
When I have a minde to be as very a Knave
ffice as your selfe, But shall we slp
, and share, before the dog that owes it
e the bone from us both?

SP.SPEAKER: Gua.
SP.P: I feare you can be quicker in my absence.

SP.SPEAKER: Nan
SP.P: The fault was in your hast sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Gua.
SP.P: Took you not up a Cabinet, friends?

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: Zaff Nt we sir, we saw none.

SP.SPEAKER: Gua.
SP.P: O you watch well above there.

SP.SPEAKER: Nan.
SP.P: This fellow has it under his coat sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Zaff
SP.P: But who shall know't for yours sir?

LG.L: May we be bold to aske what marks it has,
Or what's within it?
I'le have you ear-mark'd Villaines for your theft,
Know you not me?
I cry your worship mercy, and am glad
I was your instrument to preserve this treasure
From this false counterfet.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: Fortune has sent my master to relieve me.

LG.L: Signior Guadagni our Councell have thought fit,
For better confirmation of our act,
That it be past here in your Daughters presence
Together with my Son, whom I have sent for,
Why doe you seeme thus mov'd?
An accident hath crost me. Look you sir,
You have authority; Here's a Counterfet
(Deserves examination) would have rob'd me.
I sav'd you sir from being rob'd. Heare me aside
Sir—Nicolo whispers Pant.

SP.SPEAKER: Gua.
SP.P: Carry this in; and send away the woman

DIV3.STAGE: He gives the Cabinet to Nan. who knocks at dore.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: Now do you know me I have done the feat.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: Hast treated with the Hangman Nicolo?

LG.L: The Carnifex is fitted for your service,
In a most gorgeous habt of a Dutchman,
And about five i'th' evening will be with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Nan.
SP.P: Astutta! Madona Flavia! Astutta!

SP.SPEAKER: Gua.
SP.P: What's the matter there?

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: The best jest, ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Nan
SP.P: You'l open the dore?

SP.SPEAKER: Gua
SP.P: What's that?

LG.L: It will be mirth to morrow at our feast
To laugh our bellies full.
I am sure you heare me
Foole me, but not my master: he is here.

SP.SPEAKER: Gua.
SP.P: Why stay you there sirrah?

LG.L: I let him go: a merry harmelesse fellow
I'le answer for him. Hence, away, and shit you.
And quickly send my Son.

SP.SPEAKER: Nan.
SP.P: The dore is fast sir, and they will not heare mee.

LG.L: I feare I am undone. Flavia, Astutta, ko!
Ts so, tis so, some Robbers are slipt in,
And now make havoc of my goods and Daughter.
It is no dallying Run and fetch a Smith Ex. Nan.
To force the Lock.
Astutta, Flavia! O this cursed chance
I feare will ruine me and all my hopes. Enter Pedler woman.
How came you hither?
Sir by good appointment
To bring Bride-laces, Gloves, and curious Dressings
To deck your Daughter on her Brideale-day,
To morrow as I weene, holds it I pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Gua.
SP.P: Were you not here before, and in the house?

LG.L: If you could put it off sir one day longer
I could so fit her with new fashiond tires
That shee should thanke me.

SP.SPEAKER: Gua:
SP.P: I fear a new, and further secret mischief.

LG.L: Hence let me fall to earth; I may not see
My Masters fury rise out of his ruine.

SP.SPEAKER: Gua.
SP.P: How gotst thou thither?

LG.L: By the back-dore which I found widely open.
O sir your Daughter—

SP.SPEAKER: Gua.
SP.P: Ravish'd or murderd is shee?

LG.L: Worse, worse, by far sir, shee is conveyd hence
The Neighbours from the windowes o're the way
Saw her, the Mayd, and a young Man take boat.
They guesse it was Francisco.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: How, how, how!

LG.L: Loaden with Caskets sir. Here's his Deceptio visus,
The ed clak, that charm'd my honest care; N▪ show▪
And here's his jugling Bo. What toyes are these!

SP.SPEAKER: Gua.
SP.P: O me accursed wretch.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: O sir, your Sonne!

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: Where is he? speake.

LG.L: Sir, no where to be found
In private let me tell you, he slipt forth
At foure i'th' Morning; sir, when you and I
Were you know where. He cast forth doubtfull words
Of a vagary he would fetch at Rome.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: We both are wrought upon by hellish Magick.

SP.SPEAKER: Gua.
SP.P: Devills are in this plot.

SP.SPEAKER: Chec Pros.
SP.P: Thinke you of Devills?

LG.L: Though you sirs, being Lawyers, think there's none
VVe may both thinke there are, and fear 'em.
Forbear such talke; and think upon the irth,
The jest you have in hand against to morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: Sir, use your jerks and quillets at the bar.

SP.SPEAKER: Gua.
SP.P: Cast there your petulant wit on misery.

LG.L: Sir, you mistake, my counsell is to comfort,
Be not dejected, but seeke speedy way
To circumvent the wit has wrought upon you.

SP.SPEAKER: Gua.
SP.P: Good sir, your best advise.

LG.L: First charge this officer
Here, with this woman; who by'examination
May make discovery—
I can discover nothing but my ware sir,
Nor part with that for lesse then ready money.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: Take her to custody.

SP.SPEAKER: Zaff.
SP.P: Mistris come with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: VVhither? for what?

SP.SPEAKER: Zaff.
SP.P: You shall know that hereafter.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: VVhat can I discover?

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: Away with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: VVhat can I discover?

LG.L: Into your house sir now, and secure that;
Come, recollect your selfes, call home the strength
Of your approved judgements, wee'l assist you.
You must be soddaine too in this your pursuit;
Advise and do at once, use no delay;
The speediest course is now the safest way.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.
DIV3.STAGE: Fabritio like the glorious Dutchman, Horatio▪ Piso.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: FOund you the Fort, then, so impregnable?

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: Against all force of armes, or braines.

LG.L: No way but by the down-right composition
Of the two thousand Duccats to be enter'd.
Sure tis some noble wench then you imagine,
But my disguise shall put her to the test.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: I'm sure she jeerd me out of my Monsieurship.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Did she, and all thy fine french qualities?

LG.L: And is as like to make a skitter brooke
Of you in your Dutch slops. For if she be not,
After all this, a cunning whore, i'me couzen'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: Shee lives at a good rate how ere maintaind.

LG.L: The secret way, man, by her commings in
Too common among women for their livings,
I'le not believe her wit and feature are
Allyed to honesty.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Thou art no worshipper of faire women Piso.

LG.L: No, If I worship any of 'hem more
Then in the Knee-trick, that is necessary
In their true use let me be unuchiz'd.
Looke here's your fathers Pimpe againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: Now Nicolo?

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: Sw you my young Master Gentlemen?

LG.L: Yes there he stands, translted out of sober
Italian into high Dutch.
I sweare he was past my reading,
Slight, he appeares as like the noted Almaine
Late come to town, if he had but his beard—

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: How like you this for a beard?

LG.L: Most excellent!
But pray take heed your stay spoyle not the purpose
Of your disguise.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Why what news Nicolo?

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: Your Father is in busy quest of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Then he dos misse me?

LG.L: Pray Phaebus he misse as much of Madnesse,
He and his vertuous brother old Guadagni,
Who misses too his Daughter. Francisco has her.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: Has he got her off?

LG.L: And shee has got him on by this time: they
Are silly fooles else.

SP.SPEAKER: Pi.
SP.P: Hymen be their speed.

SP.SPEAKER: Nor.
SP.P: But how I pray thee scap'd they?

LG.L: First, sir, know
There's a strange fellow without desires to speake w'yee
I guesse hee is some Bravo.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: A Bravo speake with me?

LG.L: Yes, and inquires here for my Master too,
And Signior Piso, you are all known it seemes.

SP.SPEAKER: Pi.
SP.P: Come leave your fooling.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: By mine Eares tis true.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: Goe call him in, I feare no Knavery.

SP.SPEAKER: Pi.
SP.P: Your lodging protects me.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: My disguise me.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: This is the Gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Pi.
SP.P: Tis the proud Braes whiske!

LG.L: I cry you mercy si, are you Signior Horatio?
I tooke you sir this morning for a Monsieur.
I thanke you for my Duccatoun.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: What! Is shee come about? Has shee sent for mee?

LG.L: Good sir! are you here too? I thank you sir,
You payd me your entrance, but no paing fo.
Prithee deserve no being ill thou hast done
Thy errand. What dost come for?
Sir, to intreat this Gentleman to bring
With him one Signior is, and Fbritio—
Beyond my hopes! Good ir, are you here too?
This is a Devill! could he know me else
That nere saw him before; in this disguise?
Cry mercy ir: you would not these should know
Nor shall they (I feare it not) but hk you sir.
What Familiare these awd are. They'l talke yet
Thus to Lords in private.
Sure he takes him for the Dutch loggerhead
We saw to day in the Piazz.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: So would any man: Hee has hit his shape so right.

LG.L: I am sure I rejoyce in these Dollors, that you
Give me to day, and are as ine, that
My Mistris wish'd a better dinner for you
For frighting of the Spaniard with your fireworks.
But, by your strangers it seemes you repent
The Marriage offer that you made my Mistres.
Fortune direct you to no worse a wife,
And so I leave you to your choyce.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: I have found the error, and will make good use 't.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: Your businesse then is to that strangers sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Pau.
SP.P: Only your selfe, and briefly from Francisco.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: Francisco! where?

LG.L: Where but at our house sir? he and his Bride
Craving your company and those Gentlemen
I nam'd unto you.
For no disparagement unto their worths, sir,
But private reasons yet unknown to me
Wherein you shall be satisfied at your comming,

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: But are they Married?

LG.L: I brought the Priest to 'em:
And saw them lawfully coupled, and before
Sufficient witnesses, that saw 'em chamberd,
Shee was his own Church-sure before I left 'm,
And he has made her Cock-sure, sir by this time,
Or else he is a Bungler.
Goe i'le follow thee.
Piso is here.

SP.SPEAKER: Pau.
SP.P: But where is that Fabritio?

LG.L: Wee'l finde him too. Jg you sir on before:
You are no street companion for us.

SP.SPEAKER: Pau.
SP.P: I am gone sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: You have heard all Fabritio; what d thinke on't?

LG.L: Nothing; nor nothing will till I arrive
There at the full knowledge of all together.
But prithe hang thy Hagman project now,
And beare us company in thine own shape.
Not for the price of the Novella Piso.
I'le try her to the quick. You'l give me leave
To make prize of her if I can, I crost not you.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: We wish you safe aboard sir.

LG.L: On before then. Exit Hor. Piso.
Now Nicolo; your disguise againe oth Zaffi.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: O, it is ready; and I know my quue.

LG.L: Who see me, in this straine, seeme to outstrip
The bounds of filiall duty, let (withall)
Their observation, by my just ends, gather,
Tis not to lose, but to recall a father.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.

LG.L: NOw Lady, has your entertainment pleas'd you
In the Novella's house? is all well yet?
So well, that now come Father Friends, and all
The friendly Foes that did oppose my blisse
I can maintaine my cause in these safe armes
'Gainst all their Frownes and Furies.
And your Mistris is over, too▪ I hope sir
The place is not so dangerous as it was.
Lady your noblenesse shown in this great bounty,
Hath not alone wip'd off my foule suspition:
But scor'd upon my breast an endlesse summe
Of thanks; which I, unable to discharge,
Must not presume to live, but as your Creature;
Nor will I further dare to tempt your goodnesse
In deeper search of what your reason was
(Past all my hopes and wishes) to provide
For me; I will not sum in such a scruple▪
For sure, I hold you for a power Divine
(Past all the fictions of the fabulous times
Fashioning out the Gods in earthly formes)
Sent by the highest providence to helpe me.
You take too deepe a sense of curtesie!
But see, are these your friends?

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Paulo, with Horatio, and Piso.

LG.L: And let me beg
Your suffrage Lady, I may bid them welcome.
Your Bride and I will both supply you in it.
Neither of these is he they call Fabritio?

SP.SPEAKER: Pau.
SP.P: No, but hee's sent for; and comes instantly.

SP.SPEAKER: Fra.
SP.P: This is the Lady I am bound to serve.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: And I to honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Vic.
SP.P: Setting aside your suit sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: I cannot promise that.

LG.L: And I doe wish
I had her double price in ready Duccats,
For what she has done, and tother doe besides.

SP.SPEAKER: Vic.
SP.P: You still stand in your good conceit of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Pi.
SP.P: Yes, and I would so stand to', ha—

SP.SPEAKER: Vic.
SP.P: You are a merry Gentleman.

LG.L: I will not whisper it, Horatio,
The woman that I dealt with for disguise
Was wrought before by this most matchlesse Lady
To crosse the Match twixt Flavia and Fabritio;
And had undone it though I had done nothing,
And ere she would condition with me,
Oblig'd me, by an oath, (in case we scap'd)
To bring her hither to this Ladies house.
I kept that oath, and here you find us welcom'd.
Then thou hast done't, would I had still the Duccats
To pledge thee here.

SP.SPEAKER: Vic.
SP.P: Wee'l talke of that hereafter.

SP.SPEAKER: Pi.
SP.P: What acted you, Tit, in this Comedy?

LG.L: The Chambermayde, a kind of putter forwards,
Sir, to the businesse.
Shee has done so well,
That, if a Match in Venice may be found
By my best care, i'le helpe her to a Husband,
For shee deserves a good one.
And if he prove not so, I am like to prove
A good one my selfe, and make him something.
Thou wilt, I find it in a villanous cast
Of that eye there.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: And what thinke you of this?

LG.L: Even such another, of another hue,
Shee has a devilish gloat too.
Gallants, I find you merry, y'are more welcome:
My man acquaints me with a present businesse
Requiring privacy. Please you, with your friends
Goe up to the Bride-chamber. There is musick.
Waite you respectively.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: Wee'l all observe you Lady.

LG.L: But Lady, if you receive the Duccats
Before you come to us, pray bring our shares,
Wee all connive you know.
Pray be not jealous,
Follow your Friends, i'le follow you streight way. Ex. Pi.
How dreames he of this money? he knows nothing,
An English Factor, say you Borgio?

SP.SPEAKER: Pau.
SP.P: Yes Mistris, a brave fellow.

LG.L: And is he so well money'd as to spare
Out of his Masters trust, so great a summe?
Oh hee's a master here himselfe. They are
Abroad, the royalist Nation of the World.
What rich Venetian Rarity has not
The English Money-masters purchac'd from
Princes and States, to beare home as their triumphs?
And for their pleasures—but i'le say no more;
Hee thinks I stay too long for him to wait
Without, with so much money.

SP.SPEAKER: Vic.
SP.P: Didst thou see'?

LG.L: Most brightly shining! Hee's now telling it
In the next roome! He comes not to tender
The value of it in fine qualities
Like your suppos'd Monsieur: but in cash!
Cash! cash of Gold! Oh tis a tempting sight;
Able to damne a Noble womans honour.
What's your descent? But poore I make no question;
Why, this will set you up and make you noble.
This way of his might serve to turn the blood
That has but any tincture of good in it
From touching such a bait, yet he thinks now
He spurres me to it. But Bravo I will fit you.
Goe call him in, goe.
Now my Blood and Braine,
Be strong and sodaine, stay.

SP.SPEAKER: Vic.
SP.P: Why stop you Borgio?

LG.L: To see him weigh his gold. Oh dainty sight!
He brought his weights in's pocket: just Gentleman
He will be sure you shall not want a graine
Of your full price of sweet damnation.

SP.SPEAKER: Vic.
SP.P: Hee's doing no such thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Pau.
SP.P: No, no, I have it now.

LG.L: I pray thee goe, thou knowst not how the thought
Of so much gold, and the conceit o'th' Maydenhead
Lost i' the house to day sets my virginity
On edge now to be going.

SP.SPEAKER: Pau.
SP.P: Are you so ready? then I fly.

SP.SPEAKER: Vic.
SP.P: What ayles the fellow troe!

LG.L: I must yet have an eye upon this female
To quit my jealousy, or catch her i'th' nick.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: Here we may see, and heare all undiscover'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Pi.
SP.P: Watch close, he comes.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Swatzenburg, like a Marchant with a full Bagge.

LG.L: By your leave Lady, I come not a pure Sutor
(VVith studyed Oratory; nor addresse a Sonnet,
Or trifling Love-toyes to perswade admittance
By slow degrees into your inmost favour)
But a rich purchacer, that brings, at once,
The golden Summe, and Price of your enjoying.
Here precious Beauty, made by this more precious!
Take your full due, and render readily
The full tuition of my wealthy purchace.

SP.SPEAKER: Vic.
SP.P: Now vertue guard me.

SP.SPEAKER: Pi.
SP.P: VVhat's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: Shee invokes vertue.

LG.L: Ha! why this delay?
Let not the glorious sight of this amaze you,
Though it be granted, sodaine apprehension
Of such bright blessings may transport a soule
Into high raptures, when it is considerd,
The Ornament of youth, the strength of age,
Lifes great maintainer, Lady, let not this
At all transmute you. For i'le bring supplies
That shall so frequently acquaint you with
Such sights as these, that you shall grow regardlesse
Even of the care to keepe them, in respect
Of the delicious pleasure brings them in:
Delay not therefore that high purchac'd pleasure,
That brings this to you, by a Minutes losse
To make it fully yours.
Sir I have heard you: Enter Paulo behinde with pistolls.
And now must let you know, tis not the sight
Of that your glorious summe can take my wonder;
Much lesse my love or person: my amazement
Is, that a man, that beares his Makers shape,
Indued with reason, to direct and governe
That goodly fortune; and has such treasure given him
(Besides his greater blessings of the mind
By well desposing of it) to advance
This worth in deeds of vertue, should descend
Below the sense of Beasts, to part with that,
Allotted for his livelyhood and honour
To wast it, and himselfe in beastiall Lust.

SP.SPEAKER: Swa.
SP.P: How's this?

LG.L: I know not what to make o'this wench.
Shee preaches me thinks:
Besides sir, were it well examin'd,
The golden summe you tender is, perhaps,
None of your proper own: I understand
You are anothers Factor, I presume
In all your Catalogue of Merchandise
You finde no warrant to buy Maydenheads.
Is such a thing in all your bills of Lading?
They are no way transportable▪ tho' you allow
For fraught and leakage halfe the worth; and lesse
Returnable by way of exchange. How can
You take up a virginity in Venice,
And make a London payment of it, on
Sight of your bill, or six or ten dayes after?

SP.SPEAKER: Pi.
SP.P: Good!

LG.L: Nay then you dally with me, and I must
Deale plaine and briefly with you. Here's the price,
And either render me my just demand,
Or I shall take for your disgrace an order
Shall spue you forth the City.
Now I feare
I am insnar'd. I have but one way left
To fly from shame, or fall to utter Ruine.

SP.SPEAKER: Pi.
SP.P: I begin to suspect her honest.

SP.SPEAKER: Swa.
SP.P: Your answer Gentlewoman.

LG.L: Gentle sir,
The Law hath made me yours. And I have now
No Court but Conscience to relieve me in.

SP.SPEAKER: Swa.
SP.P: What may this meane?

LG.L: If the strong passion of a Virgin soule,
Exprest in bitterst teares, move not your pitty,
This shall prevent your cruelty.

SP.SPEAKER: Pi.
SP.P: Shee'l prove honest o' my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Swa.
SP.P: What meane you Lady?

LG.L: Keepe at that distance sir, and you shall know:
Come nearer, and I will not live to tell you.
Pray rise and speak your story: yet I tell you,
I hold it very strange, that so much money
And such a one as I (none of th'unhandsomst)
Should not goe down with a young wench, and one
Of the profession you pretend to be of
Before cold Iron! Me thinks most unnaturall.
Thinke better yet before you utter further.

SP.SPEAKER: Vic.
SP.P: Indeed I may not.

SP.SPEAKER: Swa.
SP.P: Well, well, on then.

LG.L: Tis true, I am indeed a meere pretender
To the profession you suppos'd me of;
A spotlesse Virgin (by my utmost hopes)
And will remaine so till I am a Bride.

SP.SPEAKER: Pi.
SP.P: Too honest to be a woman!

SP.SPEAKER: Swa.
SP.P: Why tooke you this deceiving habit then?

LG.L: I am about to tell you for your pitty,
I am a Romane borne, of good discent;
My father noble (of the Candiani)
How ere decay'd in fortune, ere he dyed;
Which drew on my Misfortune: For, being betroth'd
Unto a wealthy heire, here, of this City,
Who so journ'd then in Rome, his covetous Father
Ravshd his faith from me, to give't another;
And calld him hastily from Rome to Venice.
I followd him, in hope to crosse the Match.
And so regaine him; towards which already,
I have done something.

SP.SPEAKER: Pi.
SP.P: Fabritio's wench my life on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Swa.
SP.P: VVhat in this habit, as a Curtezan?

LG.L: Not without good advise: For, by this meanes
I draw the eyes of all the youthfull Gentry,
Not without hope to gaine a sight of him.
My price and port keepe back inferiour persons.
Nor lose I honour by it: For the strictnes
Of our Italian censure gives a virgin,
That held familiarity with any Man,
By way of Marriage treaty, and then forsaken,
Lost in repute; shee is no honest woman
Untill that man doe vindicate her honor.

SP.SPEAKER: Swa.
SP.P: But should hee finde you here, what were his censure?

LG.L: Here he should find what his disloyalty
Had wrought me to; and should restore me firme
On my first basis, or exchange a life
For mine ere we would part.

SP.SPEAKER: Swa.
SP.P: This sounds yet well.

LG.L: I'le trust thee now. Thou art a noble wench,
Thou hadst kiss'd Death by this else. Now i'le trust thee.
If he were lost by Marriage of another,
I would remove with such a testimony
Of my reserved honour (in despight
Of this my outward carriage, for my ends;
Maugre the sterne construction of my countrey)
That strangers should receive me; and some one
More noble then himselfe—

SP.SPEAKER: Swa.
SP.P: Take you to wife?

SP.SPEAKER: Vic.
SP.P: I should not doubt.

SP.SPEAKER: Swa.
SP.P: Tis done, and I am he that does it.

LG.L: I cannot sir, but kindly take your offer:
But, if my first love faile me, there is one,
A noble German, that commenc'd his suit
To me this day.
I am he too Lady—Looke well upon me
That in this shift, reducing of my beard,
VVith this supply of money came to try you,
I finde you noble, and above it, honest.

SP.SPEAKER: Pi.
SP.P: This is the German that Fabritio apes.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: And he should come now.

LG.L: Gentlemen forbeare;
Indeed it is not civill in you to pry beyond
Your hospitable usage, pray forbeare.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: Tis timely chidden wench, we will obay thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P: Besides the Bridegroome, and the Bride ex∣pect you.

SP.SPEAKER: Pi.
SP.P: O ha they done we come, we come.

LG.L: This jealous tryall now of yours (how ere
You have exprest strong arguments of love)
Has not augmented you in my affection.

SP.SPEAKER: Swa.
SP.P: O say not so sweete Lady, i'le redeeme it.

LG.L: I cannot yet believe you are the Man,
You are so chang'd from what you seem'd to day,
Must the minde alter with the outward habit?

SP.SPEAKER: Pau.
SP.P: Mistris the German—

SP.SPEAKER: Vic.
SP.P: Here he is man, he sayes.

SP.SPEAKER: Pau.
SP.P: I say he is without, and craves to see you.

SP.SPEAKER: Vic.
SP.P: How can this be? or who can I believe?

LG.L: Good sir depart and make roome for your selfe
Your proper selfe to enter the Dutch Prince.
I tell thee I am he, and here already,
I am Swatzenberg.
Yes in your tother beard sir.
Hans Snortanfart, are you not? well I can but warn you,
If you will needs stand to the taking off
A mans good name from him before his face,
Then take what followes, I will fetch him in
Mistris, you were best be out of sight a while:
Your presence with this stranger may whet up his fury
To cut all our throats else.

SP.SPEAKER: Vic.
SP.P: I'le take your councell.

LG.L: For sir i'le tell you, if you had but seene
How he worried a Spaniard to day, you would
Have beene able at your returne to make
As many of your Countreymen, as thrive
By serving of the States to laugh ifaith.
I tell thee I am he; 'twas I that chac'd
The Spaniard hence.
I tell you yet againe
You were best be gone before the He indeed
Come in to chace you after him.

SP.SPEAKER: Swa.
SP.P: I'le stand the hazard.

SP.SPEAKER: Pau.
SP.P: See his impatience pulls him in already.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Fabritio in the Germans habit.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Where is this Lady? Dos her beauty flie me?

LG.L: Shee is at hand, but first here is a stranger,
A most strange stranger that sayes he is you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Swa.
SP.P: Was oder wer bistu? Bistu ein Deutscher? Sag mihr in was ort Du gelebst hast?

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Who's this?

SP.SPEAKER: Swa.
SP.P: Ich denke du bist ein heuchler; bistu aber ein Deut∣scher so anwort mihr in deutscher sprach.

LG.L: Good sir speake in the proper language of
The Nation we are in, though it come brokenly
From you that this good fellow here may understand us.
Thou son of impudence, and imposture, speake;
What is thy end in this?

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Thinke what thine owne must be, thou son of slander.

LG.L: Precious counterfeit!
But I am weaponlesse, and must fetch strength
Of officers to right me.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: What dos your shame remove you sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Pau.
SP.P: What can this Rascall meane?

LG.L: I care not honest fellow, where's thy Mistris?
Good Angells guard me.

SP.SPEAKER: Pau.
SP.P: Dos shee fright you sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: I aske thee for thy Mistris, the Novella.

SP.SPEAKER: Pau.
SP.P: What appeares shee to you?

LG.L: Thou powerfull man in Magick, I will tell thee.
Th'hast rays'd an apparition, that has damn'd thee
Blacker, then thy black art; nay hell it selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Pau.
SP.P: Blesse us! more madnesse yet!

LG.L: The heavenly spirit, that inspir'd this forme,
(When the unworthy world enjoyd her being,
VVhich thou hast conjur'd into this lewd habit)
Has, at this instant won the powers above
To sinke thee and thy forerers.
VVhat may you meane? Here is no forcery,
This woman's Flesh and Blood.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: I would not dare to try to be the Duke.

SP.SPEAKER: Pau.
SP.P: You may depart, pray hinder not the house.

LG.L: Hadst thou but seen, as I have, one like her,
And noted the divinity in her lookes
(Although in those adulterate incitements
Shee seemes to wear) she would have struck thy soule
VVith fervent adoration, not base lust.

SP.SPEAKER: Pau.
SP.P: I know not what to say to 'him.

LG.L: See who rings. Exit Paulo.
VVhat divine creature, sir, was that you mention'd?
I dare to name her to thee, though thou be
Her incens'd Ghost, to worke me to despaire,
It was Victoria.

SP.SPEAKER: Vic.
SP.P: This sounds most strangely! Have you beene at Rome sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: 'Twas there I saw and lov'd her.

LG.L: Answer me pray sir, why could not this fall
In your discourse to day, when I relted
My Life and Fortune to you? why do you start?
I am no shadow; but suspect you rather,
To be not as you seeme, the noble German
That vowd me love, dos that too startle you?
See sir, to prove I am no aery spirit,
I'le trust your hand (if you be mortall substance)
VVith so much flesh and blood as may resolve you.
I find tis she, and having found her thus
Shee's lost for ever, and my selfe no lsse,
That was the cause of this her desperate fortune.
VVhat's that you say? what aile you sir? how ist?
And what moves thy destraction? Borgio, speak.
Horror and shame invades us, all the house
Is round beset with officers. The Magistrates,
Are entring now, for what, or whom they search
I cannot guesse, unlesse this be some Murderer
Slipt in, to draw our lives in question.

SP.SPEAKER: Vic.
SP.P: Deale plainly sir, what are you? hee's stupified!

LG.L: The Spanyard's with 'hem too that took th'affront
By the supposed Dutchman here to day;
And he that fain'd himselfe to be that Dutchman
Desires their aid against this unknown person.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Pantaloni, Pedro, Guadagni, Swatz. Prospero, Checquino, Zaffi, Pedler-woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Gua.
SP.P: This is the house you say.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: And this is the Gentlewoman.

SP.SPEAKER: Gua.
SP.P: Give me my Daughter, Harlot.

LG.L: Here's no such creature, here sir, if she be
Your Daughter, this woman directed hither,
Shee is no Harlot, but an honest Bride;
Lawfully wed and bedded; as may appeare
By the strong testimony of divers friends:
Call them all downe.
Unheard-of impudence! Are Bawdes, and VVhores
Fit Matchmakers for Magnificoe's Daughters?
Speake lower, or at home sir, you know not
VVhat we are: Harke you sir—your last nights triall
Did not enough informe you.
VVe shall know more anon;
I'th' meane time what are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: A stranger sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Pant.
SP.P: VVe shall know more of that anon too.

LG.L: This is the stranger, that affronted me;
'Gainst whom I crave your Justice.

SP.SPEAKER: Pant.
SP.P: You shall know more anon too.

SP.SPEAKER: Swat.
SP.P: And this is my Abuser.

SP.SPEAKER: Pant.
SP.P: You also shall know more anon.

SP.SPEAKER: Gua.
SP.P: You are well met Gentle-woman—I gave you lost.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Paulo, Francisco, Piso, Horat, Flavia, Astutta, Jacconetta.

LG.L: VVhat will you whimper now? will not marriage
Make you bold, that makes so many impudent?
Shee was not lost sir; nor in danger of losing,
Shee was but mislayd a little, as your VVriting was to day.

SP.SPEAKER: Pi.
SP.P: VVell said my chattring Magpy. I will side thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Gua.
SP.P: Audacious strumpet that seduces my Daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Pi.
SP.P: You are Mistaken, shee did but wait upon her.

SP.SPEAKER: Ast.
SP.P: Right sir, and did but duty i'le be sworne.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Nor I, I will be sworne.

SP.SPEAKER: Gua.
SP.P: Not, in consenting to the stealth?

LG.L: It was my duty sir for the reward,
VVee all would live you know.

SP.SPEAKER: Gua.
SP.P: VVill you be gone?

LG.L: I hope I am discharg'd: for looke you sir,
I brought you where you finde your Daughter safe.

SP.SPEAKER: Gua.
SP.P: Begone I say.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: No whit the worse for wearing, as they say.

SP.SPEAKER: Gua.
SP.P: Goe thrust her out of dores.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: At my owne liberty I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Gua.
SP.P: How thou wilt to be rid of thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: May you see your Childrens, Childrens, Childrens, Children.

SP.SPEAKER: Pant.
SP.P: And thou misledst my Sonne, I aske him of thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Pi.
SP.P: You shall know more of that anon sir.

LG.L: Out-brav'd and scornd by Strumpets, Bawds, and Bravoes!
Call in the Officers.
And call the common Hangman if you please,
And end all 'mong your selfes, if your grave wisdomes,
And Lawyers, here, can find one guilty person
VVee'l all submit our necks to you.

DIV3.STAGE: Horatia and Francisco, &c. talke aside with Fabritio and Victoria.

SP.SPEAKER: Gua.
SP.P: Tis boldly spoken.

LG.L: I will speake but truth.
And you, opposing it, shall wrong the dignity
You beare i'th' City, to your utter shames.
This Gentleman and your Daughter were contracted,
Your selfe a willing witnesse; your Son likewise
Unto a noble virgin (Sir of whom
You shall know more anon)
It pleas'd diviner providence to take
From eithers chosen mate their earthly fortunes;
Yet each had person, blood, and vertue left
Above the value of a Princes dowry.
VVould you so Kick at heaven then, in despight
Of its great Ordinance, as to force your children,
To forfeit both their faiths, thereby to lose
The never-fayling hope of future blessings,
To pull withall a curse on your own heads,
That could no lesse then ruine your estates,
And render you most wretched in your dotage,
Past helpe or hope how to relieve your selfes:
Your consciences still groaning underneath
The lashes that your Childrens bastard issue
Should lay upon you? more, you may consider—
We doe consider sir, this place and people
No fit receipt for warrantable businesse.
This was no bawdy talke sir, nor have I
Heard worse from any mouth in this free place
Till your arrivall here.

SP.SPEAKER: Vic.
SP.P: I cannot be so happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Let her see your face.

SP.SPEAKER: Vic.
SP.P: O my Fabritio—

LG.L: You see the worst of us, I should be loath
Any unwarrantable act should passe among us.

SP.SPEAKER: Gua.
SP.P: Thou lookst like one indeed of upright Con∣science!

LG.L: And for the Marriage sir, it is as lawfull
As if your selfe had given her in St. Marks.
I'le fetch the Priest t'avouch it.

SP.SPEAKER: Gua.
SP.P: Fetch that Priest.

DIV3.STAGE: Paulo joynes in conference with Victoria and Fabritio.

LG.L: But i'le be so reveng'd
Upon this instrument, this unknowne Trull here—

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: Our Eares and Eyes, Fabritio, witnesse for her.

LG.L: You have told me wonders,
Yet with such faith as I shall ever wish
Lockt in this heavenly Cabinet I take all.
You may Fabritio, for as I prize Life;
Honour 'bove that; and above both thy friendship,
My soule is not assur'd of firmer truth,
Let thy Dutch habit drinke off jealousy,
And take her to thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: 'Tis done my Piso.

SP.SPEAKER: Vic.
SP.P: And I made happy past my height of hopes.

SP.SPEAKER: Pant.
SP.P: Good, you shall see how I shall coole those Kisses.

SP.SPEAKER: Pau.
SP.P: May I say boldly you are man and wife?

LG.L: We are most faithfully till death;
I'le fetch a Priest shall streight pronounce ye so.

SP.SPEAKER: Pant.
SP.P: You say that is a Dutchman sir, that wrong'd you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Right, worthy Signior, that's the man I Chal∣lenge.

SP.SPEAKER: Pant.
SP.P: You say you are the man confronted Don here.

LG.L: Yes, and will still mayntain't, for violence
He offerd to that noble vertuous Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Pant.
SP.P: Good! vertuous Lady! Let mee joyne your Friendships.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped. Swa.
SP.P: You have done it sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: That is the man I challenge.

LG.L: The same man I. He has not left the house
Since my abuse; I feare to her much wrong:
For he is some disguis'd Knave on my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Pant.
SP.P: Now you are in the right.

SP.SPEAKER: Swa.
SP.P: Hee could not weare those Cloathes and speake no Dutch else.

LG.L: Still i' the right; i'le shew you what he is,
And out of him, what shee is, whom you call
So vertuous and so noble! and you sir,
That mentioned the Hangman, come all and see
The commendable port this Lady beares.
It seems, sir, you affect this Gentlewoman.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: The best of any living.

SP.SPEAKER: Pant.
SP.P: And you him Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Vic.
SP.P: Yes, he is my husband.

LG.L: Would that were true ifaith. The rogue your man
Sayd he would fetch a Priest—

SP.SPEAKER: Pau.
SP.P: No verier Rogue then my selfe sir.

LG.L: Thou art a mad fellow for a Priest indeed;
But such a Priest, such a Marriage,
Put 'em together.

SP.SPEAKER: Pau.
SP.P: I doe pronounce them lawfull man and wife.

LG.L: The Bridegroome thankes you, but you Mistris Bride
For the fine trick you put on me last night,
Looke now upon your husband,
Who would you speake with fellow?
With Signior Rastrofico here, the Hangman,
I come to call him to State-businesse sir.
Can this be he? (you said he was a counterfeit)
I saw him ride the Wooden-horse, last day
With lesse then halfe this beard, unbeard him sirrah.
I'le beare you out. So rest you Gentlemen
With your so vertuous Lady, and her husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: Pi. &c. Fabritio!

LG.L: Sir I must crave your pardon, This is he,
My first love that I told you of.

SP.SPEAKER: Swa.
SP.P: You have it freely Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Pant.
SP.P: I am abus'd and couzend.

LG.L: I thanke you sir for all the harme you did me
In your Revenge—And harke you, be at peace,
And i'le be silent for your last nights worke.

SP.SPEAKER: Gua.
SP.P: Forbeare mee, I am off againe.

LG.L: Good sir,
Stop not the blessing you were about to give us.
I am off againe. The pandare was the Priest,
The Match is no Match, you no more my Children,
But Knave and strumpet.
I'le not be so couzend.
This is no Priest; and all that's past unlawfull

SP.SPEAKER: Pi.
SP.P: You will know more anon.

DIV3.STAGE: Paulo casts off his Perruk and Beard.

LG.L: Then cast your eys on me, who dare maintain
My Priest-hood lawfull; it being deriv'd
From th'holy Order of St. Augustine?
Let me not surfet with excesse of joy?
My brother Paulo!
Thy brother and thy father, vertuous sister.
Be ever subject of my dearest care;
And pardon me, who (jealous of thine honour
Inflam'd by the same heart, of the same blood:
For we are all the Relicts of our Parents)
Watch'd nearely, and pursu'd thy scape from Rome.
For which I had good warrant, Gentlemen
See there my dispensation with th' allowance
Of all the holy brotherhood of my Covent.
My ends were faire, though in this uncouth way
Tho' (heaven I beg thy pardon) as my care
Was to preserve her life and more her honour;
Fearing her violent and abused spirit,
Might have made wrack of either, or of both,
I once had secret purpose to have ta'ne
Her Life, in case shee had forsooke her honour;
And with her cut off Candianies Line,
Which now branch'd here, may touch the worlds end
With faire succession! Be you blest for ever.
And now, grave sirs, let me intreat your likings,
And cheerefull reconcilement to your Children:
That so you may your Childrens, Children see,
Crownd by the prayers of your prosperity.

SP.SPEAKER: Gua.
SP.P: I am content.

LG.L: And I, but for one scruple
Cleare me this point, how had you sav'd your honor
If the old youth, last night (who shall be namelesse)
Had but mis▪ spent his time upon your moore here?
'Tis easily done sir, see my lov'd Fabritio
The Eunuch moore you gave me.
My boy Jacomo, turn'd Chambermayd!
Has thy Mistris us'd thee well?

SP.SPEAKER: Vic.
SP.P: Not without much desert.

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P: Shee meanes for your deare sake sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: I see, sweete Heart, you have an honest Fa∣mily.

LG.L: Here you see all, and all that came i'th' house;
(Since it was made mine) in this Convention,
I dare them not; but give them freest leave
To speake the worst they found in the Novella.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.P: Wee all conclude y'are noble.

LG.L: All's well accorded then. Wee all are Friends,
And may Priests travaile never to worse ends.
CAuse 'tis the Custome, By the Poet, Sirs,
I'm sent to crave a Plaudit, and the Spurrs
That prick him on to't, is, his promis'd Pay
May chance to faile, if you dislike the Play,
But don't if you be wise; for hee has vow'd
To write farre worse if this be not allow'd.

DIV1.P: Acted at the Cock-pit, by his MAJESTIES Servants, Anno 1632.
Printed for RICHARD MARRIOT, and THO. DRING, and are to be sold at their Shops in Fleet-street, 1653.

LIST.ITEM: SIR Andrew Mendicant, an old Knight, turnd a pro∣jector.
Mr. Swaynwit, a blunt Countrey Gentleman.
Mr. Citwit, a Citizens Son that supposes himselfe a wi.
Mr. Daynty, a supposed Pictured rawer, but a Pick-pocket.
Sir Raphael, an old Knight that talkes much and would be thought wise.
Sir Ferdinand, a Knight distracted for love of the Lady Strangelove.
Lady Strangelove, a humerous widow, that loved to be courted.

LG.L: WEe've cause to fear yours, or the Poets frowne
For of late day's (he know's not (how) y'are grown,
Deeply in love with a new strayne of wit
Which he condemns, at least disliketh it,
And solemnely protests you are to blame
If at his hands you doe expect the same;
Hee'l tread his usuall way, no gaudy Sceane
Shall give instructions, what his plot doth meane;
No handsome Love toy shall your time beguile
Forcing your pitty to a sigh or smile.
But a slight piece of mirth, yet such were writ
By our great Masters of the Stage and Wit,
Whom you approv'd: let not your suffrage then
Condemne't in him, and prayse't in other men.
Troth Gentlemen let me advise yee, spare
To vex the Poet full of age and care,
How he might strive to please yee, and beguile
His humerous expectation with a smile,
As if you would be satisfy'd, although
His Comedy containes no antique show.
Yet you to him your favour may expresse
As well as unto those whose forwardnesse
Make's them your Creatures thought, who in a way
To purchace fame give money with their Play,
Yet you sometimes pay deare for't, since they write
Lesse for your pleasure than their own delight.
Which if our Poet fayle in, may he be
A Sceane of Mirth in their next Comedye.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: YO' have given him then his answer?

LG.L: Forc'd by you,
Heaven knowes with my much sorrow. Such a Lover
So in all points deserving of true worth,
And best indowments to make up a Man
That I shall never see—your pardon sir,
Though you pulld back, by violence, my hand,
In which my heart was freely given to him,
It is not in your power or strength of art
To beat a sigh back, or restraine a teare
Which I must offer to his memory.
Such stormes soone wast themselves in absent Lovers
When light of Reason, and good Counsell shall
Breake forth and shine upon 'em: and for your part
Daughter, I know it shall. And, presently,
I thus begin to dissipate your errors,
You love this Frederick.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Love knows I do.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: You say he is deserving in all points.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: My love emboldens me to tell you he is.

LG.L: Charissa, take me with you. Is he not
Deficient in that onely absolute point
That must maintaine a Lady, an estate?

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Love weighes not that.

LG.L: What can he shew you more
To take you with, then a wild head of hayre;
A very Limebush to catch Lady-birds?
A Tissue Doublet; and a Riband shop
Hung in his Hatbands, might set up a Pedler?
Can this maintaine a Lady?
You but looke
Upon his outside sir.
I trust you have not
Bin over inwardly acquainted with him.
Sir, he has Valour, Wit, and Honour, you well know
Hee's of a noble Family extracted.
What's that a yeare? those parts may be acquir'd
In winning of a strumpet. But what Joincture
Can he propound to you? or, (in case he dyes,
Your Dowry being spent) what personall Estate
Ist like hee'l leave you, but his Powder glasse,
His Combè and Beard-brush, and perhaps a Trunkfull
Of Elegies, Raptures, Madrigalls and Sonnets?
No let him goe; discard him: and embrace
The hopes that I have for thee in the hopefull,
Exquisite Cavalier, Courtier and Souldier,
Scholler, (and what not!) brave Sir Ferdinando:
There's a Man rising in the favour Royall,
And may in thee Charissa, make me happy.
Sir you have given me liberty of speech;
And may be pleas'd to let me tell you now,
You aime at your own fortune, not at mine.
I seeke no fortune, but for thy advancement:
All that I shall call mine must be thine owne.
I would be playner yet; beseeching you
I be not thought too lose in my obedience.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: Speake freely Girle.

LG.L: Your ayme has bin to raise
You state by Court-suits, begging as some call it,
And for that end you left your Countrey life,
And Lands too ever since my Mother dy'd,
Who while shee liv'd with best of womans judgement
Which held you from that course of selling faire
Possessions to enable you with money
To purchace wit at Court. You pardon me?

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: On, on.

LG.L: And for th' Exchange of a faire Mansion-house
Large fruitfull Fields, rich Medowes and sweet pastures
Well cropt with corne and stockd as well with Cattell,
A parke well stor'd with Deere too, and Fishponds in't,
And all this for a lodging in the Strand now—
But doe I not offend?

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: No, no, on still.

LG.L: Your own fed Beefes and Muttons, Fowle and Poultry
Loaded your long boords then; and you had then
Neighbours could boast your hospitality,
And poore, that for the remnants prayd for you,
Now all concludes upon a two-dishd table.
And whereas then you had a numerous Family
Of Servants and Attendants, out of which
For profit or for pleasure you could call
Your Bayliffe, Groom, your Falconer, or your Huntsman,
Now sir, a Varlet Coachman, and Footboy
Are all your Retinue; and for the Hounds
You kept, that made you sport and Musick, now
None but your project Beagles, that smell out
Where such a forfeiture is to be begg'd;
Where one would purchase a Reprieve, another
A Pardon or a lease of Life Rope-free
For ready money: Then where Goods or Lands
Are found of men that make away themselfes,
And so of fooles and madmen; All to set
Your trade of Begging up▪ and still you beg:
But your own want of favour holds you back
From reaching any profit by't, because
You beg by Mediators tongues, which you
Call Favorites, who reape the crop of all,
And leave you but the Gleanings; some small pittance
To keepe alive the itch of begging in you—

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: Shee speakes home and within me, to the purpose.

LG.L: Still wasting your own fortunes; till at last
You have no hopefull project life to thrive by
But to put me upon this suppos'd favorite
To beg for you when it is doubtfull yet
Whether hee'l take me with the Dowry, which
Mine Unkle left me, though you adde your projects.
The noble Gallant loves thee, Girle, and holds
Thy Person and thy vertues Dowry enough,
He is a wanton Lover, full of change,
And at this instant singularly devoted
Unto that humorous Lady, the young Widow.

SP.SPEAKER: Men:
SP.P: The Lady Strange love?

LG.L: Shee is ambitious
To draw all mens affections to her service,
And then abuses all by scornes or slightings,
And this (they say) has made him almost mad.
He mad! believe it not: his reason is
Married to him better then so. How now!
Ha' you seene the noble Knight from me?
How did he entertaine my Message? ha!
Why speakst thou not? what answer has he sent?
Hee's not Sir to be spoken with or seene
To any purpose, but by his Phisitians.
So sodainly and dangerously sick,
Where are my hopes?
I cannot say how sick
He is; nor can himselfe give any account
Of his condition: for he is mad sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: How! mad?

LG.L: Starke staring mad; as mad
As you can thinke a Courtier must be
That is more mad then all the rest.
If this be true I sinke, what is suppos'd
The cause?
That sir has puzzell'd all the Doctors
In weighing all his severall wild affections;
One findes he was ambitious of Court favour,
And guesses he was cross'd in some great suite;
Another takes him as he was a Souldier,
And losing cost and travaile in the warre
Must lose his wits for that. A third collects
He was a Poet that drunk too deepe of Helicon,
And turnd his braine in clyming of Parnassus:
A fourth considering that he was a Gamster
Long and much favourd, and uprais'd by fortune
To mountaynous heapes of Gold, conjectures, that
Some late unlucky hand or chance at play
Hath with his money swept his wit away.
Fy, these can be no causes to remove,
Or shake his settled judgement or his temper.
Then sir a fift and youngst head among
The learned men (what call you him for a Doctor?
Hay that affects gay clothes and Flanders Laces,
That trim effeminate Gentleman) he
Has known this noble patient to have beene
An extreame Amorist, desperatly devoted
Unto the service of some threescore Ladies,
And honord every one the most in costly presents,
Banquets and Verses; and thinks the disdaine
Of one or all of them has turnd his braine.
I told you sir, the cause before; and nam'd
That humorous Lady for it, whom in heart
I can no lesse then thanke.
Goe, get you up.
And stirre not from my Chamber on my blessing
Till my returne, nor admit any one
Unto a conference with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: I obey you.

LG.L: Some of your project searchers wait without sir,
Loden it seemes with new intelligences.
They may come in: but as I feare they bring
Me little comfort, I am sure I shall
Afford them none. Now sirs, your businesse?
We wait upon your honour my good Lord
To crave the knowledge of what good successe
Your honor finds in our late suits my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: Why honor? why my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Pro.
SP.P: We stile you now.

SP.SPEAKER: 3. Pro.
SP.P: As all must doe hereafter.

LG.L: Yes, and that
In a short space of time, the world holds no
Proportion else, nor shall it more be sayd
That money can buy Land; or great Estates
In Lands and Mannor-houses be call'd Lordships.

SP.P: Or wealth joynd with desert attaine to honor.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: So now the Game's afoot. They hunt in full cry.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. P.
SP.P: My Lord 'tis most apparant.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: How you torture me!

SP.SPEAKER: 2. P.
SP.P: Wee'l mak't appeare most plainly on our lives.

SP.SPEAKER: 3. P.
SP.P: And credits too.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Their Lives and credits, ha, ha, ha.

LG.L: That in the space of one whole year our projects
Shall bring in fifty thousand pounds to us,
And hundred thousand to your selfe; and to
The Coffers Royall for full seaven years space
64 Thousand 783 l. 7 s. 9 d ob. q. per annum,
Tis here already cast. Which to make good
Wee'l venture Lives and Goods.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. P.
SP.P: Our Wives and Children.

DIV3.STAGE: Mend. takes the scroll and peruses it.

SP.SPEAKER: 3. P.
SP.P: We can ingage no more.

LG.L: A wondrous strange ingagement
Your lives and goods; your wives & children gentlemen!
That's too deep set, and questions the Kings Mercy:
Me thinks it were enough, for non-performance
You would submit your bodies to perpetuall
Imprisonment at the Kings charge; and leave
Your wives and children to their severall Parishes
You are still faithlesse sir, in all projects.
But when you shall perceive the wealthy sonnes
Dayly brought in, and be, continually,
Troubled with the Receipts (if you may be trusted
That have so little faith) when you shall soyle
And gall your fingers ends with telling money,
Yet find the lickings of 'em sweet, you'l then
Sing other Notes.
Meane time entreat my Lord
To put you to some Tellers Clearke to teach you
Ambo-dexterity in telling money.
Do you hear sir? Can you give me two sixpences
For a shilling—or any single money?
Cry mercy, you weare none in ready coine,
But all in Bullion lockt up in your brave-chests,
And there you have the treasure of the Indies;
Of deeper value, could it be digg'd out,
Then all the Hollanders have waited for
These 7 yeares out of the Spanish plate fleets.
But put mine eye out (now I dare you to't)
With any single peece of ready money.
My Lord your man abuses us here strangely
With his old misbeliefe. But still we doubt not
Your honourable good opinion of us.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. P.
SP.P: You have pervs'd this weighty paper here.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: It weighes not all twelve graines.

LG.L: No more?
Nay the whole platforme of a stately City,
Or a designe to conquer a whole Nation,
But doe you note the grounds, the Rules and Reasons,
First for the easinesse of the severall grants.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. P.
SP.P: Next for performance of our undertakings.

LG.L: And then the certainty o' th' propounded profit
Both to the King and us.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. P.
SP.P: Without all grievance unto the subject.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: That's no little marvaile.

LG.L: Take 'em into particulars my Lord,
First this for Perrukes. The Monopoly
Of making all the Perrukes male and female,
Through Court and Kingdome.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: There's a capitall project.

LG.L: Note the necessity, that they be well made
Of no diseas'd or infectious stuffe, of dead or living,
No verminous or sluttish locks or combings,
But harmlesse and sound haire, of innocent,
And wholesome people.
They must then reape none
From Gallowses, nor Hospitalls; from whence
They have had great supplies.
You have in that
Said very well; For here's a Reformation
Of that abuse intended in these words
Innocent and wholsome.
How if a man or woman shall desire
To weare a friends hayre so departed; as
You his; or your wife yours; may't not be had?
Or if your friend or Mistris dye so, you
Procure the haire and bring it from the Gallows
To th' office, and it may be done accordingly.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: You have in that said very well Sir too.

LG.L: Now out of this provision, what an infinite
Profit will rise i' th' generall use of 'em,
And multiplicity that will be worne
By people of all sorts▪ degrees and ages:
The old to hide their naturall baldnesse, and
The young and middle-ag'd their artificiall
Or accidentall.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: By the pox or so.

LG.L: They shall be brought into that reputation
That none shall be esteem'd so sound or wise
As publique wearers of them: which to effectuate
Tis requisite that you obtaine a Mandat
Unto all Courtiers, that would be thought wise
To weare false hayre: because clownes have been noted
To talke like fooles or mad men in their own.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: No more of that.

LG.L: What say to this my Lord,
Touching new fashions of apparrell; sutes,
Hats, Boots, Swords, Belts, Ribands, &c.
For every wearer of his first o'th' fashion
To pay a groat to th' King; and every Tradesman
Two pence on every severall piece he sells
Of any such new fashion the first yeare?

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: And what may this pride money amount unto Per annum, can you guesse?

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: I will not meddle in it.
No my good Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: No, nor your Perrukes neither.
What say to this my Lord of the Balconyes?

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: Nor that.
This then for sucking out of cornes.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: Away with it.

LG.L: This then: that on the birth of every Girle
The Father pay a groat; to hearten men
To live soberly and get Souldiers.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: Away.

LG.L: This makes amends for all then. A new project
For buylding a new Theatre or Play-house
Upon the Thames on Barges or flat boats
To helpe the watermen out of the losse
They've suffer'd by Sedans; under which project
The subject groanes, when for the ease of one
Two abler men must suffer; and not the price,
Or pride of Horse-flesh or Coach-hire abated.
This shall bring flouds of gaine to th' watermen
Of which they'l give a fourth of every fare
They shall boord at the floating Theatre,
Or set ashore from thence, the Poets and Actors
Halfe of their first yeares profits.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: Fy away.

LG.L: This is a weighty one: For massy summes
That may be freely given out of the City,
To have but this assurance, that hereafter
They may ingrosse the getting of their own
Children: by order tane that Cavaliers,
And Courtiers may no more invade,
Or mix with Tradesmens wives: whereby tis thought
So many City Prodigalls have been gotten;
Onely the thrifty countrey Gentlemen
To be excepted: for by them 'tis guest
So many Citizens grow landed men.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Were not they gotten by Projectors think you?
My Lord your servant jeeres us.

LG.L: To deale plainely
I doe allow't in him—

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Heaven has heard my prayers.

LG.L: And will heare him or any man oppose
All that is put to me by way of project
To put me by all further hopes in 'em:
For (with hearts griefe I speake it) he by whom
I onely hop'd to climbe (alas) is fallen.

SP.P: What out of favour?

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: No, out of his Reason.
The noble Cavalier sir Ferdinando.

LG.L: That late stood candidate for the favour royall,
Is he now fallen besides himselfe?

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: Even he.

LG.L: What have you then to doe my Lord
In lieu of all your service but beg him?
His greater and his nearer friends at Court
Will prevent me.

SP.P: They shall not, never feare it.

LG.L: Come we will make quick worke of this.
My Lord you shall disburse but twenty pieces.
Among us three. 3. And we will instantly
Finde his estate. 1. And lay you down a way
So plaine that you shall say All's yours,
Before you stir a foot.
But when he has travell'd
Till he has tir'd himselfe, he shall returne,
And say All's lost, ist not so Gentlemen?
I will not part with any money sirs.
Trust me you doe not well to put my Lord
Off o' his benefit, by disheartning him
In this small venture. Will you then be pleas'd
To give us but ten pieces.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: Not a penny.

LG.L: Five you shall my Lord,
And stand no longer thus in your own light.

SP.P: Or but a piece a Man.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: Not a denier.
A dinner then my Lord, but of one piece.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: My answers cannot please you. Answer 'em you.

LG.L: I wonder how you having stretch'd your throats
With the loud sounds of thousands, hundred thousands
Can, after all, so faintly whisper forth
One piece; and that as much in vaine, as all
The massy summes: for all but brings you nothing,
It shewes you Gentlemen of resolute patience;
And would take thankfully I warrant you
An od halfe crowne amongst you: and what say you
To every man a kick on the condition?
What say you to one with tother?
This abuse
Shall lose your Master a hundred thousand pound.
Goe coine your bullion braines into the money
And come againe. My master was
Your Lord even now, as he was Lord of Beggers.

SP.P: I hope to live to see him beg of us.

LG.L: Out hundreds, thousands, ten thousands, hundred, thousands, Millions, ten Millions, Millions upon Millions
Away, i'le stamp your buttocks into coyne else. Ex. Pro∣jectors.
The Devill ride that hind most of 'em, for
A raw bon'd Jade: Sfoot he has lam'd my toes.
I am glad I am so rid of' em, and now
As th'art my Servant and my loving Kinseman—

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: To follow you in all things but in Projects.

LG.L: Looke to my House and Daughter, that she start not;
Nor any entrance be allowd to Fredrick
To re-intangle her in his Love. I know
Thy vertue and thy valour can make good
My trust impos'd in thee.
You need not feare sir
But, good sir, no more projects.
I have but one,
On which I'le set my rest. Thoult say tis good.
Except it be the begging of this Madman
It can be nothing.
Tis the very same:
By which I will advance my house and name.
The Beggers best is that he feeles no shame:
Sprecious what meane you? Ha'you forgot so soone
Your Fathers strict command, and he scarce gone yet?
Alas hee'l then meet Fredrick and divert him,
I saw him at the window making this way.
He gets no entrance to you. I must obay
A master though you can neglect a father.
Be not so cruell. Thou mayst live to love,
And need the pitty of a friend.
I pitty you,
And will do no more then you know how to aske
For your own good. I understand your cause
And can relieve you if you'l yeild to councell.
You are my Kinsman; and have bin my friend,
Though you observe my father who, I feare,
Has not a fathers love towards me.
His love is great and certaine,
And all his travell is for your advancement:
But he goes blindfold on unprosperous wayes
Led by credulity. Projects! pox o' projects
The patron of his projects is (it seemes)
Pepper'd with madnesse. Tis but Justice on him,
And now i'le give you a secret if you'l promise
To be ruld by me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: You shall rule me cosen.

LG.L: This Ferdinand, your fathers great Court-godling
Nere sought you for a wife; but to have whor'd you:
(That is the English on't) and to appeare
A right great man in th'act, he would ha' made
By hopes and promises your credulous Father
The instrument of your prostitution:
Which to effect, (though still he undertook
His hopefull projects) cunning Lawyer-like
He crost or lost him still in all, on purpose
That poverty at length might urge him to
Give you to his dispose.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: This was my feare.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Away: some body comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Tis Fredrick. I must see him.

LG.L: You'l never see him more then. Go to your cham∣ber.
A little patience and he shall be yours.
So dos a heart consume in lingring fire,
When cooling hopes are cast on hot desire.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Poore heart I pitty her, and will labour for her.

LG.L: O Gabriel! I am happy in finding thee,
Thy master absent, whom I saw, in hast
Now passing towards the Court. Where's my Charissa?

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: You may not see her.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: May not see her sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: May not! nay must not: shall not see her.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Y'are very plaine with me.

LG.L: Her owne command
Warrants me speake it sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: A villaine speakes it.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: I have a sword speakes other language for me.

LG.L: Can she whose thoughts are truth, and written here,
Here in this breast, giving me ample welcome,
Give thee a countermand to bar me from it?
Wouldst thou make her a double hearted monster?
Or like another woman?
Repent the of thy trespasse yet and live.
Sir, if you thinke to fight, talke not too much;
Or, if you needs must talke, then heare as well.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: What wouldst thou say?

LG.L: Sir, I have more to say
Then fits this place, since you are apt to quarrell;
And this no ground to bustle on: nor indeed
Where I dare for my honesty and trust
Allow you longer stay. If therefore you
Will walke, I'le wait upon you; and direct you
In a more ready way to finde Charissa.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Is shee not here i'th' house?

LG.L: O sir, a man
May come within his arme-reach of his money
In the Exchequer: but he must walke about
To finde due order e're he draw it out.
The fellow's honest, valiant, and discreet,
Full man, in whom those three additions meet.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Sir, dare you trust me?

LG.L: Yes I dare; and why?
Because if thou dar'st fight, thou dar'st not lie.
HEre in this gallery Gentlemen you may▪ at your pleasure,
Untill my Lady comes, walk or sit.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: Or lie down if you please.

LG.L: If you so, wrong not my Ladies Couch with your
Spurres I pray▪ take heed you leave not a Rowell there.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: If one should, your Lady has no Lord to call her honour to question, whose Knight-hood it belong'd unto.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: You have a good countrey wit sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: My name is Swayne-wit; and for all you twit me with the Countrey, I am a Gentleman tho'.

SP.SPEAKER: Ph.
SP.P: I honour you the more sir, for I am a Countrey Maide my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.

LG.L: Thou art a baggage, and a bold one, I am deceiv'd else.
I would be further acquainted with you tho'. Kisse long.
Have you done now? You will have time enough for
Further and better acquaintance.

SP.P: Thou art a Jackanapes of the basest tricks that ever I saw, for a halfe-penny. Shee's your choyce, is shee? Could not you let be tho'? I ha' bin acquainted with thee but two dayes, and forgi'me for swearing, I ha' found thee beating ripe a skore o' times at least. Take heede I be∣gin not now, and hand sell your Ladies house, that is so much talkt on, and your Gentlewomans presence here with a fist about your eares.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: Not for a thousand pound.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: That's a great deale of money. I could find i'my heart to do't tho'.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: Slife we are all undone then.

LG.L: He sets my teeth on edge to looke upon him:
He lookes so like a wilding crab, good neither for drink nor sauce.

SP.SPEAKER: Ph.
SP.P: Why would you presse him then?

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Thou hast a verjuice wit.

SP.SPEAKER: Ph.
SP.P: For my poore sake forbeare sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Let him stand further then, and looke o' to side.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Well sir, this is no cause nor place to fight in, when—

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: What sayes he?

SP.SPEAKER: Ph.
SP.P: Nothing, you heare he whistles tother way.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Tother way, what backwards?

SP.SPEAKER: Ph.
SP.P: What new guest ha' you brought here Mr. Court∣wit, for my Lady to laugh at?

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: One for that purpose Phil, you ha' spoke the man, But what company has my Patronesse, that shee is yet busy.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: I that! If shee be long busy I will not stay, and shee were ten great Ladies, or one as big as twenty, for all shee is your Patronesse, must we wait out of our wits, because Chalivere ran mad for her?

SP.SPEAKER: Ph.
SP.P: Ha' you heard o' that sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: My Cozen Court-wit's question was who's with her?

SP.SPEAKER: Ph.
SP.P: O sweet Mr. Court-wit, when will you bring the fine civill Gentleman, that maintaines himselfe so gal∣lantly by picture drawing?

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Here's a new businesse! Fare yee well, pray tell your Lady I came not from Pensans to grow here.

SP.SPEAKER: Ph.
SP.P: Nay sweet sir stay, there is sir with my Lady none but the grave and witty talking Knight. Some call him the metrapolitane wit of Court; he that loves Ladyes so∣ciety so much, and yet has vow'd virginity.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: As much as in man lies Phil; Hee is a perpetuall vowd batchellor indeed, and as constant to his vow as to his fashion in apparrell, which is ever the same, sir Raphael Winter-plum.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: That old witherd piece. I know him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Thou wilt beare up again.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P:
He has lick'd up a living with his tongue; makes all great tables his own; and eats for his talke: He may be conversant with women: for (they say) he guelt him∣selfe
beyond Sea for spight one did him; and now preaches chastity to Ladies, and love to their husbands. Hee's a Lay-gospeller among the married sort, and an especiall pedant to the youth o' Court.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: Fy, thou speakst too much.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: There's another humor I could beat thee for with all my heart, thou wilt speake outragiously of all men behinde their backs, and darst not answer Ba—to the face of a sheep, O I could pommell thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: This is not yet a cause to fight for, when—

SP.SPEAKER: Ph.
SP.P: But will not that fine Gentleman Mr. Dainty come, Mr. Court-wit?

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: I expect him presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Ph.
SP.P: I'le see if their conference be ended, or breake it if I can, and hasten my Lady to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: This wench has a dainty wit.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: Shee may, living with the prime Lady-wit in towne.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: But what Dainty is that shee talkes on so affecti∣onately?

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: Troth a Gentleman that lives at a good rate; very civill in conversation, keepes good company; yet none of his acquaintance that I am acquainted with knowes his beginning, or his present meanes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: A Gentleman borne.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: I know no more but by his port, and fashion, you saw him with me last night.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Forgi' me for swearing, Ist he?

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: He was at the Play with us too, doe you not re∣member that?

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Yes, that I was at the Play, by sure token and a sad one.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: I'le shew you somewhat of him. A Gentleman borne did you aske?

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Now he beares up againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Hee cannot be a Gentleman by birth or place. A fine-handed, and a fine headed fellow he is; and pre∣tends great skill and practice too in Picture-drawing, Watch-making, and such like finger-workes; which he sayes he uses as a Gentlemans exercise, not as a trade to live upon; when either he does live on't; or else hee has some more secret way, as perhaps pimping or pursing for ought I know.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: There he is again! Art thou bound in conscience to wrong all men in their absence, till I beate thee into better manners?

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: Hold, hold, I prithee hold.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Yet still the cause is insufficient, when—

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: Here comes the Gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Is hee come? Noble Mr. Dainty—The wel∣comst in the World. I protest I suffer'd by your absence.

SP.SPEAKER: Dai.
SP.P: You do me too much honour Mr. Cit-wit.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Oh sir, your humble servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Ha, ha. Forgi' me for swearing, what a Spaniell's this?

SP.SPEAKER: Dai.
SP.P: Gentlemen you are well found, I was a little stayd by the way upon receipt of monies. Ha' you seene the Lady yet?

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: Shee's yet a little busy. We shall all instantly take the opportunity together.

SP.SPEAKER: Dai.
SP.P: But Gentlemen; you that have better knowledge of this Lady informe if you please, why are we summond hither?

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: Thou speakst as if thou hadst guilt upon thee; fear nothing man.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P:
I that's the thing that I would understand too. And why me of any man? They say indeed shee is a hu∣morous Lady, and loves to busy her selfe. But what are we to her? are there not greater men, and Lords enough
for her to foole away the time with, but we must danc attendance on her humors?

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: I protest Mr. Swayn-wit, I admire your inge∣nuity.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: You will be medling still.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Tis to your question sir, which I will answer.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: I there's another of your cockscombly tricks, to answer any question, that's ask'd another man, out with tho'.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: This Lady sir, this humorous wity Lady is a wit∣sponge, that suckes up wit from some, and holds as her own, untill shee squeeze it out on others. Shee will make use of ours, or any courser wits; and search 'em out to sift 'em. Shee will collect from market-folkes; and hold conferences with the poore Trades people that cry their wares about the streets, Shee will rake wit out of a dunghill Ragwoman.

SP.SPEAKER: Swa.
SP.P: So there he is againe! darest thou abuse a noble Lady, in her owne house too? I dare not now but beat thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: Forbeare good cosen.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Still, still, the cause is naught, when—

SP.SPEAKER: Dai.
SP.P: Ods so the Ladies comming I think.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: Gentlemen, my Lady cannot yet be rid of the tedious talking Knight. But shee will cast him presently. He is now following her into this roome, pray passe into the next; my Ladies Musick roome. There you shall find a collation of good Tobacco and Sack and one to attend you, you know the fashions of the House Mr. Court∣wit.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: Come away Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: I could even love and looke upon that sweete Mr. Dainty a whole houre methinks.

SP.SPEAKER: Stra.
SP.P: Goe your wayes down Mayd, and if any aske for Sir Raphael here, say that I hope hee will ha' done anon.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: You would be rid of me: but pardon me Madam, I must hold your glasse to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Stra.
SP.P: That's a poore Chamber-mayds office; and ill becomes your gravity Sir Raphael.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: I'le open then the booke to you of your errors.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: Now you speake scholler-like, and your selfe: But have we spent all this while in by, and idle talke, and have that volume to be open'd yet? Pray read mee for the first Lesson for this Mornings Exercise, and my Edification, the last Chapter of my book of errors as you call it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: You are a mocker of instruction, and good counsell.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: Begins it so? whom is that spoken to?

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: I speak to onely you; to conjure (if I can) that spirit of scorne out of you; which you have taken in, and long affected for a humor, your singular own humor, till it is grown so familiar, so inherent in you, that you have wonne the title of the humorous Lady by't; and drawn a scorne upon your selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Stra.
SP.P: Why then all's paid, and wellcome good Sir Raphael.

LG.L: I am not gone so; nor is all so payd:
For there's a greater reckoning yet of Raylings,
Reviling, Curses by the many that
Y'have scornd and slighted, shot at you in hot vollies.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: They hit me not. I am sure I do not feele 'em.

LG.L: You may in time be sensible of their suffrings,
Whom you have violently, and willfully abus'd
With scorne and pride; if you call to mind
The cause, bred meerly out of humour; cause you would have it so.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: You come too neare mee sir, cause I would have it so?

LG.L: Can it be otherwise? Has it not ever bin
Your practise, since your time of widow-hood
To catch all mens affections? Tis indeed
An honour to a Lady to have many suitors;
But to lay bait for 'em only to delude 'em—
Is impiously dishonorable.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: Have I done so?

LG.L: Yes, and have gloried in it for your humour
To lead men into brakes with foolish fire.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: If they will follow it, I cannot helpe it.

LG.L: You might though have prevented the mishaps
Of many, by a faire and free resistance
In the beginnings of their suits of Courtships,
And not to set your selfe at gaze to draw them on,
And then allure them with assured hopes
Of love and favour till you have wound their follies
Into the reach of your disdaine; and then
To torture 'em, or having ta e 'em captives
To slave and sell 'em to the worlds derision.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: O sir Raphael—

LG.L: Shee feeles compunction!
I will pursue it to the quick.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: On good Sir Raphael.

LG.L: Consider then good Madam, since I know,
And your own conscience knowes, that you have made
A secret vow from your late husbands death
Never to marry, how better and more glorious
It would be for your honor to declare
Your constant purpose to a single life,
Then to fall into the transgression
Of robbing men so of their wits and reason,
And all by willfull humor: as this late
Unhappy accident of madnesse in
The hopefull Knight Sir Ferdinando cryes
Lowdly to your disgrace, and the worlds sorrow.
Halfe the worlds sorrow is mine own
For that sad accident, I would I coold redeem't
With halfe my health or life. But let me tell you
(Now you have justly chidden me) that you
Have a fault too.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: What ist in your construction?

LG.L: As I conceal'd my vow of single living,
And gave men leave to court me, by which meanes
I won them into hopes, and robd their wits,
You in declaring to the Court and City
Your vow of chastity and single life,
Yet dayly, nightly, howerly frequenting
The company of Ladies, with your sweet,
No lesse then grave discourse and conversation
Have rob'd (nay I may say deflowr'd) more Ladies
Of chast and honorable thoughts, then all
The cavalry of Court.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: Who I Madam!

LG.L: Even you sir Raphael (if unchast desires
Must be held sinfull) I know some of them,
And one (I feare) too well, that have bin subject
Unto the breach of any vow for you,
Yet you to vow a single and chast life;
And publish your intent!
Tis with intent,
And a religious purpose to decline,
And divert womans fond affections from me.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: O, but forbidden things are womens longings! You have read, you have read (sir Raphael) you have read.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: And travell'd too: yet never could discover Such an example.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: Pray sit down by me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: Good thoughts possesse you Madam. I must hence.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: I'le not be tedious to you. One word I pray sir?

LG.L: Vertue, be thou my armor. Briefly then
Let me intreat you Madam▪
Pray refuse not
To sit downe by me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: Sanctity protect me.

LG.L: Sir, you are famous, and cry'd up by all
For your great wisdome, Morall and Divine:
You are the Ipse dixit of the Court
As I have heard you stil'd by men of learning.
The Court Philosopher—

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: Madam to the point.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: What is our strength, and what is not our frailty?

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: Where is shee wandering now? Bee playner Madam.

LG.L: Doe not my blushes (which I hope you pardon)
Deliver you a message from my heart?
Which I want words to r? O these vowes!
These rash and ill-made vowes! dos not your judgement
Read something on this face? pray look upon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: I am no good interpreter of looks.

LG.L: I dare not speake, till you have first remov'd
A weighty scruple, which doth much perplexe me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: You must first speake it Madam.

LG.L: Whether these vowes,
(I meane your own, and mine, for single life)
May safely be dispens'd with or absolv'd,
And we become a lawfull paire in Marriage?
Pray sir resolve and blesse me in a Match.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: Madam I'le pray for you.

LG.L: You will first kill me
With your disdaine, and then you'l pray for me!
Is that your Charity?

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: I dare not heare you.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: Leave me not so.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: Who waits upon my Lady here?

LG.L: I had no other way to shift him, would he would make
An errand now to Rome to quit my scruple;
And rid the Court of an officious foole:
Women some times have sent wise men to schoole.
Is the Knight gone?
And blessing of himselfe,
As witch craft were i'th' house.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: But where's my favorite Court-wit, has he brought his countrey Kinsman and the rest?

LG.L: They are all in your wit-office Madam (as you call the Roome)
Passing the time among the Pipes and Bottles,
And singing catches. Here you may here 'em Ma∣dam.
Marry, this takes past▪ all sir Raphaels Lectures,
Goe call 'em downe. Exit Phi.
This Madam troubles me, 'would he were right agen;
Or I quit of the scandall. Enter Court-Swain, and Cit-wit.
O Gentlemen! y'are welcome,
And chiefly you that are the onely stranger,
I ha' been so troubled with an overtalking si, that he
Has wound me into melancholly—

SP.SPEAKER: Swa.
SP.P: I wish you mirth Madam. I come not as one o' you-fooles to make you any though—Offer to go away.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: Be not so briefe with mee, let mee intreat you though.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Forgi'me for swearing doe you mock me tho'?

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: Mistake me not sweet sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P:
Sweet with a mischiefe! How sweet am I? I come
not as a suitor to your great Ladyship. I am a Gentleman of two hundred a yeare tho'.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: Not as a suitor to me sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: No you are too great for me. Nor to your Mopsey without, though shee be snout-faire, and has some wit shee's too little for me, I understand degree and quality, respect and difference; and am scholler enough to know my unde and my quare.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: You ga' me his true character. You are a com∣pleat Gentleman sir (if I mistake not) the Kinsman of my favorite here, who has given me an ample relation of your worth and vertue.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: Yes, Patronesse, 'tis he, who though not throughly vers'd, or conversant i'th' Court or City garbe, he under∣stands both Men and Manners.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Prattle for your selfe sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: But to the businesse Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: I that I would faine know if it be any.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: You have heard I doubt not of a disastrous blot lately cast upon my e, out of my owne free∣nesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Concerning the Mad-courtier Madam, when 'tis as likely, that his Taylor made him mad as you, for not hitting the fashion right in his last rich suit.
