But tis most like he fell from a reasonable man, by over-studying him∣selfe what Lord he should be at the next creation, whe∣ther of Gleek, or Cribbidge;
In and in, or Hazard.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Hearke how this shotten headed Cocks-combe prates! And how he, that can indure beating, dares speak any thing, or abuse all men! canst not give the Lady leave to speake tho'?

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P:
Since there is an aspersion layd upon my freenesse in giving entertainment unto persons of great and noble quaity, the world deeming it to be done by me meerly
for ostntation, to cry my own humor up, by drawing them into Love-knots, and then to slight or scorne them. My resolution is from henceforth, to exclude those great resorts, and friendly and freely be merry within our selfes. I have foure thousand a yeare to spend; and will be huswife good enough to keepe in compasse. I will not entertaine a servant, friend or guest above your rank or fortunes—

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Why—(forgi'me for swearing) what do you think of us?

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: I thinke you Gentlemen of worth and quality: and therefore welcome, I thinke you able to maintaine your selfes midle-sis'd Gent.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: I am Midlesex indeed; borne i'th' City.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Give the Lady leave to speake tho'.

LG.L: I'le give accesse to none, that the censorious world shall dare to judge a suitor to me,
Or to finde favour further then meat and wine.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Yes, faith a little money to; and make's your Fidlers.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Pray give the Lady leave to speak though.

LG.L: Mauger the greatnesse of my former visitants
I give you my election for the chiefes
Of my familier society.
I may perhaps call in, (at least admit)
People of meaner garbe, without (I hope
Your grudge or envy. But they shall be men
Of Science, Art, and Action.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Of action Madam? who do you meane? the Players?

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: Why not? I love their quality and them, and mean to have the use of some of 'em shortly: Besides Musiti∣ans (Poets in the first place) and Painters: In which last mention'd art I heare you are excellent, though all this while so silent.

SP.SPEAKER: Dai.
SP.P: I boast no skill or practise Madam: but I have drawne some pieces that have been worth my paines in my Rewards.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: I must commend their ingenuity for whom you tooke those paines. But (where I left) I must make use of wits, of arts, and actions.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Here in your house Madam, I would be glad to see the Actors, but I saw 'em at their own too lately: for I lost my purse there, no matter let it go. There was 15. pound in't tho!

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Sprecious! How now! my Fob has been ubd to day of six pieces, and a dozen shillings at least. No∣thing but a bowd groat left as I hope for my Grannums blessing.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: Sure you have been in some ill company.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Pox of ill company I say. My watch is gone out of my Pocket too o'th right side.

SP.SPEAKER: Dai.
SP.P: You rose o'the wrong side to day it seemes, were you in no crowd or quarrell?

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: I never was in a quarrell i'my life. I alwayes run from 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: I dare sweare thou dost.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: I onely stood to day at the Coranto-shop to read the last great news; and I was hoop'd in I remember by some that seem'd to wonder as much as I.

SP.SPEAKER: Dai.
SP.P: Then certainly there was a cut-purse amongst 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: I'le go to honest Moll about it presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: But first stay and heare my Lady tho'.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: I Madam you were speaking of the use you would make of Poet, Painter, Musick, Actor and the like.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P:
True favorite for a Masque that I intend to have shortly, you shall performe the poeticall part, your
servant Citwit the Musicall. And by your skill and directi∣ons the Painters office for the scenes. Dancers and spea∣kers I have in store.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: I must be something too tho', must I not Ma∣dam?

LG.L: Marry and thanke you too sir. Enter Philomil.
Now your Newes.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: Sir Andrew Mendicant desires to see you Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: You should have told him I would not be seene by him.

SP.SPEAKER: Ph.
SP.P: I told him you were busy. But hee sayes hee is to speake with you upon a weighty businesse from the Court.

LG.L: Tis the Court-begger. You know him favorite.
Goe not away, I'le bring him in amongst you,
And (as you love me) put some ridiculous projects to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Dai.
SP.P: What's that sir Anw Mendicant? doe you know him well?

SP.SPEAKER: Cour.
SP.P: Thou askest still a question like a guilty person, with a look resembling fear upon thy face.

SP.SPEAKER: Dai.
SP.P: My countenance is too blame then; not my con∣science.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: I'le tell you what he is.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Still answering others questions?

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P:
He is a Knight that hanckers about the Court, ambitious to make himselfe a Lord by begging. His braine is all Projects, and his soule nothing but Court-suits. He has begun more knavish suits at Court, then ever the Kings Taylor honestly finish'd, but never thriv'd by any: so that now hee's almost fallen from a Pallace Bgger to a spittle one. His businesse to my Lady now can be no∣thing but to borrow money to buy a paire of wheeles
to set some Project a going to Court for a Mo∣nopoly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Thou wert in hast ene now to looke after the money; but and thy Life lay on't thou must stay to abuse a man ehinde his back, who is a noble Gentleman thou knowst, and I have heard, yet (speake in thy conscience) wouldst thou not be beaten now?

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: Forbeare, they come.

LG.L: Sir, since it is requested by those great ones
Whose power cannot command me in this case
(For tis my charity and not my duty)
I am content that the mad Ferdinand
Shall so journe in my house for his recovery.
Tis thought you were the ground-work of his frensy
The Doctors therefore mov'd their honours to it
For that your frequent presence may be helpfull
Towards his care.
He shall have it th
Towards the expiation of the crime
They charge me with. But in case sir Andrew
He should be cur'd by this meanes, I should then
Crosse you in fortune and your future hopes
Of his estate; which you have beg'd you say
If he recover not.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: I must leave that to fortune Madam.

LG.L: Will you be pleas'd sir to take notice of
These Gentlemen my friends. They may be usefull Salute
For they have all projective braines I tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: Pray of what nature are your Projects Gentlemen?

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: Sir my affection leanes much to Poetry, especialy the Drammatick.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: Writing of strange Playes?

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P:
I am glad I speake sir, to your understanding.
And my project is that no Playes may be admitted to the Stage, but of their making who Professe or indea∣vour to live by the quality: That no Courtiers, Divines, Students at Law, Lawyers-clearks, Tradesmen or Pren∣tises be allow'd to write 'em, nor the Works of any lay-Poet whatsoever to be receav'd to the Stage, though freely given unto the Actors, nay though any such Poet should give a summe of money with his Play, as with an Apprentice, unlesse the Author doe also become bound that it shall doe true and faithfull service for a whole Terme.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: Here's a trim businesse towards, and as idle as the Players going to Law with their Poets.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: I have another sir, to procure a Patent for my selfe to have the onely priviledge to give instructions to all the actors in the City, (especially the younger sort) the better to enable them to speake their parts emphatically and to the life.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: You were best take heede in time then that you well preserve your own voyce, for feare you doe a spoyle among 'em in teaching 'em to utter in unsavory tunes. Doe I come hither to be mock'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Will you heare mine though? I am a Countrey Gentleman, young, healthfull and lusty. I heare com∣plaints of barrennesse in the City; and of men that can∣not get their wives with child; Get me but a Patent for't I'le undertake by my selfe and deputies (provided that the woman be sound and handsome) to make them mul∣tiply, and upon reasonable conditions: we will deale with the rich for money, and the poore for cha∣rity.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: This is foolisher then tother. Doe you abuse me Gentlemen?

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Is that a wise man's question? you cannot tell th'o.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: We have our projects too Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: I would have yours first, you seeme a civill and substantiall Gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Dai.
SP.P: In more private if you please Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: I like well his reservednesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Dai.
SP.P: Sir I am a Picture-drawer Limner, or Painter (if you please) and wou'd gladly purchase authority, by my selfe and deputies, for the painting of all the Kings, and Queenes-head signes for Tavernes, Innes, Ale houses, and all Houses and Shops of Trade throughout the King∣dome upon this ground that they draw and hang up their tyall Images for signes in so hideous manner that men blesse themselves to see't.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: I marry this hangs upon some ground. But are you an exquisite workeman in that art si?

SP.SPEAKER: Dai.
SP.P: I am an Artist in that mistery sir, and have drawn some of his Majesties Pictures (by coppy onely but) so to the life, that Gentlemen have kneel'd to 'm for suites, and knight-hoods.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: Indeed sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Dai.
SP.P: Yes sir, and great Lords I have pictur'd so power∣fully, their own followers sodainly rushing into the room have started back, and solemnly stood bare to 'em as they hung o'the walls.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: Ist possible!

SP.SPEAKER: Dai.
SP.P: I drew a sterne Judge, and a civill Lawyer so to the life, that after their corps were in the Grave, a man durst not looke upon their pictures without a bribe, or double fee in's hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: I do admire you!

SP.SPEAKER: Dai.
SP.P: I ha' drawn Ladies too, with that alluring beau∣ty, that men have lov'd their dead pictures, for their pain∣ted lookes, more then their living persons for all their vertues.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: Thou boy! introth you abuse me most merrily Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: An excellent fellow: I like him for that fancy more then all the rest.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Pray heare my project too sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: Yes good sir Andrew, you shall not part so ab∣ruptly.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Mine is a good common wealths businesse, against the common Plague, that raignes i'th' City of Pick∣pockets, and Cut-purses▪ I my selfe ha' bin robb'd to day, and am going to a good member that deales in private for the recoveries of such goods: One that shall under∣take if you'l but get a Patent, for a Cutpurse-hall, or Office, to helpe all men to their owne againe, allowing but the Tithes of their Losses, and freeing the offending parties.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: Fie, fie. Here's tithing indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Provided that notice be brought to the Office within foure and twenty houres after any such losse.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: Enough, enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Wee may by the same course secure the Coun∣ties too, and make the hangman hang himselfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: Let every man be wise enough to looke to his purse, and there will be no Cut-purses, nor need of your patent.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: As wise a man as you may lose his purse tho', as I ha' done my selfe in a crow'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: He puts me in mind of a crowd I was in once to day of company I lik'd not—ha—. For hea∣ven 'tis gone: And I dare not discover it for being laught at.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: It seemes none of your Projects will passe with you sir Andrew.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: Come sir, they are but (as you said) merry with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P:
Be you merry with them good Madam, you know the serious worke I came about. In which
I sodainly shall presume to give you a re-visite.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: Pray do sir Andrew, bring your Mad-man. My garden Lodgings shall be his bedlem. Come gentlemen tis Dinner-time.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: We are your waiters Madam.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.

LG.L: THese are the Lodgings, that my Lady appointed
For your distracted patient.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: Like you 'em Doctor.

LG.L: Exceeding well. Excuse me Gentlewoman
That now intreat your absence.
Willingly. I am not taken with the sight you bring:
For I see mad-folkes enough every day.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: Here set him downe. Unbind him, and unblind him.

DIV3.STAGE: Ferdinand brought in a chaire bound and hooded, &c.

LG.L: Am I then taken prisoner in the North?
Wounded, disarm'd and bound? I shall be ransom'd
To which of your rebelliously usurp'd
Castles ha' you brought me? you sir Presbiter,
That better can pugnare then orare,
And so abjure all duty and allegiance—

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: Hee takes you for a Northerne Pastor Mr. Doctor.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: No matter what, let him run out his fancy.

LG.L: You were best to use me well; and like a souldier
Order will else be tane (though you know none.)

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: You shall have all best usage sir.

LG.L: And use my horse well too, and let my horse and armor
Be decently preserv'd and seene forth-comming
At my redemption.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: With all best care sir.

LG.L: For I shall soone be sent for, or fetch'd off
With ruine of your countrey 'bout your eares.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: You shall have all content the countrey yeilds sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.P: I shall have Oat-bread, Ale, and Bag-pipes, shall I?

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: If you'l be merry sir.

LG.L: Merry! why not? come let's ha' cards; and you and I to cribbidge
For an od hundred pound, I meane not Scotch,
But sterling English pieces, where's your money?
All gone in Ammunition, and charge Military.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: I'le finde you money enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.P: O here's a third man, let's then to Gleeke.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: Crown Gleeke sir, if you please.

LG.L: Crown Gleeke! no more?
You seeme to be a thrifty Covenanter
To play but at crowne Gleeke, whole piece Gleeke or nothing.
High as you please sir, wee'l find money enough,
And pay us but our buyings.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.P: Sir, you must bae mee Aces. You will play Tib and Tom.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: All i' the Cards sir.

LG.L: Away with cards. Bring dice, set all at hazard,
And though I lose all, I have yet a project
That at the end o'th' war, and the great sitting
Shall fetch all in agen. But O my Muse!
How dare I so neglect thy inspirations?
Give me Pen, Inke and Paper.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: All's ready.

LG.L: Now will I write, nor will I emulate
Ovids smoth vaine, or Petraks buskind stile.
Nor Laura, nor Corinna did deserve
To have their prayers written n such Verse
As i'le bestow on her that I adore.
Listen to me you blest Intelligences,
And, Phebus, stay thy course to heare me sing
Her prayses, for whose love th'inamor'd Gods
Would leave their proper seates, and in stoine shapes,
Converse with mortalls, your soule-ravishing spheres
Send forth your sweetest harmony whilst I sing—
But O shee is disdainfull; and her scorne
Hath blotted all the glory of her praise,
Away, away with all.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: Now sir, doe you observe the roote of his Disease?

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: I guesse at it, know you the remedy?

LG.L: Disease! what's that? who is diseas'd? who wants a Remedy?
Are you sir a Phisitian?

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: This Gentleman is, and brings you remedy, be you patient.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: O you will move him.

LG.L: You are a brace of Quacks,
That tie your knowledge unto dayes and houres
Mark'd out for good or ill i'th' Almanack.
Your best Receipts are candy for a cold;
And Carduns Benedictus for an ague,
Could you give life as Aesculapius
Did to unjustly slaine Hippolitus,
You could prescribe no remedy for me.
Goe study Gallen, and Hippocrates,
And when your rare simplicities have found
Simples to cure the Lunacy of Love,
Compose a potion, and administer't
Unto the Family at Amsterdam.
I'le Phisick you to morrow and allay
The heate of this strong fit, or Leach it out.
I have venter'd to this house againe, assur'd
That now the humerous Lady is from home
Forgetting not her Love-trick put upon me
Which she already boasts to my disgrace
For which I may require her Ladyship,
How dos your patient? a sleepe! That's well.
No hee's but silent sir, and it is well
That he is so, so long.
The Lords in honorable regard unto
His health directed me to visite him.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.P: Who's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: Do you not know me sir?

LG.L: You are (I tak't) the Ghost of Dionisius
The great tirannicall Court-schole-master.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: Your Friends at Court commend them to you Sir.

LG.L: What hither, unto hell? Extend their loves
So far, to finde me out? Pray let 'em know
That here's a trobled world in want of Statesmen.
But tell the youthes and beauties there, they never
Shall finde a happier opportunity
To raise a new Plantation. They'l drive all
Before 'em here. For pride is at a stand;
Fashions are all worne out, and no invention
For new here to be found: all beauty's lost;
Nor have the greatest Ladies here the act
To make so much as their poore Chambermyds:
Let 'em come downe, as many of the Gallants
As are made weary of their Wives or Mistresses;
And, of those Wives and Mistresses, as many
As can their husbands, or their servants spare:
And what a yeare of Holy-dayes, a Jubile
Shall we have in hell then? Ha' old Lad!

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: What a wilde fancie's this!

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: Crosse it not good sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: Pray give mee leave to touch it though, a little.

LG.L: But above all, finde out the Lady Strangelove
That humorous Madam, and tell her from me,
The many Lovers shee has sent before her
Into these shades (where we can find no torments
Like those that shee inflicted) have prevail'd
With the great Queene Proserpina, that shee
Shall be in place next to her royall person.
The Lady Strangelove! you are in her house sir,
Where doe you thinke you are? or who you are?
Pray call your selfe to mind sir, are not you
The noble Cavalier and hopefull Courtier
The most accomplish'd Knight sir Ferdinando?

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: Forbeare sir, you will move him strongly else.

LG.L: I have authority for what I do sir,
Can you forget your selfe sir, or neglect
The bounteous fortunes, that the Court and Kingdome
Have in store for you, both for past Atchievments,
And for the large endowments of court-vertue
Are found still growing in you, studied and practis'd
So to the life, as if you were built up
Vertues own Mansion, on her foure firme pillars?—
I hope he cannot flatter him into's wits
When 'tis the way to foole men out of 'em.
The Wisdome, Justice, Magnanimity,
And temperance of court you are exactly
Fram'd and compos'd of, and indued with all
The excelencies that may adorne a man
By Nature, Fortune, Art and Industry!
And all this glorious light to be eclips'd;
And such Divine perfections seeme to sleepe?

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.P: Pray sir your eare.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: Sir, most attentively.

LG.L: What do you thinke of Salsbury steeple sir,
For a fit hunting speare t' incounter with
The whore of Babilion? might I not firke her thinke you?

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: Your Doctrine dos not edify sir Raphael.

LG.L: Is Oratour Demostines growne dumbe
O'th' sodaine? what! no answer? give me a Knife
He is but tongue-tied.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra:
SP.P: Guard me Divinity.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: I told you what you would doe.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: Patience good sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.P: Patience in tortures?

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: Helpe here sodainly!

LG.L: Do you sally forth in troupes? Have I no troupe?
Give me my horse and armes, and come a hundred.
Wee'l arme and horse you, since y'are so unruly,
Away with him into his Bed-chamber.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.P: O doe you make me then your Knight o'th' shir A tun o' Wine for that. Shoulder your Knight, advance your Knight, beare him out.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: A Ferdinand, a Ferdinand, &c.

LG.L: This now to me is Musick, Golden chimes
That rings all in with an assur'd advantage,
How now Sir Raphael! Frighted?
In all my disputations all my travailes,
And all conspiracies that have bin had
Aagainst me, never met I an incounter
By man, or spirit that I feard so much,
Yet here's another fury.
By what oppression or tiranny (for Law
I'm sure could never do't) is my house here
Confiscated or usurp'd, and I become your slave?

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: How Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: Your slave, lay your commands on mee, what drudgery doe you appoint me to?

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: Shee's mad too.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: Did not your Ladyship give way?

LG.L: To make my house a hell?
The noyse of Bedlem is soft Musick to 't.
Could your Projectorship find no house else
To make a mad-man madder in but mine?
And me as mad as he too with the trouble.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: I was no principle in't good Madam.

LG.L: Was it your plot then sir Philosophaster,
That so you might under pretext of reading
Philosophy to him, to cure his madnesse
Make your adresse to me to prosequte
Your Love-suite when I thought I had answer'd you,
But if you must proceede, o'recome me if you can,
Yet let me warne you to take heede withall
You pull not a disease unto you, that may
By your ungovern'd hast post into
Your grave: for I shall prove a torment to you,
Though you'l take no denyall, take yet a warning.
I take it to forsake your house; and never
More to resort where madnesse raignes. Did I
Make love to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: Pardon mee vertuous sir, it is my love to you that tortures mee into this wild distraction. O sir Raphael.

LG.L: Now vertue guide me. I will shun this place
More then I would the Spanish Inquisition.
I shall in time be rid of all such Guests,
And have the liberty of mine owne house
With mine own company, and to mine own ends
Where are you Phil? I were but dead if I had not this
wench to foole withall sometimes.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: I must be a little serious with you, shut the dore.

LG.L: Now am I call'd into correction,
When shee is vext and wants the company
Shee likes, then come I into question,
'Tis common among Ladies with their women.
Why that down looke, as if you meant to fetch
An answer, or excuse out of your Apron-strings
Before you are charged or question'd? what new faul
Has past of late?
Doe you read any Madam
Upon my face or lookes? I never was in love
Much with my face, nor ever hated it. But if I thought
It had upon't, or in it, any trespasse
Against your Ladyship (my heart being cleare)
These Nayles should claw it out.
Nay be not passionate Phil. I know you cannot
Forget the care I have had of you; nor should you
Distrust me in the promises I have made you,
Bearing your selfe according to your covenant Phil,
Of which one Article is to laugh with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ph.
SP.P: Go, you are such a Lady, ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: Now thou comst to me wench: hadst forgot?

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: You said you would be serious.

LG.L: Dost not thou know my seriousnesse is to laugh in private,
And that thou art bound to stir that humour in me?
There's but two things more condition'd in thy service;
To do what I bid thee, and tell me the truth
In all things that I aske thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: I Madam, you had never known that same else▪

LG.L: Of the clap thou hadst i'the Countrey e're I took thee,
But hast thou faithfully kept thine own e're since?

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Yes most severely Madam on your promise—

LG.L: Well we will have a husband then to solder up the old crack,
I have already made my choyce for you:
Your sweete-heart Cit-wit makes most suite to you,
And has a good Estate, and wit enough
Too for a husband, and a handsome person.
I finde no fault in all that. But he is
So base a coward, that he may be soone
Beaten out of his wit and money.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: But if he should prove valiant!

LG.L: If he were valiant now I could say something,
But to wait for growing to't were such a losse of time.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: What say to Swayn-wit?

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Hee's the others extreame. I might feare him but never love him.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: What think you of my speciall favorite Mr. Court∣wit?

LG.L: As of a Courtier Madam, that has tasted
So much of all waters, that when he has a fountaine of his owne
Hee'l be too jealous of it.
And feard that every man will drink of's cup
When perhaps none dares touch it, were I it.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: What say to Dainty then the curious Limner?

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: I am bound from lying. Madam hee's the man.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: Well i'le take thy cause in hand wench: But yet we are not merry. I am inclin'd most jovially to mirth me thinks. Pray Jove some good be towards. Laugh or i'le pinch you, till you doe.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha, ha, Madam, ha, ha, ha. O the picture drawer! ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: I, come, the Picture drawer.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P:
O, I love drawing and painting, as no Lady bet∣ter,
who for the most part are of their occupation that professe it. And shall I tell all Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: By all meanes Phil.—now shee's enter'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: I hope I am handsome enough too. For I have heard that Limners or Picture-drawers, doe covet to have th fairest and best featur'd wives, (or if not wives, Mistresses) that they can possibly purchace, to draw naked Pictures by, as of Diana, Venus, Andromeda, Leda, or the like, either vertuous or lascivious; whom they make to sit or stand naked in all the severall postures, and to lie as many wayes to helpe their art in drawing, who knowes how I may set his fancy a worke? and with mo∣desty enough. We were all naked once, and must be so againe. I could sit for the naked Shepherdesse, with one Leg over the tother Knee, picking the Thorne out of her Foote most neatly, to make the Satyre peepe under.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: Well thou shalt have him.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: Mistris Philomel.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: Let in the Boy. Now sir your newes?

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: The mad Knights Doctor Madam intreats to speake with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: Now seekes he may assistance in his cure.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: And Mr. Court wit, and the other Gentlemen are below.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: Goe you and entertaine the Gentlemen, while I consult with the Doctor, let him enter.

Now Mr. Doctor! you come to aske my counsell I know for your impatient Patient. But let me tell you first, the most learned Authors, that I can turne over; as Dioscorides, Avicen, Galen, and Hyppocrates are much discrepant in their opinions concerning the remedies for his disease.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: Madam—

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: Therefore I trust you'l pardon my weaknesse, if my opinion jumps not altogether with your judgement.

SP.SPEAKER: Doc.
SP.P: Madam, my purpose was not—

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: My purpose is to advise you though, that, if his Frenzie proceed from love as you conjecture, that you administer of the rootes of Hellebore, destill'd together with Salt peter, and the flowers of blind Netles, I'le give you the proportions, and the quantity is to take.

SP.SPEAKER: Doc.
SP.P: Mistake not me good Madam—

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: But if his Malady grow out of ambition, and his over weening hopes of greatnesse (as I conjecture) then he may take a top of Cedar, or an Oake-apple is very soveraigne with the spirit of Hempseed.

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.P: Madam, I seeke no counsell in this case, my cun∣ning is—

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: To let me know, that that part of my house which I allow you is too little for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.P: Shee's surely mad.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: But you must claime possession of the rest, You are come to warne me out on't; are you not?

SP.SPEAKER: Doc.
SP.P: Mistake not so good Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: Or do you call my attendance on his person, by way of a Nurse-keeper? I can do little service.

SP.SPEAKER: Doc.
SP.P: For my part Madam I am sorry we are made the trouble of your house, and rather wish me out on't then your favour. But if your Ladyship will bee pleas'd to entertaine with patience the little I have to say.

SP.SPEAKER: Stra.
SP.P: Come to it quickly then.

LG.L: First, let me tell you Madam, as 'tis manifest
You were the cause of his distraction,
Y'are bound in charity to yeild such meanes
(With safety of your honor and estate)
As you may render for his restoration
VVhich of all the earthly meanes depends on you
If I know any thing in my profession.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: Come to the point, you'ld have me visit him.

LG.L: True Madam: for a sight of you, shall more
Allure his reason to him, then all medicine
Can be prescrib'd.
By your favour sir, you say
Saving my honor and estate I am bound,
But may I with the safety of my Life,
And limbes and a whole skin dare venture.

SP.SPEAKER: Doc.
SP.P: My life o' that.

LG.L: You might more safely lay
Lives of a hundred Patients.
Now hee's calme,
Now shall he see you, but at most secure
And modest distance.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: Come for once i'le trust you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Come out into the Garden here; and let them talke within, I say he shall talke with her; and his belly full, and doe with her too, her belly full, for all thou: an honest discreet Gentleman, and thou a coward and a cockscombe. Besides he has an art and quality to live upon, and maintaine her Lady-like, when all thy money may be gone. And yet thou prat'st o'thy two thousand pound at use, when thou and thy money too are but an asse and's load tho'.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Well, you may speake your pleasure. This is no cause to fight for.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: I'le make thee fight, or promise to fight with me, or somebody else before we part, or cut thee into pieces.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: But tell me seriously dost thou love my Ladies woman so well as to marry her, and suffer the Picture∣drawer now to court her privately, and perhaps to draw and carry her from thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Why he here will have it so you see, and pull'd mee out.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: It is to doe a cure upon thee, coward.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Coward! pish! a common Name to men in buffe and feather. I scorne to answer to't.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Why dost thou weare a Sword? only to hurt mens feet that kick thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: Nay you are too severe.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Pray hold your peace. I'le jowle your heads to∣gether, and so beat ton with tother else. Why dost thou were a Sword I say?

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: To fight when I see cause.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: Now he sayes something, yet, and may be curable.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: What is a cause to fight for?

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: I am not to tell you that sir, It must be found out and given me before I ought to take notice.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: You may safely say for Religion, King or Countrey.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Darst thou fight for Religion? say.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Who that has any Religion will fight I say?

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: I say thou hast none. Speake, hast thou any?

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Truly, in this wavering world I know not how to answer.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: La you. Hee'l say he has no King neither, rather then fight.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: Why if he will not fight for him he is no Subject, and no Subject no King.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: I thanke you sir, I would ha' said so.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: O thou wouldst make a speciall Souldier now!

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Well sir, all are not choyce doggs that run, some are taken in to make up the cry.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: And for thy Countrey, I dare sweare thou wouldst rather run it then fight for't.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Run my Countrey I cannot, for I was borne i'the City. I am no clown to run my Countrey.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Darst thou tell me of clowns thou cockney chick∣en-hearted whelp thou?

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Forbeare good sir, there are countrey Gentlemen as well as clownes, and for the rank I honour you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Sirrah you lie, strike me for that now; or I will beat thee abhominably.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: Up to him man: wilt thou suffer all?

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: I would—but—

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: You lie I say againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: I thinke I doe, I thinke I doe, and why should I maintaine an evill cause?

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: The wench thou lov'st and doatest on is a whore.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Sir, if she be 'tis not my fault, nor hers: somebody else made her so then I warrant you. But should another man tell me so!

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: What then?

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: I would say as much to him as to you. Nor in∣deed is any mans report of that a sufficient cause to pro∣voke mee unlesse shee her selfe confess'd it, and then it were no cause at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Here's a true City wit now.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: I should have wit sir, and am acounted a wit within the walls. I am sure my Father was Master of his company, and of the wisest company too i'the city.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: What company's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: The Salters sir. For sal sapit omnia you know.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Your Father was a cuckold tho', and you the Son of a whore.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: Fight now or you'l die infamous, was your Mo∣ther a whore?

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Deny't and darst, say, was she not?

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Comparatively shee might be in respect of some holy woman, the Lady Ramsey, Mistris Katherine Stubbs and such, ha, ha. Is that a cause?

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: What! not to say your Mother was a whore?

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: He may say his pleasure, It hurts her not: shee is dead and gone. Besides, at the best shee was but a wo∣man, and at the worst shee might have her frailtie like other women. And is that a cause for mee to fight for the dead, when wee are forbidden to pray for 'em?

SP.SPEAKER: Cou
SP.P: But were your Mother living now, what would you say or doe?

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Why, I would civilly ask her if she were a whore? If she confess'd it, then he were in the right, and I ought not to fight against him: for my cause were naught. If she deny'd it, then he were in an error, and his cause were naught, and I would not fight, 'twere better he should live to repent his errour.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Nay, now if I do not kill thee let me be hang'd for idlenesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Hold I am unprepar'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: I care not—unlesse thou sweare presently, and without all equivocation upon this sword—

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Scabberd and all I pray sir, The cover of the book is allowd in courts to sweare upon.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Well sir, now you shall sweare to challenge the next that wrongs you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Yes, if the wrong give me sufficient cause.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: Cause agen! suppose that fellow within should take your wench from you? which very likely he has done already: for I left 'em close on a couch together Kissing and—

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Gi' me the booke, i'le have her from him, or him from her if he be without her belly, or Kill him if he be within her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Tis well a cause may be found at last tho'.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P:
I like a man, whom neither Lie, Kick, Battoune, scandall, Friends, or Parents, the wrongs of Countrey, King or Religion can move, that will, yet, fight for his
wench. Thou wilt be one of the stiffe blades o' the time I see.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: A wench is a moving cause:

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: Helpe, helpe, here helpe—ha—

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Why dost not draw and run in upon 'em?

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: After you I will sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: A pox upon thee art thou down agen?

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: No sir, I am drawn you see.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: Help, help, a rape, a rape, murder, help!

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Cou. Tis time to fly then.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Dainty (his sword drawne) and Philomel.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: I come my Philomel.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: What's the matter Phil?

SP.SPEAKER: Dai.
SP.P: What cry was that?

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Was it not you that caus'd it sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Was it not here?

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Was it not you that cry'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: Is there helpe, helpe, helpe?

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: O tis my Lady in the Madmans chamber. Is her mirth come to this?

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Where, which way?

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Here, here the dore's made fast.

DIV3.STAGE: Exe. omnes Pret. Cit. his sword drawn. Doctor looks out above. Florish his sword.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: I'le breake it open.

SP.SPEAKER: Doc.
SP.P: Help here, help the Lady; help the Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: We are a comming, you shall have help enough
I warrant, what's the matter? you shall not lack for help—

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.P: Away Medusa. Hence, thou hast transformd me. Stone, stone, I am all stone. Bring morter and make a bul-wark of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: O that's the Mad-man! How madly he talkes!

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.P: Hold me not down.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P:
Stones to make a bul-warke quoth a! If he had
but to make a brace of Demy-culvering bullets, they were thumpers I thinke.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.P: Hold me not down, but reare me up, and make me my own statue.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Strangelove, Swain-wit, Court-wit, Dainty. Phil.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: Was ever such a practice?

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: A meere accident of madnesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: I say it was a practise in the Doctor.

SP.SPEAKER: Dai.
SP.P: Yet he calld out for help.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: You had broke up the dore first. That was but to colour his trechery.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: A new way, and a very learned one I promise you; to cure madnesse with a plaister of warme Lady∣gutts.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: He would ha' had a mad bout with my Lady it seemes. He would ha' vented his madnes into her. And she could ha' drawn better then the Leaches.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: If you believe this Madam, tho' sir Ferdinand be by his madnesse excusable in the attempt, you ought to be reveng'd upon the Doctor.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Let's cut him into pieces Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: I'le think upon some way to make him a dread∣full example to all the Pandarean Doctors i' the Towne. Come in Gentlemen, and helpe mee with your ad∣vices.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: You shall want no advise Madam. No strength, Let's goe sir.

DIV3.STAGE: He snatcheth Phil. from Dainty, who took her by the arm.

SP.SPEAKER: Ph.
SP.P: What mean you Mr. Cit-wit?

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: I have sworne. Therefore I say no more, but I have sworne▪

LG.L: THou art so honest, that I am asham'd
The vice of Anger blinded so my Reason,
As not to see through thy transparent breast
A true and noble heart; such as becomes
A Kinsman and a friend to her I love;
I can see now, and read thy integrity,
And, by the light of that th' inhumane false-hood
Of that Court-monster, that compacted piece
Of Rapine, pride and Lust.
Yet this is he
That did aspire to be a glorious Courtier.
Courtier? A meere vaine glorious imposture;
Pretending favour, having nothing lesse.
Witnesse his want of Merit. Merit only
It is that smoothes the brow of Majesty,
And takes the comfort of those precious beauties
Which shine from grace Divine: and hee's a Traytor
(No way to stand a courtier) that to feed
His Lusts, and Riots, works out of his Subjects
The meanes, by forging grants of the Kings favour.
What my master has suffer'd by his forgeries
I know to be the Shipwrack even of all
Except his Daughter, and what his ayme at her
Was I thinke appeares to you; And what she might
Have suffer'd by't we both may guesse: onely we hope
Her vertue would have bin a guard to her beauty.
Tis plaine he never lov'd her vertuously
That is fallen mad for another.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: That madnesse is his fate; which renders him into my masters hands to restore all agen. I, note the Justice of it.

LG.L: But as his fortune by the others ruine
Shall be advanc'd, I shall be more rejected.
That foule mistrust much misbecomes a Love
Rejected sir? by whom? Charissa's constant to you,
And time will cleare his frownes: and put you on
Now, the same confidence you had before;
His wanting fortune rais'd a storme against you,
Your noble friend Sir Raphael has already
By learned reasons and court-oratory
Prevayl'd for you to visit her: and now
Y'are come within the verge o'th 'house, do you shrinke?
See, a good Omen, they issue forth to meet you.
I'le heare no more on't sir, and am much sorry
That so much Lip-labour is spent already
Upon so vaine a Subject.
Give me leave then
To wonder at your light inconstancy,
Your want of resolution: yea of judgement.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: He is flown off agen.

LG.L: Did you not give me leave to send for him;
Who, now is come to tender his affection
Unto your Daughter?
Did not you first promise Ferd▪ Char. and Gab. aside
To give assurance of fit joincture for her,
Proportionable to her dowry, which
You now are started from?
I understood not
Nor can yet understand more of her dowry
Then a thousand pound which her Unkle left her,
And answerably to that I will make good her joincture.
O you are short sir,
I meane to make her worth ten thousand more
Out of my estate in the mad Ferdinand.
Another ten thousand to redeeme my Land,
Ten thousand more, i'le keep in bank for purchace.
A judgement's fallen upon him: Hee's mad too;
Struck lunatique with his o're-weening hopes
Sprung from the others misery.
And so sir, as you came you may depart:
For 'lesse you bring a thousand pound per annum
T'assure upon her, shee's no wife for you.
O sir, you had better left me in that peace
I lately slept in, without any hope
Of seeing her againe, then by your summons
To startle me back from a quiet death
To Kill me thus with Tantalizing tortures.
Thank then your learned friend, who fail'd me in
His undertaking for you, and for her
If walls and locks can hold her, she no more
Shall tantalize you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: Wherein have I fail'd sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: Sir, in assuring joincture to her Dowry.

LG.L: Sir to no possible dowry you can give her,
But you propound the estate you have i' th' Moon;
When shall you take possession, thinke you, of your
Lordship of Lunacy in the Cynthian Orbe?
I shall climbe thither sir without the helpe
Of your Heaven-scaling ladder of Philosophy.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: Nay then sir heare me.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: What in private sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Fre.
SP.P: Remember, sweet, your vow.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Most constantly. And let mee conjure you by this.

SP.SPEAKER: Fre.
SP.P: And this—

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: That you forget not yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Quick, quick! i'le stand before you.

LG.L: And time at length will point us out a meanes
After a short long-seeming separation
To meet and reunite our vowes and faiths
With greater strength and fervour.
Ha! i'le part you.
Was it for that you whisper'd, politick sir?
And couldst thou stand their screene? thou treacher ou
varlet out of my dores.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: For what offence?

LG.L: Darst thou expostulate?
Thou death deserving Villaine. Hurts him.
And Huswife get you in: you may depart sirs
Has your love blinded you? i'le lead you then.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: Madnesse at heighth.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: Will you along!

LG.L: O sir you are unkinde.
Love then a wilfull father is lesse blind.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: Friend, has he hurt thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: I am sure I bleed for't.

LG.L: Why how now Frederick? despaire not man.
He has vex'd me; and out of my vexation
Shall spring thy comfort. I will labour for thee,
I'le study nothing more then to beguile
This watchfull fury; this Hisperian Dragon.
Say to thy selfe and boldly shee's thine owne,
And for thy meanes, (Basta) let me alone.

SP.SPEAKER: Fre.
SP.P: You are my noble Patron.

LG.L: Turn'd away:
As I was his servingman, I am rewarded;
Tis common with us creatures to serv'd so:
But, as I am no more his servant, I
Am free to vindicate my ele out of
The wrong done to my blood (which is the same
With his,) by him rejected and despis'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Sir Andrew Mendicant at home?

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Not to be spoken with at this time sir.

LG.L: Pray let him know that the Lady Strangelove
Requires him sodainly to remove his Madman
Out of her house; or shee must take a course
Much to his disadvantage.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: In good time sir.

LG.L: This is a surly fellow, and tho' I have sworn
The humor of fighting is scarce warme in me yet,
And she advises him to find a better Doctor for him,
For this has taken a wrong course.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Say you so sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: I'le tell't you as a secret. The Physitian thought to have cur'd his patient, (who has bin a notable Game∣ster at In and In) between my Ladies legs. If I and two or three more (but chiefly my selfe indeed) had not rescued her, the Doctor had held the Lady-cow to the Mad-bull.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: May I believe this?

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: He thinks I lie now. And should he gi' me the lie, the vertue of my Oath were questionable.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Is this upon your knowledge sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: True upon my life. So farewell honest friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: This may prove sport and businesse too.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: We will do something sodainly.

LG.L: What if you take me into that something too?
I guesse it is some stratagem to beguile
The cautious father of his injur'd daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: This fellow will betray us.

LG.L: I will venter
All that I have, my fortune in Charissa
On his fidelity, sir his thoughts are mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: Cupid and Mercury favour our designe.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.

LG.L: YOur judgement (by your favour) Mr. Doctor
Much faild you in that case.
Your reason yet may plead
Mine innocence, that drew her but to visit him.
But that drew on his fury; and though reason
May argue much for you, shee can heare none,
Nor any understand: The swift affrightment
Upon her strength of passion, struck so deepe
A sense into her, that is has depriv'd her
Of all her proper senses. She is even mad sir.
Not past my cure; and by a present meanes
Pray, win her hither to see a madder object
Then is her selfe, and see how that will worke.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: I'le gladly ad my paines unto your skill.

SP.SPEAKER: Doc.
SP.P: Come forth into the aire. Conduct him gently.

LG.L: Into the aire! Set me upon Mount Lathmos,
Where I may see, and contemplate the beauty
Of my ador'd Diana; or carry me
Up to Hymttus top, Cytheron, Othris or Pindus
Where shee affects to walke and take the ayre;
Or tarry, stay, perhaps shee hunts to day
I' th' woods of Merathon, or Erymanthus.

SP.SPEAKER: Doc.
SP.P: That's a long journey sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Fre.
SP.P: Y'are a long bearded foole.

LG.L: I thought I had been a Phisitian. But sir
You shall not need t' expose your selfe to travell,
Your Goddesse will descend into this Garden,
Passe but time here a while and shee'l come to you.
We will have joviall pastime. Shall we run
At base, or leape frog, or dance naked
To entertaine her, or what do you thinke
Of downe-right drinke and singing?

SP.SPEAKER: Doc.
SP.P: That's best of all.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.P: Let's have a mad catch then.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: Here Madam may you see the Madmans Revels.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: And after that the Doctors Tragicomedy.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.P: Are not your wind pipes tun'd yet? Sing

LG.L: So now a Dance, I am all ayre—Ahaigh—Ahaigh
I thanke thee Mercury that hast lent thy wings
Unto my feete. Play me my Countrey Dance,
Stand all you by. These Lasses and these Swaines
Are for my Company.

SP.P: He Dances a conceited Countrey Dance, first doing his honours, then as leading forth his Lasse. He danceth both man and womans actions, as if the Dance consisted of two or three coupls, at last as offring to Kisse his Lasse, hee fancies that they are all vanish'd, and espies Strangelove.

LG.L: How now! all vanish'd, ha!
It is no mervaile that the lesser lights
Become obscur'd when Cynthia appeares,
Let me with Adoration fall before
Thy Deity great Goddesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: Keepe him from me.

LG.L: You must approach no nearer sir. The Goddesse
Is not so confident in her Divinity
As to trust you in reach of her.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: Keepe back sir.

LG.L: What Hydras, Gorgons, and Chymaeras are you;
Centaures and Harpies that dare interpose
Between my hopes, and my felicity!

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: Doctor, away with him.

LG.L: Carry him to his Chamber,
And hold him down. His raging fit is on him
Was Night made to surprise men at Noon-day?
Or shall the charmes of Heccate take force
To dimne Apolle's brightnesse? So't must be,
When Gods themselves give way to Destine.

DIV3.STAGE: Exiunt with Ferd. Swa. pulls back the Doctor.

LG.L: They are enough to hold, and binde him too.
Come you afore the Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: What's her pleasure?

LG.L: Tis to do Justice upon thee O Doctor
Stirre, or cry out, or give the least resistance,
And I will cut thy head off before judgement.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: What outrage doe you intend?

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: Outrage! Can you thinke of an outrage above the horror you offerd to this Lady, To violate her cha∣stity? her honor?

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: You cannot say so.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Tis said, and you are guilty. Proceed to judge∣ment Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: I first would heare your censures.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: And mine among the rest good Madam. I have taken care that a new Doctor shall be brought. Therefore in the first place my censure is, that this be presently hang'd out o' the way.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: That's too high straind. What thinke you Ma∣dam, if to rectify his judgement, wee pick'd all the errours of his braine; First, opening the Pericranion, then take out the cerebrum; wash it in Albo vino, till it be throughy clens'd; and then—

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Pox o' your Albo vino, and his cerebrum taking out, that were a way to kill him. Wee must not be guily of the death of a Dogleach, but have him purg'd a safer way.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: How? Proceed.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P:
We will fill his belly full of Whey, or Butter∣milke, put him naked to a Hogs-head, then put into
the same an hundred broken Urinalls, then close up the Vessell and roll your Garden with it.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: I trust they cannot meane any such mischiefe.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: Hearke yee Gentlemen. Do you heare?

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Yes Madam, tis a Sowgelder.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: Fetch in that Minister of Justice.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Who Madam? the Sowgelder?

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Wee'l make a Doctor guelder of him tho', and my Lady be so minded.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: That will be sport indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: But will you see the execution Madam?

LG.L: Why not as well as other women have
Seene the dissections of Anotamies,
And executed men rip'd up and quarter'd?
This spectacle will be comicall to those.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: They dare not doe the thing they would have me feare.

LG.L: Now Doctor you look heavily methinks,
You shall be lighter by two stone presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: You will not murder me?

LG.L: Stirre not; nor make least noyse
As you hope ever to be heard agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: I would I could pray now to any purpose.

LG.L: I have brought him. The rarest fellow Madam,
And doe you thanke your fortune in him Doctor,
For he can sing a charme (he sayes) shall make
You feele no paine in your libbing or after it:
No Tooth-drawer, or Corne-cutter did ever worke
With so little feeling to a Patient.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: Sing then, he shall not suffer without a Song.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: What must he be stript now; or will letting down his breeches be enough?

LG.L: You dare not use this violence upon me
More rude then rage of Prentices.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Doctor it is decreed.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: You cannot answer it.

LG.L: Better by Law then you can the intent Guelder whets his knife and all in preparati∣on, Linnen, Bason, &c.
Of Rape upon the Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: That was not to have beene my act, nor was it done.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: When this is done wee'l talke w' ye, come lay him crosse this Table. Hold each of you a Leg of him, and hold you your peace Dodipoll. And for his armes let me alone, do you work Guelder.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: Hold, I have a secret to deliver to my Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: You shall be deliver'd of your secrets presently.

LG.L: If I tell her not that shall give her pardon
Then let me suffer. Heare me sweet Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: Forbeare him, let him down.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Sweet sayst? Thou art not i'le be sworne.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: Well sir your weighty secret now to save your trifles.

SP.SPEAKER: Doc.
SP.P: In private I beseech you Madam: for I dare but whisper't.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: You shall allow me so much warinesse as to have one at least to be my Guard, and witnesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Doc.
SP.P: This Gentleman then Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: We are shut out of councell.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: No matter. I list not be no nearer him: no more wou'd my cozen had he my nose. But where's Mr. Dainty and your finicall Mistris Phil all this while tho'?

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: No matter, but I ha' sworn you know. Therefore I say no more, but I have sworn.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: VVhat a strange tale is this! I can't believe it.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P:
I doe, and did before suspect it: and fram'd this counterfet plot upon you, Doctor, to worke out the
discovery: would I ha' seene you guelt dee think? That would have renderd mee more brutish then the women Barbers. Looke sir this is no Guelder, but one of my house Musick. (Goe, your part is done—
And for th' affright you gave me, Doctor, I am even w' ye.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: The Devill fright him next for a spurging, skitter∣brooke. 'Twere good you would call to burne some perfumes Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: But for the secret you have told me i'le keepe it secret yet, I will keepe you so too; and from your Patient.
There's a new Docter come already Madam to the madman.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: From sir Andrew Mendicant?

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: His servant brought him.

SP.SPEAKER: Doc.
SP.P: I pray what Doctor is it?

LG.L: Ingage your selfe with no desire to know,
But, for the good you finde, fit thanks to owe;
So come with me, and come you Gentlemen.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Frederick in a Doctors habit, Gabriel with two swords under his cloake, Ferdinand upon a Bed bound, and held down by servants.

LG.L: HEape yet more Mountaines, Mountaines upon
Mountaines, Pindus on Ossa, Atlas on Olympus,
I'le carry that which carries Heaven, do you
But lay't upon me!
Forbeare you'l stifle him,
Take off the needlesse weight of your rude bodies;
Unbind him and stand off, to give him ayre.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P:
Sir though you are a Phisitian, I am no foole.
Take heede what you doe. Hee's more then six of us hold when his hot fit's upon him. He would now teare you to pieces should you let him loose.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.P: The danger then be mine. Let him sit up. Is not he civill now?

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P: I, for how long? do you note that Hercules eye there?

SP.SPEAKER: Fre.
SP.P: I charge you quit the roome.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P: Tis but to come agen when we are call'd.

LG.L: Be not within the hearing of a call,
Or if you chance to heare me, though I cry
Murder, I charge you come not at me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P: Tis but a Doctor out o' the way; and that's no losse while there are so many, the best cannot live by the worst.

LG.L: Keep the dore fast. You are much mist abroad sir,
And chiefly by the Ladies, who now want
The Court-ships, Banquets, and the costly presents
In which you wonted to abound to 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.P: Ha—

LG.L: Nay, nay, sit still sir. They say y'are mad;
Mad with conceit of being a favorite
Before your time, that is, before you had merit
More then a tumour of vaine-glory in you,
And in especiall care for your recovery
I am sent to administer unto you: but first
To let you blood.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.P: Ho! Murder, Murder, Murder.

LG.L: Are you so sensible already? do not stirre
Nor cry too loud. Dos the meere apprehension
Of blood-letting affright your madnesse? Then
Reason may come agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.P: The Battaile of Musteborough Field was a brave one.

SP.SPEAKER: Fre.
SP.P: O do you fly out agen?

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.P: Sings part of the old Song, and acts it madly.

SP.SPEAKER: Fre.
SP.P: This is pretty: but back from the purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Fre.
SP.P: Will you come to the point sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Fre.
SP.P: We but lose time in this sir: Though it be good testimony of your memory in an old Song. But do you know me?

LG.L: Not know my Soveraigne Lord? Curs'd be those
Knees, and hearts that fall not prostrate at his Feete.
This wild submission no way mittigates
My wrongs, or alters resolution in me
To Cure or Kill you quickly. Do you know me now sir?
Or have you known Charissa? do you start sir? Off his beard & gown.
There's signe of reason in you then: But bee't
By reason or by chance, that you awake
Out of your frantick slumber, to perceive me,
My cause and my Revenge is still the same,
Which I will prosecute according to
My certaine wrong, and not your doubtfull reason,
Since reasonlesse you layd those wrongs upon me
When you were counted wise, great, valiant, and what not
That cryes a Courtier up, and gives him power
To trample on his betters.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.P: Who talkes this mortall to? I am a spirit.

SP.SPEAKER: Fre.
SP.P: Sure I shall finde you flesh, and penetrable.

LG.L: I would but live to subdue the Pisidians,
And so to bring the Lydians under tribute—
You would but live t'abuse more credulous fathers
With courtly promises, and golden hopes
For your own lustfull ends upon their Daughters.
Thinke (if you can thinke now) upon Charissa.
Charissa who was mine, in faith and honour
Till you ignobly (which is damnably)
By a false promise with intent to whore her
Diverted her weake Father from the Match
To my eternall losse. Now whether you
Have wit or no wit to deny't, or stand to't,
Or whether you have one, or ten mens strength,
Or all, or none at all i'le fight or Kill you
Yet like a Gentleman, i'le call upon you Throw away his dags.
Give me the Swords. They are of equall length
Take you free choyce.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.P: Pish.

SP.SPEAKER: Fre.
SP.P: I cast that to you then. Hand it, or die a Madman.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.P: O, ho, ho, ho.—

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: All this sir to a Madam.

LG.L: I have a cause to be more mad then he,
And in that cause i'le fight.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: He knowes not what you tell him.

LG.L: I tell't the Devill in him then to divulge it
When I have dispossest him. I have further
Reason to kill him yet, to crosse your Master,
VVho has beg'd his Estate. Now fight or die a Mad∣man.
Hold Frederick hold. Thou hast indeed awak'd
Me to see thee and my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Hee's not so mad to fight yet I see that.

LG.L: I'm glad you are your selfe sir, I shall fight
Now upon honorable tearmes, and could
Suppose before your madnesse counterfeit.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.P: Yet hold. Has Mendicant beg'd me?

SP.SPEAKER: Fre.
SP.P: During your madnesse. VVhat should hinder him?

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.P: Put up thy Sword.

SP.SPEAKER: Fre.
SP.P: Upon no tearmes, and you alive.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.P: Not to obtaine Charissa?

SP.SPEAKER: Fre.
SP.P: As you Guest sir.

LG.L: It shall be by meanes if gold can win
Her Fathers grant.

SP.SPEAKER: Fre.
SP.P: That's most unquestionable.

LG.L: Not that I dare not fight, doe I urge this,
But that the other is your safer way.
Your gold's too light. I will accept of nothing
From you while you dare tell me you dare fight,
Perhaps you doubt of ods, goe forth. Nay I
VVill lock him out.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: You may: For I dare trust you while I go call the Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Fre.
SP.P: Now are you pleas'd, or dare you now to fight sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd
SP.P: I neither will nor dare fight in this cause:

LG.L: This is a daring Courtier!
How durst you wind your selfe in so much danger?
And why take madnesse in you, to be bound,
And grapled with so rudely?
Keepe my councell,
And take Charissa.

SP.SPEAKER: Fre.
SP.P: Tis a faire condition.

LG.L: First for the wrong I did thee, noble youth
In my designe against Charissa's honour,
It is confess'd, repented; and her selfe
For satisfaction to be given to thee,
I'le fall upon thy Sword else, or be posted,
And Ballated with all disgrace.

SP.SPEAKER: Fre.
SP.P: VVell yet.

LG.L: And for my shew of madnesse; 'twas put on
For my revenge on this impetuous Lady
To coole these flames (as much of anger as
Dsire) with her disdaine, and tempting malice
Had rais'd within mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Fre.
SP.P: You would have ravish'd her.

LG.L: I rather thought, she like a cunning Lady
VVould have consented to a Madman, who
She might presume could not impeach her honor
By least detection: Monkeyes, Fooles, and Madmen,
That cannot blab, or must not be believ'd
Receave strange favours.
And on that presumption
You fain'd your madnesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.P: True.

LG.L: But rather then to faile,
With your bawd Doctors helpe you would ha' forc'd her:
And that's the councell you would have me keep
On your assurance of Charissa to me▪
That your proceeding in your madnesse here,
May yet finde meanes and opportunity
To exercise your violence.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.P: Suppose so.

LG.L: Thou art not worth my Killing now.
Justice will marke thee for the Hangmans Office:
Nor, were Charissa in thy gift, were shee,
In that, worth mine or any good acceptance,
And for your councell, had within there Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.P: Frederick—

LG.L: The Lady of the house! where are you?
VVill you be pleas'd to heare a secret Madam?
Strangely discover'd?
I doe not slight your act in the discovery,
But your imposture sir, and beastly practise
VVas before whisper'd to me by your Doctor
To save his Epididamies.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: O your pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: I am disgrac'd, undone.

LG.L: Tis in my power
To make you the perpetuall shame of Court;
And will assuredly doe't, if you comply not
VVith me to make this injur'd Gentlemans fortune
In his belov'd Charissa.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.P: Madam most readily, I have offer'd it.

LG.L: I have forecast the way and meanes already:
Which we must prosecute with art and speed.
Good ends oft times doe bad intents succeede.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.P: I'le be directed by you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fre.
SP.P: Noblest Lady.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: COme Sir, must I take you in hand agen?

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: My Lady will convery her Madman to sir Andrew Mendicants it seemes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Tell mee that I know not; and answer my questions.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Shee and the Doctor, and the tother Doctor's gone with him too.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Leave you by flim flams, and speake to the pur∣pose.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: You know I ha' sworne. Doe you not know I ha' sworne?

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: To live and die a beaten Asse; a coward hast thou not?

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: Prethee forbeare him: Hee's not worth thy anger.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Anger! Is every Schoole-master angry that gives Discipline with correction?

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Would he were at Pensans agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Didst not thou tell my Lady that I was a coward in my own Countrey, and Kick'd out of Cornewall?

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Comparatively I thinke I did in respect of Corine∣es, that wrastled and threw Giant after Giant over the cliffs into the Sea.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Pox o' your comparative lies; And didst not thou say that he here was pepper'd so full o' the what∣s callums, that his spittle would poyson a Dog or a Rat?

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: That was comparatively too in respect of a pure Virgin; a chrisome child or so.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: He never shall move me, I forgive him.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Meerly comparatively I speake it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Forgi' mee for swearing i'le make thee speak positively, or beat thee superlatively before I ha' done with thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: Gentlemen, my Lady—

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Hold a little. Didst thou not say this child here was a Pickpocket? and that he pickt thine of thy money, and thy watch, when he was singing betweene thy Leggs to day?

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: Who I a Pick-pocket?

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Forbeare good Lady it was comparatively.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: A pick pocket?

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: Forbeare and hear him Hercules.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: Lend me a sword i'le kill him, and heare him af∣terwards.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: Nay I must hold you then. How was hee comparatively your Pick-pocket?

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: That is as much as any man I know; That is I accuse nobody; that is all are as innocent as the child, and hee as the innocent unborne. And let that satisfy you.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: Live. I am satisfied. Now Gentlemen my Lady prayes you to follow her to sir Andrew Mendi∣cants.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: I know the businesse, 'Tis about our Revells.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Suffer a child to beat thee!

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: His cause was bad you know.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Incorrigible coward! Say now; art not thou thy selfe a pick-pocket, and a cut-purse? say.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Comparatively it may be said, I am to a Church∣warden, a Collector for the poore or such.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: The conclusion is, that if ever I heare thou men∣tionst my name agen in any sense whatsoever, i'le beat thee out of reason.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: In my good wishes, and prayers I may: Heaven forbid else.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Not in your prayers sir, shall you mention me, you were better never pray.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Heaven forbid I should then!

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: And make thine Oath good on that flie fellow that has taine away thy wench, or—

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: He has not tane her yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: You ha' not seene her or him these two houres; has not my Lady call'd too, and shee not to be found?

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: True, true: and if I be not reveng'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Do't then now, while thou art hot. Shee comes, here take, and keepe her while thou art hot and hast her.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Is she at your dispose sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Your Lady gave you me.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Or am in her gift?

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: You are in my possession, nor shall Lucifer dis∣possesse me of her.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: So valiant on a sodaine!

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Have I not cause?

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: You'l have me with all faults?

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Yes, and a match forever.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: How meanes shee by all faults?

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: A word shee alwayes uses in waggery.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: By all meanes take her from him. What! affraid of a coward?

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: You must do't or take the share, hee should ha' had a down-right beating. Forgi' me for swearing, hee's a veryer coward then tother.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: Hee will serve the betrer to flesh him. And do but note his tiranicall rage that is the vanquisher.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: You will on.

SP.SPEAKER: Dai.
SP.P: Sir shee is mine by promise.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Shee's mine by act and deed sir according to the flesh, let her deny't and she can.

SP.SPEAKER: Dai.
SP.P: That shall be try'd by Law.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: By Law of armes and hands it shall, take that, and let her goe.

SP.SPEAKER: Dai.
SP.P: Beare witnesse Gentlemen he struck me.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: O pittifull Picture-drawer!

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Will you not draw? I will then.

SP.SPEAKER: Dai.
SP.P: What would you have sir? If shee be yours take her.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: That's not enough, I will make thee fight, what blindnesse have I liv'd in! I would not but be valiant to be Cesar.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: O brave Cit, O brave Cit.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Why dost not draw thou fellow thou?

SP.SPEAKER: Dai.
SP.P: Shee's his he sayes; and she denies it not, shall I fight against him for his own?

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: I'le make thee fight, or cut thee into pieces.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: He turnes your words over to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: VVhy dost thou weare a sword? onely to hurt mens feet that Kick thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: Doe you observe? Nay thou art too severe.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Pray hold your peace, i'le jowle your heads together and so beat on with tother else.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Forgi' me for swearing. Hee'l beat's all anon.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: VVhy dost thou weare a Sword I say?

SP.SPEAKER: Dai.
SP.P: Some other time sir, and in fitter place.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Sirrah you lie, strike me for that, or I will beat thee abominably.

SP.SPEAKER: Dai.
SP.P: You see this Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: And I see't too, was ever poor wench so couzend in a man?

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: The wench thou lov'st and doat'st on is a whore.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: How's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: No, no, That was not right, your father was a cuckold tho', and you the sonne of a whore.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Good, I shall love this fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Dai.
SP.P: I can take all this upon account.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: You count all this is true then. Incorrigible cow∣ard! what was the last vile name you call'd mee Mr. Swain-wit? O I remember, sirrah thou art a Pick∣pocket and a Cut-purse; And gi' me my money agen, and him his or I will cut thy throat.

SP.SPEAKER: Dai.
SP.P: I am discover'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Doe you answer nothing, doe you deurr upon't?

SP.SPEAKER: Dai.
SP.P: Hold sir I pray; Gentlemen so you will grant me pardon, and forbeare the Law i'le answer you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou. Sw.
SP.P: Agreed, agreed.

SP.SPEAKER: Dai.
SP.P: It is confess'd: I am a Cut-purse.

LG.L: Comparatively or positively doe you speake?
Speake positively, or I will beat thee superlatively.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Forgi' me for swearing a brave Boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Dai.
SP.P: Here is your VVatch, and Money; And here is yours. Now as you are Gentlemen use no extremity.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: Beyond all expectation!

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: All thought.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Miraculous! O the effects of valour!

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Was ever woman so mistaken o' both sides?

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: But dost thou thinke thou art valiant for all this tho'?

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: You were best try; or you, or both, or come all three.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: I sweare thou shalt have it to keepe up while thou art up.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Is this your picture-drawing? are you the Kings Picture-drawer? A neat denomination for a Cut-purse, that drawes the Kings Pictures out of men Pockets.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: Come sir, come in with us.

SP.SPEAKER: Dai.
SP.P: Pray use me Kindly Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Yes, wee will use you in your kind sir.

DIV3.STAGE: Takes Phil by the hand. Exeunt Omnes.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Mendicant, a Letter in his hand.

LG.L: THis is the day of my felicity,
And is the same with that the Poet Sings
Is better then an Age. Come forth Charissa, Enter Charissa.
Now you appeare my comfort; and I can
No lesse then thanke thy sweet obedience
That hast comply'd with my directions,
Bride-like and glorious to meet a fortune,
So great as shall beget the present envy
Of all the Virgin Ladies of the Court,
And a posterity, that through all ages,
Shall praise and magnify thy act.
Your acceptation of my duty sir
Is all that I can glory in.
How are we bound unto this noble Lady▪
That sent us our instructions.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Sure I am. If this be a true Coppy.

LG.L: Let Musick in her soft but sweetest notes
Usher their welcome, whilst unto my thoughts Musick
The lowdest harmony resounds my triumph. Enter Doctor, and Fred. in Doctors habit, Strange, Priest, Ferd. in the chair as before borne by servants, Fab. as one of the servants.
Madam most welcome.
In fewest and the softest words sir Andrew.
(He sleepes) and let him gently be convey'd
Onely with those about him to his Chamber.
Charissa, go: be you his conduct, softly, softly.
I see y'ave brought a Priest Madam.
By all best reason,
For when we found he us'd Charissa's Name,
When he was calme and gentle, calling still
Charissa! where's Charissa? a good space
Before he slept, and being then demanded
What would he with Charissa? He most readily
Reply'd, Fetch me Charissa and a Priest.
The Doctors in their judgements (unto which
My full opinion assented) might
Foresee, that in removing him, where she
Might be his immediat object, when he wakes,
That fresher flames to instant marriage
Would then arise.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: Incomparably judicious Madam.

LG.L: Yet not without your leave would I attempt it:
Without your leave, knowing your watchfull care
Over your Daughter.
And that care of mine
Was (Madam) by your favour
Principall motive to this great effect.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: Take all unto your selfe, I am content.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: I'd faine steale in and watch th' event of things.

LG.L: But have you heard sir Andrew the mischance
Of the unfortunate Lover, distracted Frederick?

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: How! what of him?

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: H'has made himselfe away.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: Ist possible?

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: (Hee has by this time, or the Priest is tongue∣ty'd▪)

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: He has left no estate worth begging, that's the worst of'.
My joyes come flowing no me—yet I would see.

LG.L: And heare me good Sir Andrew, for the Love
I bring to ad unto your joyes: for I
Foreseeing the event of this nights happinesse
Have warn'd some friends to follow me with Revells
To celebrate the Marriage of your fortunes.
See they are come. Pray entertaine 'em sir.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Court. Swayn. Cit-wit, Dainty, Phil. Boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: The Gallants that were to day so merry with mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: The same: but very harmelesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: All but one sir. Did you not lose your purse to day?

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: What's the meaning?

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: Sw. Wee'l tell you Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: My purse? (I mist it at my Lady Strangeloves.)

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: This Picture-drawer drew it, and has drawne more of the Kings-pictures then all the Limners in the Towne. Restore it sirrah.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: I will not take it, 'twas my nelect that lost it, not he that stole it. This is my day of fortune; it comes home to me; more then I dare receive. O my joyes, let me be able to containe you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Ha' you another purse to lose?

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: I have a purse; which if I lose, i'le blame my selfe, none else.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Let him but come so neare you as to aske forgive∣nesse for the last, and if he doe not take the next, though it be six fadome deepe i' your pocket i'le hang for him when his time comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: I'le watch his fingers for that.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: Observe good Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Dai.
SP.P: Sir at your feet I beg your pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: It needs not, prithee rise.

LG.L: Never, till you pronounce that happy word
I pardon thee: or let me have some token
Of sweet assurance that I am forgiven
Which I beseech you—I beseech you grant.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: In sooth thou hast it. Heaven pardon thee as I doe.

SP.SPEAKER: Dai.
SP.P: I have it sir indeed, and as your gift i'le keepe it, promising before all these witnesses, i'le never venter for another.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: Fore me an expert fellow; Pitty he should be hang'd before we have more of his breed.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Did not I tell you sir? And these are but his short armes; i'le undertake, when he makes a long arme, he shall take a purse twelve skore off.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: I doe not like Thieves handsell though, This may presage some greater losse at hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Now Gentlemen you know your taske, be expediti∣ous in't.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: I have cast the designe for't already Madam. My inventions are all flame and spirit. But you can expect no great matter to be done extempore or in six minutes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: What matter ist so wee skip up and downe? our friend Jack Dainty here, Mr. Cut-purse dances daintily tho'.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: And Mr. Cit-wit, you have worthily wonne my woman sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: I have her Madam, she is mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: I'le make her worth a thousand pound to you, besides all she has of her own.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Her faults and all Madam, we are agreed o' that.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Suppose this Boy be mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: I would he were else, that I might have him under lawfull correction, and the cause o' my side: for he beat me not long since.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: And you be my father, and do not make much of me and give me fine things, i'le beat you agen so I will; and my mother shall helpe me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Agree'd Billy, agreed Philly. Never was man so sodainly, so rich; Nay never looke Gentlemen, shee is mine, and hee's mine own, I am sure I ha' got him now; And all faults are salv'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Her word in waggery is made good in earnest now tho'.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: To your busines Gentlemen; if you have a short speech or two, the boy's a prety Actor; and his mother can play▪ her part; women-Actors now grow in request. Sir Andrew! melancholly?

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: I was thinking on the omen of my purse.

DIV3.STAGE: Court draws his Tables and retires to Phil, writes & some∣times shewes her.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: Fear no further mishap sir; tis ominous to feare.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: Pray let's go in and see how things proceed.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.

LG.L: Pray give mee leave to make the first discovery;
Walke downe into the Garden, i'le come to you;
And here are some would speak with you.

SP.P: 1. Into the Garden, good, let's follow him.
2. Tis not the repulse he gave us in the morning shall quit him of us.
1. No now his superintendent's turn'd away, wee'l once more fill his head with millions.

SP.SPEAKER: Dai.
SP.P: I'le make the Dance, and give you all the footing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Stand further off o' my Pocket tho'.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: No matter if we lose any thing, and he within ten miles of us i'le make him answer't.

SP.SPEAKER: Dai.
SP.P: I want a fift man, I would have an od.

SP.SPEAKER: Doc.
SP.P: The Marriage is perform'd. The Priest has done his office—

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Doctor can you dance?

SP.SPEAKER: Doc.
SP.P: And sing too, I ha' forgot much else.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: I'le speak the Speech: Ha' not I forgot my Actors tone tro? I shal remember't, I could have acted'em all ore.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy:
SP.P: I can speak a Speech too Mother, must I call you Mother now?

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: I my Boy, now I dare vouch thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Doc.
SP.P: What think you of this tune sir for your dance? Tay dee▪ dee, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Dai.
