SP.P: I'le borow a Violl and take it of you instantly.
Pray sir, is sir Andrew Mendicant i'the house.

LG.L: Umh— He writes in his tables sometimes scratch∣ing his head, as pumping his Muse.
Is he within sir, can you tell? He's too busie it seemes.
Can you tell me sir I pray, if sir Andrew be within? To Cit-wit as he mov'd toward him, Cit-wit Dances looking on his Feete, &c.
Very strange! among what Nati∣on am I arriv'd?
Here's one in civill habit sure will answer me,
Sir may I be inform'd by you? saw you sir Andrew?

DIV3.STAGE: The Doctor stretches his Throat in the Tune.

LG.L: They are no Christians sure.
Sir may I be inform'd by you? To Swayn. He whistels & Dances Sellingers round, or the like.
Blesse me; the people are bewitch'd. Enter Dainty.
Do you belong to the house sir? To Dainty, he fidls to him & the 4 dancing & sing∣ing practise about him.
I hope for curtesie here Lady wil
you be pleas'd—

DIV3.STAGE: To Phil. she speaks in a vile tone like a Player.

LG.L: O by no meanes, we must speake Charon faire,
O hee'l not waft us o're the Stigian Floud,
Then must we have a sop for Cerberus
To stop his yawning Chaps; Let me alone
To be your Convoy to Elizium.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: This is most heathenish of all.

DIV3.STAGE: Dainty playes softly & Doctor with him aside.

LG.L: I'le pass that snarling triple-headed Cur
Which keeps the pallace-gate of Pluto's Court,
And guide you safe through pitchy Acheron.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: What Woman Monster's this? Sweete young Gentleman, let me aske you a question.

LG.L: Grim death, why rather didst thou not approach
My younger dayes; before I knew thy feares?
Thy paines are multiplied by our yeares.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: All Lunatick? or Gentlemen, do you want leasure O civility to answer me?

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Ha' you done the speeches Mr. Court wit?

LG.L: I have already from the forked top
Of high Parnassus fetcht 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: And shall my wife and Billi boy speake 'em?

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: As i'le instruct you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: You write admirably I confesse; But you have a ill tone to instruct in; I'le read to 'em my selfe, you give your words no grace.

SP.SPEAKER: Doc.
SP.P: You have the tune right, will you instruct the Musick men?

SP.SPEAKER: Dai.
SP.P: And you all in the Dance imediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: But shall we have no silken things, no whim wham To Dance in tho'.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Perhaps the Bride can furnish us.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: With some of her old Petticotes, can she?

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: No, no my Lady has tane care for all.

SP.SPEAKER: Dai.
SP.P: Come, come away to practise, and be ready.

LG.L: Never was I in such a Wildernesse. Om. Fidling, Footing, Singing, Acting, &c.
But my revenge upon Sir Mendicant
Shall answer all my patience, in the Jeere
I meane to put upon him.
I will possesse him with a braine-trick, now,
A meere invention of mine own (wherein
Heaven pardon me for lying) shall so nettle him.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: Goe back and be not seene till I come to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: Hee's come. Ha' you heard the newes sir Andrew?

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: What sir Raphael?

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: That Ferdinand's restor'd to's wits.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: I am glad on'.

LG.L: Do you take the losse of his estate so mildly
Which might ha' bin your own?

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: I hope you thinke mee a Christian sir, but how should he arrive at such a sodaine knowledge of it, if it be so? I will pretend tis true, yes sir, he is in's wits.

LG.L: I thought I had ly'd when I did prophesie:
But sir my Nephew Fredrick—

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: Has made himselfe away, I heard o' that too.

LG.L: (I hope not so) yet there's another accident
Of which you have not heard, may touch you nearer,
And that indeed's my businesse, you sir, furiously
Wounded your Man to day.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: Not dangerously I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: Flatter not so your selfe; Hee's on the point of dying.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: How!

LG.L: Nor be too much dejected,
His life you may get off for (as 'twas done
In heat of blood) marry sir your estate
(You'l pardon me) is beg'd; my selfe has don't,
And therein, beg'd the Begger.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: Ha!

LG.L: Take not too deepe a sense of it: For if you'l yeild
That Frederick yet shall have it with your Daughter,
I will remit the Estate.
O is it so?
Do you move this for a dead man?

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: No, he lives.

SP.SPEAKER: Men:
SP.P: Do you practise on me? Madam where are

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Strange. Ferd. Fred. Charissa. Gabriel behind.

LG.L: Here sir, and am become your Usher to such guests you?
As you must bid most welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: She here! i'm then agen confounded.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: Nay sir Raphael, I potest we will be friends notwithstanding I have outstript you in your plot of matching your Nephew Frederick, here to his love Charissa.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: But is it so?—

LG.L: It is, in which I hope sir you are not offended,
Who gave me leave by any opportunity
To take her, I broke no locks nor walls for her.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: I beg your pardon, and your blessing sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: And is it so with you sir Ferdinand?

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.P: It is, and sir in testimony of my recovery, I make demand of my estate: of which you thought your selfe possest.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: What hopes am I fallen from? and what misery fallen into; when the little I have is beg'd for Man∣slaughter!

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: I quit you of that sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: How couldst thou deale so with me?

LG.L: To shew my gratitude.
You overpaid me for all my former services,
For which I justly thought I ought you this.
Nor thinke your Daughter undervalued sir,
Three thousand pound I give him to augment
Her fortune in him.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: Dreames, dreames, All these are waking Dreames.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.P: All reall truth sir, whither flie you from us?

LG.L: Am I of all defeated; and by all
Abus'd and mock'd? More roome there: let me goe.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.P: You mistake strangely.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: Harke! the Revellers.

LG.L: That come to celebrate your joyes, which wilfully
You will not apprehend.
Tis all but shew, Let go, and I will do
Something shall ad to your delight imediatly.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: Let him goe and weare ou his fit by him∣selfe.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Boy, and Philomel, as Cupid and Venus.

LG.L: Venus and Cupid, my Mother and I—
Helpe me.—I have it now.
Venus and Cupid; my Mother and I
Helpe me agen▪ Noe, no, no.
Venus and Cupid; my Mother and I,
Let me alone.
Venus and Cupid my Mother and I.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: There's an Actor now!

SP.SPEAKER: Fre.
SP.P: How doubtfull of himselfe; and yet how perfect he was!

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: A selfe mistrust is a sure step to Knowledge.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: Sententious sir Raphel.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: Quarrells are ended Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.P: Come hither Cupid.

LG.L: From my Italian Mount I did espy
(For what is hidden from a Deity?)
How faintly Hymen did his Office here
Joyning two Lovers with the hand of feare;
Putting his Torch out for obscurity;
And made the Chamber (which belongs to me)
His Temple. But from hence let feare remove.
See here, the Champions for the Queene of Love.
Swain. Courage, sent from Mars; The Court. Muses kill.
From wise Apollo. And the God, which still
Inspires with subtilty, sly Mercury
Sends this his Dainty. Agent. Here's Cit-wit. Activity
From Doctor. Jupiter himselfe; And from her store
Of Spies, the Moon sends This to keepe the dore.
With Art of Action, now, make good the place,
In right of Love to give the Nuptialls Grace.

DIV3.STAGE: After they have Danc'd a while, Enter Projectors, breakes 'em off.

LG.L: Lay by your Jolity, forbeare your Sport,
And heare a story shall inforce your pitty.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.P: What black Tragedian's this?

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: Some Nuntius sent from Hell.

SP.SPEAKER: Ga.
SP.P: One of my Masters Minions, a Projector.

LG.L: You had a Master: But to all I speake.
Your practises have sunk him from the Comforts
Of all his hopes in fortune, to the Gulfe
Of deepe despaire; from whence he rose inflam'd
With wild distraction and phantastick fury.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.P: Hee's mad; is he?

SP.SPEAKER: Pro.
SP.P: Mad, and has hang'd himselfe—

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Alas my Father.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: How! hang'd himselfe?

LG.L: All over sir, with draughts of Projects, Suits,
Petitions, Grants, and Pattents, such as were
The Studies and the Labours of his Life,
And so attir'd he thinks himselfe well arm'd
T'incounter all your scornes.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Mendicant attir'd all in Patents; A Wind∣mill on his head, and the other Projector.

LG.L: Roome here: a Hall for a Monopolist,
You, Common-wealths informers lead me on.
Bring me before the great Assembly. See,
Fathers Conscript, I present all I have
For you to cancell.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Here's a brave shew, and out-shines our de∣vise.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: This is a Patent for the taking of poor John and Barrell-cod alive, and so to preserve 'em in salt-water for the benefit of the Fishmongers.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: There's salt in this.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: I this has some savour in'.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: This is a fresh one sir, For the catching, preser∣vation, and transportation of Butter-flies: whereby they may become a native commodity.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: That's a subtle one.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: This is for profits out of all the Common-Cryes i' th' City, As of—Oysters—Codlings—wood to cleave, Kitching stuffe, and the thousand more, even to the Matches for your Tinder-box, and all Forrainers to pay double; And a Fee out of the Link-boyes profits. But no cries to escape. Tis for a peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Dai.
SP.P: What if some should cry Murder, murder?

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Or Theeves, theeves?

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: Or Fire, fire?

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Or women cry out five Loves a penny?

LG.L: All all should pay. But I submit
My selfe to your most honorable censure.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: What dos he take us for?

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Powers, Powers; A lower house at least.

SP.SPEAKER: Men.
SP.P: And all my patents to be conceal'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Our Projects would not take with you, wee'l take yours tho'.

SP.SPEAKER: Dai.
SP.P: He shall dance out of 'em: Musick! Play out our Dance, we will disobe you presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Yes, and dismantle his Projectors too.

DIV3.STAGE: They all Dance. In the Dance they pull off his Patents; And the Projectors Clokes, who appeare all ragged. At the end of the Dance the Projectors thrust forth.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.P: An excellent Morrall! The Projects are all can∣cel'd, and the Projectors turnd out o' dores.

LG.L: True Gallants, and now I am my selfe agen,
I saw th'event of all with good esteeme.
And would as well as you a Madman seeme,
And now my blessings on your Son and Daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: This Bride, Dame Venus here, cooles all this while tho'.

SP.SPEAKER: Dai.
SP.P: By Mr: Bride-groomes leave, i'le stirre her blood a little for the good meaning shee had towards me.

LG.L: You may doe so. He dare's not pick her pocket,
And for her Maidenhead I dare trust him tho' he should
Dance quite out of sight with her.

DIV3.STAGE: While they Dance the rest confer.

SP.SPEAKER: Ra.
SP.P: 'Tis well: And all are friends.

LG.L: You have my potestation: and in that,
Madam, my faith before these noble friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: Upon those honourable tearmes sir Ferdinando I will be yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Cit.
SP.P: Sheel' have him, it seemes at last.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: Shee's a wise widdow by': for sure enough, she saw something in his mad naked fit, when hee put her to't, to choose a husband by, wo' not out of her thought yet.
What is there more to say now Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: You question well.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: But to Supper and to bed?

SP.SPEAKER: Str.
SP.P: You consider well.

SP.SPEAKER: Sw.
SP.P: We have had other pastime enough.

LG.L: You reason well, Would all were pleas'd as well
T' absolve that doubt, to those we must appeale.
LAdyes, your suffrages I chiefly crave
For th'humble Poet. Tis in you to save
Him, from the rigorous censure of the rest▪
May you give grace as y'are with Beauty blest.
True: Hee's no dandling on a Courtly lap,
Yet may obtaine a smile, if not a clap.
I'm at the Cavaliers. Heroick spirits,
That know both to reward, and atchieve merits,
Do, like the Sun-beames, vertuously dispense
Ʋpon the lowest growths their influence,
As well as on the lofty: our Poet so
By your Phebean favours hopes to grow.
And now you generous spirits of the City
That are no lesse in money then braine wity,
My selfe, my Bride, and pretty Bride boy too,
Our Poet for a Boun preferres to you.
And though you tast of no such Bride-ale Cup,
He hopes y' allow the Match to be clapt up.
And, if this Play be naught (yes so he said)
That I should gi' yee my Mother for a Mayd.

SP.SPEAKER: Swa.
SP.P:
And why you now? or you? or you? I'le speak enough for you all, you now would tell the Audients they should not feare to throng hither the next day: for you wil secure their Purses cut-free, and their pockts pick-free. Tis much for you to do tho'. And you would say that all
your projects are put down, and you'l take up no new: but what shall be (spectators) to please you. And you Poetick part induces you, t'appologize now for the Poet too, as they ha' done already, you to the Ladies, you to the Cavaliers and Gentry; you to the City friend, and all for the Poet, Poet, Poet, when alls but begging tho. I'le speak to 'em all, and to my Countrey folkes too if here be any o'em: and yet not beg for the Poet tho', why should we? has not he money for his doings? and the best price too? because we would ha' the best: And if it be not, why so? The Poet has shewd his wit and we our man∣ners. But to stand beg, beg for reputation for one that has no countenance to carry it, and must ha' money is such a Pastime!—If it were for one of the great and curious Poets that give these Playes as the Prologue said, and mo∣ney too, to have 'em acted; For them, indeed, we are bound to ply for an applause. Because they look for no∣thing else, and scorn to beg for themselves. But then you'l say those Playes are not given to you; you pay as much for your seats at them as at these, though you sit nere the merrier, nor rise the wiser, they are so above common understanding; and tho' you see for your love you will judge for your money, why so for that too, you may. But take heed you displease not the Ladies tho' who are their partiall judges, being brib'd by flattering verses to commend their Playes; for whose faire cause, and by their powerfull voyces to be cry'd up wits o' Court, the right worshipfull Poets boast to have made those enter∣ludes, when for ought you know they bought 'em of Uni∣versitie Scholars tho', and onely shew their own wits in owning other mens; and that but as they are like neither. As thus, do you like that Song? yes▪ I made it. Is that Scene or that Jest good? Yes, Twas mine; and then if all be good 'twas all mine. There's wit in that now. But this small Poet vents none but his own, and his by whose care
and directions this Stage is govern'd, who has for many yeares both in his fathers dayes, and since directed Poets to write & Players to speak, till he traind up these youths here to what they are now. I some of 'em from before they were able to say a grace of two lines long to have more parts in their pates then would fill so many Dry∣fats. And to be serious with you, if after all this, by the venemous practise of some, who study nothing more then his destruction, he should faile us, both Poets and Players would be at losse in Reputation. But this is from our Poet agen, who tels you plainly all the helps he has or desires; And let me tell you he has made prety merry Jigges that ha' pleas'd a many. As (le'me see) th' Anti∣podes, and (oh I shall never forget) Tom Hoyden o' Tanton Deans. Hee'l bring him hither very shortly in a new Motion, and in a new paire o' slops and new nether stocks as briske as a Body-lowse in a new Pasture.

LG.L: Meane while, if you like this, or not, why so?
You may be pleas' to clap at parting tho'.

DIV1.P: THE CITY WIT, OR, The VVoman wears the BREECHES.
LONDON, Printed by T. R. for Richard Marriot, and Thomas Dring, and are to be sold at their Shops in Fleet-street, 1653.

DIV1.HEAD: The Prologue.

OPENER.SALUTE: Quot quot adestis, salvete, salvetote Gentlemen,

DIV1.P:
YOu see I come unarm'd among you, sine Virga aut Ferula, without Rod or Fe∣rular, which are the Pedants weapons. Id est, that is to say, I come not hi∣ther to be an Instructor to any of you, that were Aquilam volare docere, aut Delphi∣num natare, to teach the Ape, well learned as my selfe. Nor came I to instruct the Comedians. That were for me to be Asinus inter simias, the fool o'the Company: I dare not undertake them. I am no Paedagogus nor Hypodidascalus here. I approach not hither ad erudiendum, nec ad Corrigendum. Nay I have given my Schollars leave to play, to get a Vacuum for my selfe to day, to Act a particle here in a Play; an Actor being wanting that could beare it with port and state enough. A Pedant is not easily imitated. Therefore in person, I for your delight have
left my Schoole to tread the Stage. Pray Jove the terror of my brow spoile not your mirth, for you can∣not forget the fury of a Tutor, when you have layne under the blazing Comet of his wrath, with quaeso Praeceptor te precor da—&c. But, let feare passe, nothing but mirth's intended.
But I had forgot my selfe, A Prologue should be in Ryhme, &c. therefore I will begin agen.

LG.L: Kind Gentlemen, and men of gentle kinde,
There is in that a figure, as you'll finde,
Because weeltake your eares as 'twere in Ropes,
Ile nothing speak but figures, strayns & tropes.
The Schoolemaster that never yet besought yee,
Is now become a suitor, that you'll sit,
And exercise your Judgement with your wit,
On this our Comedy, which in bold Phrase,
The Author sayes has past with good applause
In former times. For it was written, when
It bore just Judgement, and the seal of Ben.
Some in this round may have both seen't, and heard,
Ere I, that beare its title, wore a Beard.
My sute is therefore that you will not looke,
To find more in the Title then the Booke.
My part the Pedant, though it seem a Columne
Is but a Page, compar'd to the whole volume.
What bulk have I to bear a Scene to passe,
But by your favours multiplying Glasse.
In nova fert Animus, then Ile do my best
To gaine your Plaudite among the rest.
So with the salutation I first brought yee,

LIST.ITEM: CRasy, a young Citizen, falling into decay.

Crack, a Boy that sings.
two keeping Women.
Isabell
Jone

DIV1.HEAD: The City VVit. OR, The woman wears the Breeches.

DIV3.HEAD: Scene I.
DIV3.STAGE: A Dinner carryed over the Stage in cove∣red Dishes. Exeunt.
A Table set forth with em∣pty Mo∣ny-bags, Bills, Bonds, & Bookes of accompts, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Jer.
SP.P: Will you not go in and dine, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: No: I am of other dyet to day.

SP.SPEAKER: Jer.
SP.P: The whole company expects you.

LG.L: May they sit merry with their cheer,
while I feed on this hard meat. And wait
you within: I shall not change a trencher.

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.P: Alas my good Master.

LG.L: Here are the nests, but all the He takes up the bags.
Birds are flown.
How easie a thing it is to be undone,
When credulous Man will trust his 'state to others!
Am I drawn dry? Not so much as the Lees left?
Nothing but empty Cask? have I no refuge
To fly to now? Yes, here, about a groats worth He takes up the bils & papers.
Of paper it was once. Would I had now
Greens groats-worth of wit for it. But 'twill serve
To light tobacco-pipes. Here (let me see)
Here is three hundred pound, two hundred here.
And here one hundred, and two hundred here;
Fifty; fifty; fifty; and one hundred here,
And here one hundred and fifty. Besides
A many parcells of small debts, which make
Two hundred more. I shall not live to tell it,
But put it up, and take it by the weight. He puts the Bills & Bonds into a Bag.
O me! how heavy 'tis! And, doubtless, so 'twould be
At some mans heart. It troubles me a little. Enter Jeremy.
Now what newes?
My mistriss, and your Mother Sir,
Intreats you to come to dinner.
These they are; My debts,
That strike me through. This bag will never pay
Any of these.

SP.SPEAKER: Jer.
SP.P: Sir, shall I say you'l come?

LG.L: How well it were, if any of my Creditors
Could once but dream that this were current mony!

SP.SPEAKER: Jer.
SP.P: What shall I say?

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Even what thou wilt, good Jeremy.

LG.L: Alas you know, this dinner was appointed
A friendly meeting for most of your Creditors,
And many of your Debtors.
But I hope
Few of the last appeare.
None but some priviledg'd Courtiers, that dare
Put in at all mens Tables. They're all set,
Your Creditors on one side, and your Debtors
On t'other; and do only stay for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: To feed on; do they? Goe. I will not come.

LG.L: I feare, Sir, you will overthrow the good
That was intended you. You know this meeting
Was for the Creditors to give longer day,
As they should find your Debtors to acknowledg
The summes they owe you. Sir I should be sorry
To see you sinck, or forc'd to hide your head,
That look'd as high, as any in the City.
Prithee go in. And if they seem to stay,
Pray 'em fall too; tell 'em I take this time
Only to order my Accompts, and that as soon
As they are full, and fit to talk, I'le come:
Good Jeremie goe.

SP.SPEAKER: Jer.
SP.P: Introth I pity him—

LG.L: A right good Boy thou art. I think on thee:
What must I do now? All I have is lost,
And what I have not, sought to be forc'd from me,
I must take nimble hold upon Occasion,
Or lie for ever in the Bankrupt ditch,
Where no man lends a hand to draw one out▪
I will leape over it, or fall bravely in't,
Scorning the Bridge of Baseness, Composition,
Which doth infect a City like the Plague,
And teach men Knavery, that were never born to't:
Whereby the Rope-deserving Rascall gains
Purple and Furrs, Trappings and golden Chaines.
Base Composition, baser far then Want,
Then Beggery, Imprisonment, Slavery:
I scorn thee, though thou lov'st a Trades-man dearly
And mak'st a Chandler Lord of thousands yearly.
I will have other ayd. How now! Againe?

SP.SPEAKER: Jer.
SP.P: O, Sir, you are undone.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Hast thou no newes, Jeremie?

SP.SPEAKER: Jer.
SP.P: Alas your Mother Sir—

LG.L: Why what of her?
Is there a Plate lost, or a 'Postle-spoon
A China Dish broke, or an ancient Glass,
And stain'd with Wine her Damasque table-cloath?
Or is the Salt faln towards her? What's the matter?
Her mischievous tongue has over-thrown the good
Was meant to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: What Good, good Jeremie?

LG.L: Your Creditors were on a resolution
To do you good, and madly she oppos'd it,
And with a vehement voyce proclaims you a Beggar;
Says, you have undone her Daughter; that no good
Is fit to be done for you: And such a storm
Of wicked breath—

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: She's drunk; Is she not, Jeremie?

LG.L: No Sir, 'tis nothing but her old disease,
The Tongue-ague, whose fit is now got up
To such a height, the Devil cannot lay it.
The learned School-master, Mr. Sarpego
Has conjur'd it by all his parts of speech,
His Tropes and Figures; and cannot be heard
I'th furious Tempest. All your Creditors
Are gone in Rage; will take their course, they say.
Some of your Debtors stay, I think, to laugh at her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: Now deafeness seize me. I disclaime my hea∣ring. I defie my audituall part. I renounce mine ears. Mistris Pyannet, a desperate Palsey is on thy lips, and an everlasting Feaver on thy Tongue?

LG.L: What raging Rout hath rent thy rest;
What Scold hath scutch'd thy skonce:

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.

LG.L: I'le breath it to thy bolder breast,
That askst me for the nonce.

SP.P: You understand or know, that here hath been a Feast made, to take up a ponderous difference be∣tween Master Sneakup your Father in Law, and your selfe Mr. Crasy; and between most of your Creditors and Debitors. Food hath been eaten; Wine drunck; Talke past; Breath spent; Labour lost: For why? Mi∣stris Pyannet your Mother in Law, Mr. Sneakups Wife (though shee will be call'd by none but her owne name) that woman of an eternall Tongue; that Creature of an everlasting noyse; whose per∣petuall talke is able to deafen a Miller; whose discourse is more tedious then a Justices Charge; Shee, that will out-scold ten carted Bawds, even when she is sober; and out-chat fifteen Midwives, though fourteen of them be halfe drunk: this Shee-thing hath burst all. Demosthenes himselfe would give her over. Therefore hopeless Sarpego is silent.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Pyannet, Sneakup, Sir Andrew Ticket, Rufflit, La. Ticket, Josina, Linsy-Wolsy.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P:
O, are you here Sir! You have spun a fair thred.
Here's much ado, and little help. We can make bolt nor shaft, find neither head nor foot in your business. My daughter and I may both curse the time, that ever we saw the eyes of thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Sir, you have the civill vertue of Patience in you. Dear Sir hear me.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: He sayes he heares thee, and is asham'd to see thee. Hast not undone our Daughter▪ spent her Porti∣on; deceiv'd our hopes; wasted thy fortunes; undone thy credite; prov'd Bankrupt?

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: All was but my kind heart in trusting, in tru∣sting, Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Pi.
SP.P: Kind heart! What should Citizens do with kind hearts; or trusting in any thing but God, and ready money?

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: What would you, dear Father, that I should do now?

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Marry depart in peace Sir. Vanish in silence Sir. I'le take my Daughter home Sir. She shall not beg with you Sir. No marry shalt thou not; no, 'deed Duck shalt thou not.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Be yet but pleased to answer me, good Sir. May not an honest man—

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P:
Honest man! Who the Devill wish'd thee to be an honest man? Here's my worshipfull Husband, Mr. Sneakup, that from a Grasier is come to be a Justice of Peace: And, what, as an honest man? Hee grew to be able to give nine hundred pound with my daughter; and, what, by honestie? Mr. Sneakup and I are come up to live i'th City, and here we have lyen these three years; and what? for honesty? Honesty! What should the City do with honesty; when 'tis enough to undoe a whole Corporation? Why are your Wares gumm'd; your Shops dark; your Prizes writ in strange Chara∣cters? what, for honesty? Honesty? why is hard waxe
call'd Merchants waxe; and is said seldome or never to be rip'd off, but it plucks the skin of a Lordship with it? what! for honesty? Now (mortified my Concupi∣scence!) Dost thou think, that our Neighbour, Master Linsy-Wolsie here, from the sonne of a Tripe-wife, and a Rope-maker, could aspire to be an Aldermans Depu∣ty; to be Worshipfull Mr. Linsie-Wolsie; Venerable Mr. Linsie-wolsie; to weare Sattin sleeves, & whip Beg∣gars? And, what? By honesty? Have we bought an Of∣fice, here, for our towardly and gracious son and heire here, young Mr. Sneakup—

SP.SPEAKER: Tob.
SP.P: Yes forsooth Mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: And made him a Courtier, in hope of his ho∣nesty? Nay, (once for all) Did we marry our Daugh∣ter, here, to thee; rack'd our Purses to pay Portion; left Country house-keeping to save charges, in hope either of thine, or her honesty? No, we look'd, that thy Ware-house should have eaten up Castles, and that for thy narrow Walke in a Jewellers shop, a whole Countrey should not have suffic'd thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: If my uncunning Disposition be my only vice, then Father—

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Nay, and thou hast been married three years to my Daughter, and hast not got her with Child yet! How do'st answer that? For a woman to be married to a fruitfull Fool, there is some bearing with him yet. (I know it by my self) but a dry barren Fool! How dost thou satisfie that?

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: It may be defect in your Daughter, as proba∣ble as in me.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: O impudent varlet! Defect in my Daughter? O horrible indignity! Defect in my Daughter? Nay, 'tis well known, before ever thou sawest her, there was no defect in my Daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P:
Well: If to be honest, be to be a fool, my utmost
Ambition is a Coxcomb. Sir, I crave your farewell.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Marry Sir, and have it with all his heart. My Husband is a man of few words, and hath committed his tongue to me: And I hope I shall use it to his Wor∣ship. Fare you well Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: Thanks for your cheer and full bounty of En∣tertainment, good Mr. Sneakup.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: He rather thanks you for your patience, and kind visitation, good Sir Andrew Ticket. Yes indeed forsooth does he.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Tic.
SP.P: I take my leave Sir, too.

SP.SPEAKER: Sneak.
SP.P: Good Madame—

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Uds so! ther's a trick! you must talk, must you? And your Wife in presence, must you? As if I could not have said, good Madame. Good Madame! Do you see how it becomes you?

SP.SPEAKER: La. Tic.
SP.P: Good Mistris Sneakup▪

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Good Madame, I beseech your Ladiship to ex∣cuse our deficiency of Entertainment. Though ou power be not to our wish, yet we wish that our Power were to your Worth, which merrits better service—

SP.SPEAKER: La. Tic.
SP.P: Pardon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Then our rudenesse—

SP.SPEAKER: La. Tic.
SP.P: You wrong your selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Can tender, or possibly expresse by—

SP.SPEAKER: La. Tic.
SP.P: I beseech you forsooth—

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Our best labour, or utmost devoire. Yes I pro∣test sweet Madame. I beseech you, as you passe by in Coach sometimes, vouchsafe to see me; and, if I come to Court, I will presume to visite your Ladiship, and your worthy Knight, Good Sir Andrew! And I pray you Madame, how does your Monckey, your Parrot, and Parraquitoes? I pray commend me to 'em, and to all your little ones. Fare you well, sweet Creature.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruff.
SP.P: Wee'll leave you to take private farewell of your Wife, Mr. Crasie.

SP.SPEAKER: Tob.
SP.P: Wee'l meet you at your Horse, brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Lov'd, my deare heart, my sweetest, my very being, will you needs take your journey? I shall fall before your return into a Consumption. If you die but conceive what your departure will bring upon me, I know (my sweet) nay I do know—but goe your ways; strike my finger into mine eye: 'Tis not the first true teare a married woman has shed.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Why you heare the noyse of that woman of Sound, your Mother. I must travell down, or not keep up. Yet—

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Nay, goe I beseech you; you shall never say, I undid you. Goe I pray: But never look to see me my owne woman again. How long will you stay forth?

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: A fortnight at the least; and a moneth at the most.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Well, a fortnight at the least. Never woman took a more heavy departure. Kisse me. Farewel. Kiss me againe. I pray does your Horse amble, or trot? Do not ride post as you come home, I pray. Kisse me once more. Farewell.
Hay hoe! How I do gape.

SP.SPEAKER: Bri.
SP.P: What's a clock Bridget.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Past three forsooth.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Tis past sleeping time then, Bridget.

SP.SPEAKER: Bri.
SP.P: Nothing is past to those, that have a mind and means.

LG.L: Thats true and tryed. Go lay my Pillow Bridget. Exit Brid.
Lord, what a thing a woman is in her Husbands ab∣sence!
Wast thou ever in love, Jeremy?

SP.SPEAKER: Jer.
SP.P: Who I forsooth? No forsooth.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: I forsooth, and no forsooth? then I perceive you are forsooth. But I advise you to take head, how you levell your Affection towards me: I am your Mi∣stris; And I hope you never heard of any Apprentice was so bold with his Mistris.

SP.SPEAKER: Jer.
SP.P: No indeed forsooth. I should be sorry there should be any such.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Nay, be not sorry neither Jeremy. Is thy Ma∣ster gone? Look. A pretty youth, this same Jeremy! And is come of a good Race. I have heard my Mother say, his Father was a Ferretter—

SP.SPEAKER: Jer.
SP.P: He is gone forsooth.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Come hither Jeremy. Dost thou see this Hand∣kerchief?

SP.SPEAKER: Jer.
SP.P: Yes forsooth.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: I vow'd this Handkerchief should never touch any bodies face, but such a one, as I would intreat to lie with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Jer.
SP.P: Indeed forsooth!

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Come hither Jeremy. There's a spot o'thy Cheek, let me wipe it off.

SP.SPEAKER: Jer.
SP.P: O Lord forsooth. I'le go wash it.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Heaven made this Boy of a very honest Appe∣tite, sober Ignorance, and modest Understanding. My old Grandmothers Latine is verified upon him; Ars non habet Inimicum praeter Ignorantem. Ignorance is womans greatest Enemy. Who's within? Bridget.

SP.SPEAKER: Bri.
SP.P: Here forsooth.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Go your wayes to Mistresse Parmisan, the Cheesmongers Wife in old Fishstreet, and commend me to her; and intreat her to pray Mistresse Collifloore the Hearb-woman in the Old Change, that she will de∣sire Mistris Piccadell in Bow-lane, in any hand to be∣seech the good old dry Nurse mother, Et cetera, shee knowes where, to provide me an honest, handsome, secret young man; that can write, and read written hand. Take your errand with you; that can write and read written hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Bri.
SP.P: I warrant you forsooth.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: So, now will I meditate, take a nap, and dreame out a few fancies.

DIV3.HEAD: Sene II.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Crasy, booted. Ticket, Rufflit, Tobias Sarpego, Linsy woolsy:

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: WEE take our leaves Mr. Crasy, and wish good Journey to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruff.
SP.P: Farewell good Mr. Crasy.

SP.SPEAKER: Tob.
SP.P: Adiue Brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: Iterum iterumque vale.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: Heartily Godbuy, good Mr. Crasy.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Nay but Gentlemen: A little of your patience you all know your own Debts, and my almost impu∣dent necessiries, satisfie me, that J may discharge o∣thers. Will you suffer me to sink under my Freenes? shall my goodnesse, and ready Pietie undoe me? Sir Andrew Ticket, you are a profest Courtier, and should have a ender sense of honor. This is your day of pay∣ment for two hundred pound.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: Blood of Bacchus, tis true, tis my day, what then? Dost take me for a Cittizen, that thou thinkest I'll keep my day? No, thou'st find that I am a Courtier, let my day keep me and 'twill. But dost heare? Come to the Court. J will not say what I will do for thee. But come to the Court. I ow the two hundred pounds: I'll not deny't, if thou ask seven years hence for't, fare∣well. I say no more, but come to the Court, and see if I will know thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: O, Sir, now you are in favour, you will know no body.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: True: tis just. Why should we, when we are in favour know any body; when, if we be in disgrace, no body will know us? Farewell honest Tradesman.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: That is Synonima for a fool. An ironicall E∣pithite, upon my Facunditie.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: O Master Sarpego! I know you will satisfie your own driblet of ten pound, I lent you out of my Purse.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: Diogenes Laertius on a certaine time, deman∣ding of Cornelius Tacitus an Areopagit of Syracusa; what was the most Commodious and expeditest me∣thod to kill the Itch, answered—

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Answer me my monyes I beseech you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P:
Peremptorily, Careo Supinis; I want money. I confesse, some driblets are in the Debet. But, me
thinks, that you being a Man of Wit, Braine, Forecast and Forehead, should not be so easie, (I will not say foolish, for that were a figure) as to lend a Philoso∣pher money, that cryes, when he is naked, Omnîa mea mecum porto. Well Sir, J shall ever live to wish, that your owne Lanthorne may be your direction; and that, where ever you travell, the Cornu copia of A∣bundance may accompany you. Yes sure shall I. Vive valeque.

SP.SPEAKER: Tob.
SP.P: Why look you Brother, It was thought, that I had a tender Pericranion; or, in direct Phrase, that I was an unthristy fool. Signior no: you shall now find, that I cannot only keep mine own, but other mens. It is rightly said, He that is poor in Appetite, may quickly be rich in Purse. Desire little; covet little; no not your own: And you shall have enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Enough?

SP.SPEAKER: Tob.
SP.P: Yes Brother, litle enough. I confesse I am your Debtor for the loane of some hundred Marks. Now you have need: who has not? you have need to have it. I have need to pay it. Here's need of all hands. But Brother, you shall be no looser by me. Purchase Wit; Get wit (look you) wit. And Brother, if you come to the Court, now my Mother and my Father have bought me an Office there, so you will bring my Sister with you, I will make the best shew of you that I can. It may chance to set you up againe, Brother; tis many an honest mans fortune, to rise by a good Wife. Farewell sweet Brother. Prithee grow rich againe; and weare good Cloaths, that we may keep our Ac∣quaintance still. Farewell, deare Brother. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Mr. Rufflit—

SP.SPEAKER: Ruff.
SP.P: VVhat, does thy fist gape for mony from me?

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: I hope it is not the fashion, for a Gallant of fashion, to break for so small a Portion as the summe of an hundred Angells.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruff.
SP.P: For a Gallant of fashion to break, for a Gal∣lant of fashion? Dost thou know what a Gallant of fashion is? I'll tell thee. It is a thing that but once in three Moneths has money in his Purse; A creature made up of Promise and Protestation: A thing that foules other mens Napkins: towseth other Mens Sheets, flatters all he feares, contemns all he needs not, sterves all that serve him, and undoes all that trust him. Dost ask me mony, as I am a Gallant of fashion, I do thee Curtesie, I beat thee not.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: I lent it you on your single word.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruff.
SP.P: Tis pittie but thou shouldest loose thy Free∣dom for it: you Tradesmen have a good Order in your Citty, Not to lend a Gentleman money without a Cittizen bound with him: But you forsooth scorne Orders! By this light, tis pitty thou loosest not thy Freedome for it. VVell, when I am flush, thou shalt feel from mee, Farewell. Prithee learne to have some witt. A handsome streight young fellow, grown into a pretty Bear, with a proper bodyed VVoman to his VVife, and cannot beare a Braine! Farewell. Dost heare? Be rul'd by me, Get money, do, Get money and keep it; wouldst thrive? Be rather a knave then a Fool. How much dost say I ow thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Fifty pound.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruff.
SP.P: Thou art in my Debt. I have given the Coun∣sell worth threeskore, Dog-cheap, well I'll rent the odde mony.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: Strange mad fellows these same, Mr. Crasie, me thinks to deale withall.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P:
You are right Mr. Linsie wolsie▪ I would my Genius had directed me, to deale alwayes with such
honest neighbourly men as your selfe. I hope you will not deny me a Curtesie.

SP.SPEAKER: Lins.
SP.P: Not I, I protest, what is it?

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: You took once a Jewell of me, which you sold for thirty pound, for which I have your Bond for sixty, at your day of mariage. If you will now, because I want present money, give me but twenty pound, I'll acquit you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: My good friend Mr. Crasie, I have no tricks and Jerks to come over you, as the witty Gentleman had ere while: But I know a plaine bargaine is a plaine bargaine: and wit is never good till it be bought. If twentie pound will pleasure you, upon good security I will procure it you. A hundred if you please, do you mark Mr. Crasie? On good security. Otherwise you must pardon me, Mr. Crasie. I am a poore Tradesman Mr. Crasie, keep both a Linnen and a VVollen Drapers shop, Mr. Crasie, according to my name, Mr. Crasie, and would be loth to lend my money, Mr. Crasie, to be laught at among my Neighbours, Mr. Crasie, as you are Mr. Crasie. And so fare you wel, Mr. Crasie.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.

LG.L: Is this the end of unsuspicious Freenesse?
Are open hands of Chearfull Pietie,
A helpfull bounty, and most easie Goodnesse,
Rearded thus?
Is, to be honest, term'd to be a fool?
Respect it Heaven. Beare up still merry heart.
Droop not: But scorne the worlds unjust despising.

L.HI: Who through Goodnesse sinks, his fall's his Rising.

SP.P: O Master, Master, upon my knowledge, my Mistres is forced since your departure to be

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: What Jeremy?

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.P: Honest Sir. Get up your Debts as fast as you can abroad: For on my understanding (which great Iove knowes is but little) shee will take up more then your due at home easily.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Boy. Didst never observe at the Court gate, that the Lord was no sooner off from his Horse-back but the Lackey got up into the Saddle and rode home?

SP.SPEAKER: Jer.
SP.P: Yes Sir, tis common.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: I scorne not my Betters Fortune. And what is not my sinne, shall never be my shame.

SP.SPEAKER: Jer.
SP.P: Introth I was faine to make my selfe an Asse, or else I had been tempted to have been a knave.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Boy, thou art now my Prentice. From hence be free. Poverty shall serve it selfe. Yet do one thing for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Jer.
SP.P: If it be in the power of my poore Sconce.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: If ever it be in thy possible ability, wrong all Men, use thy wit, to abuse all things, that have but sence of wrong: For without mercie, all men have in∣jur'd thy mistrustles Master, Milk'd my thoughts from my heart, and money from my Purse, and, last, laught at my Credulity. Cheat, chosen, live by thy Wits: Tis most manly, therefore most noble. Horses get their living by their Backs, Oxen by their necks, Swine and Women by their Flesh, Only man by his Braine. In briefe be a knave and prosper: For honesty has beggerd me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ier.
SP.P: Farewell Master. And if I put tricks upon some of them, let the end of the Comedie demonstrate.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: I am resolv'd I will revenge. I never provok'd my braine yet. But now if I clap not fire in the tayles of some of these Samsons Foxes—seems my defect of Fortune want of wit? Noe.

LG.L: The sense of our slight sports confess'd shall have,
That any may be rich, will be a knave.

DIV3.HEAD: Scene I.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: EGregious and most great of Expectation, my right dignified and truly Ciceonian Pupill, now that I have brought you into the Amoene fields with my ready thankfullnesse for the loane of this ten pound, I commit you to the grace of Court.

SP.SPEAKER: Tob.
SP.P: I shall expect that money shortly. Care to send it; For I purchas'd my place at a rack'd recom∣pence.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: Your Sarpego is no slipperie Companion. You know I am to marry, and this money shall provide me Complements.
SP.Q: Sis bonus o faelixque tuis. I pede fausto.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Crasy like a lame Souldier.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Belov'd of Phoebus, Minion of the Muses, deare Water Bayley of Helicon, let it not be distast∣full to thy Divine eares, to receive the humble Petiti∣on of a poore Creature, made miserable by the policie of Providence. That thy rare and absolute Mufi∣cence might supply what fortune had lst defective: I kisse thy learned toes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: I tell thee, by the Axiomes of the Peripateticall Aristotle, thou art a Monster. My reward shall be therefore like thy selfe, monstrously lame. This is a figure in Eloquution call'd Apoxegesis.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: I am not fed with Figures Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: You are an idle vagabond, and lye in wait for the blood of the learned. Labour, and live.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Right eloquent and well-phrased Sir, my edu∣cation has been liberall. I sometimes fed my flock on horned Parnassus: But my wants forc'd me to my Sword.

DIV3.STAGE: He shews his blade halfe way.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: You did peradventure sip on the top of Science, Primoribus labijs, or so, but did not convert it in Suc∣cum & sanguinem.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: That I may ever remaine a true man—Extend.

The Sun, Moon and the seven Planets are my invoked witnesses, I should be grieved, that necessity should make me grow violent on so adored, adorned Gramma∣ticall Disciplinary—Be gracious in Contribution—Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: J will give thee an infinite treasure. Sis integer vitae, scelerisque purus. Vale poore Rogue.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Sir, this Sword can bite—But, J know you had rather give it freely out of your own Proclivitie.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: Yes I protest, as I am Erudite. Here dreadfull Mavortian, the poor price of a Dinner.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: If I might in modesty importune the poore price of a Supper too.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: I do speak it in the Optative Mood, I do wish it lay in the modell of my Fortune to give harbour to your shaken state, yet receive this with appeased clutch.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P:
If I might not seem audacious even to impu∣dence, I poore Freshman in Literature, would implore
of your well-salted, & best season'd vertue, some larger allowance to supply my defects of Rayment, Books, and other necessaries: which magnificence shall ever intitle you, my most bounteous Macaenas. Be induc'd to it Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar:
SP.P: Yes, yes, yes, that you may know how deare you are to me; Know this is more then usuall largesse—for non omnibus dormio—There's a Figure too.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: O yes Sir, I understand this Figure too very well. Now deare Mecenas, let me implore a Purse to inclose these Monyes in—Nay if you impart not with a chearfull forhead, Sir

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: Vae misero mihi! sweet Purse adieu. Iterum ite∣rumque vale.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: May you be importun'd to do it, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: You shall have it instantly. I will only deprome, or take out a little stuffing first.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Tis no matter. As it is, As it is, good Sir, as it is. Jle accept it as it is. Most fragrant-phrased Ma∣ster, suffer thy selfe o be intreated. Doe—

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: You have most powerfully perswaded: Take it.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Most exorbitantly bounteous Mecenas, you have given me all this, have you not?

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: Yes, yes, and you have taken all that, have you not?

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Yes, yes, but as your gift. Iove blesse thy browes, and make cleer thy Phisnomy. Vale. Your learned Worship stincks.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P:
Now Barbarisme, Incongruity, and false Orthography shame thee; The curse of Priscian take thee. All the parts of speech
defie thee. All the Interjections of sorrow, as Heu hei▪ of Shunning, as Apage; of Disdaining, as Hem vah; of Scorning, as Hui; of Exclaiming, as Proh Deum at∣que hominum fidem take thee. My deare Pupils lend∣ings hast thou lewdly lick'd away: And sorrowfull Sarpego is lick'd dry. There's a figure left yet! But ô thou Castalion Traytor, Pick-purse of Parnassus, and Hang-man of Helicon: Dives thirst in thy Throat; Ix∣ions wheel on thy back; Tantalus hunger in thy guts; and Sisyphus stone in thy Bladder.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: O fearfull curse! Well; I haye given my first pinch, and a little scratch'd my Goat-bearded Gram∣marian, that Broke jests on my uncunning easiness. But he with the rest shall feele, that modest Simplicity is not alwayes a defect of wit, but will: What my willing honesty hath seem'd to loose, my affected deceits shall recover. I'le rid 'em one after another, like Guts, till they shall stink worse then Jewes.

LG.L: And they shall find with most ashamed eyes,
The honest Breast lives only rich and wise.

SP.SPEAKER: JOs.
SP.P: Bridget.

SP.SPEAKER: Bri.
SP.P: Here forsooth.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Bridget, I say.

SP.SPEAKER: Bri.
SP.P: Here, Lady.

LG.L: That's comfortably spoken! Nay blush not:
We women can never have too much given us. And
Madame▪ Josina would sound well.

SP.SPEAKER: Bri.
SP.P: Yes indeed, Madame Josina Crasie.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: No; not Crasie; hang Crasie: Crasie is my Hus∣bands name. I wonder why Women must be called by their Husbands names, I.

SP.SPEAKER: Bri.
SP.P: O, they must forsooth.

SP.SPEAKER: Ios.
SP.P: And why not men by their Wives?

SP.SPEAKER: Bri.
SP.P: Marrie forsooth, because that Men, when they marry, become but halfe men: And the other half goes to their Wives. And therefore she is called Woman; where before she was call'd but Mayd.

SP.SPEAKER: Ios.
SP.P: Is a married Man but halfe a Man? what is his other halfe then?

SP.SPEAKER: Bri.
SP.P: Truly, oftentimes, Beast. Which part the wife gives to boot, in exchange of her name. One knocks.

SP.SPEAKER: Ios.
SP.P: Heark, some body knocks; goe see. What should any body knock at my Garden door for? I doe not use to be visited in my Garden.

SP.SPEAKER: Bri.
SP.P: Yonders a Gentleman craves admittance to converse with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ios.
SP.P: I'le converse with no Gentleman. What have I to do with Gentlemen?

SP.SPEAKER: Bri.
SP.P: A fair-spoken, comely, modest Gentleman he is.

SP.SPEAKER: Ios.
SP.P: Is he so? I'le speak with no modest Gentleman▪ You were best be his Bawd. But are you sure he is a true Gentleman? does he weare clean Linnen, and lack Money?

SP.SPEAKER: Bri.
SP.P: Here he comes forsooth.

SP.SPEAKER: Ios.
SP.P: He is very confident, and forward, me thinks.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Exquisite; very Elixir of Beauty, vouchsafe to receive the tender of my Faith to you; which I protest is zealously devoted to your particular service.

SP.SPEAKER: Ios.
SP.P: You may speak lowder Sir: for I assure you, my Mayd is very thick of hearing, and exceeding weake sighted.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Then, Lady, let it be spoken in bold phrase, I love you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ios.
SP.P: I thank you Sir. How should I stile you, pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P:
My name is Pulse-feel: A poor Doctor of Phy∣sick, that weares three-pile velvet in his Cap; has paid a quarters rent of his house afore-hand; and as meanly as he stands here, was made Doctor beyond the Seas. I vow (as I am right Worshipfull) the taking of my Degree cost me twelve French crowns, and five and thirty pound of salt Butter in upper Germany. I can make your beauty, and preserve it; Rectifie your Body, and maintain it; perfume your skin; tinct your haire; enliven your Eye; Heighten your Appetite. As for Gel∣lies, Dentifrices, Diets, Minerall Fucusses, Pomatums, Fumes, Italian Masks to sleep in, either to moysten, or
dry the Superficies of your face; paugh, Gallen was a Goose, and Paracelsus a Patch to Doctor Pulse-feel▪ Make me then happy, deare sweeting, in your private avours: The which I vow with as much secrefie, constancie and Resolution, to preserve, as you, with Bounty, sweetnesse and Freenes shall impart.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: I protest you speak very farre within me; I re∣spect you most affectionatly.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Then Ile attend you at your Chamber: where the best pleasure, youth, Cupid can minister shall en∣tertaine you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ios.
SP.P: Entertain me with pleasure? what pleasure I pray you?

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Nothing but kisse you Lady, and so forth.

SP.SPEAKER: Ios.
SP.P: Well, for kissing and so forth, I care not; But look for no dishonesty at my hands, I charge you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: I will be provident.

SP.SPEAKER: Ios.
SP.P: And honest, I beseech you: And secret, and re∣solute, I advise you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Good.

SP.SPEAKER: Ios.
SP.P: And very chast I command you. But a kisse, and so forth.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: I understand you. This be my pledg of faith.

SP.SPEAKER: Ios.
SP.P: And this of mine.—The thought of me rest with you. And heare you Doctor; I prithee pro∣cure me some young Fellow, that can write: For I am so troubled with Letters, that I neither read nor an∣swer—

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P:
Rely upon me. I can fit you rarely. I know a well qualified fellow, that danceth rarely, playes on di∣vers
Instruments, and withall is close.

SP.SPEAKER: Ios.
SP.P: I marry, Close! Pray let me have him. Kisse and adiew.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: I will maintain it. He only, that knows it, per∣mits, and procures it, is truly a Cuckold. Some fellow would be divorc'd now. Crasie, speak; wilt be di∣vorc'd? why, what and I were? why then thou art an Asse, Crasie. Why Sir? why Sir! why prithee tell me, what would thy Divorce hurt her? It would but give her more liberty. Shee should have bounteous Cu∣stomers; Gallants, that would hoist her tires, bestow deep on her. And she should be paid for't. You speak somewhat to the matter Sir. Nay Crasie, believe it, though she be not a very modest woman for a Wife, thou mayst force her to be a reasonable private wench for a Whore. Say you so? Birlady, and I'le take your Counsell. 'Tis a pretty Drabb. I know not where to compasse such another? troth Sir, I'le follow your ad∣vice.

LG.L: And, if my hopes prove not extreamly ill,
I'le keep her flesh chast, though against her will.
He tooke her by the middle so small
And laid her on the Plain:
And when he had his will on her,
He tooke her up againe.
And what was she then the worse for wearing?
Can you tell Mr. Doctor?

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: What art thou?

SP.SPEAKER: Crac:
SP.P: One Sir (I dare tell you in private) that can conduct you to a more lovely Creature, then her you last courted.

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: A young Pimpe, a very sucking-pig Pimpe! What an Age is this, when children play at such great game! So young, so forward!

LG.L: The young and the old mun too't, mun too't,
The young and the old mun to it;
The young ones will learn to do't, to do't,
And the Oldforget not to do it.

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: This Infant piece of Impudence amaes me. Prithee what art thou? or whom dost thou serve, or broke for.

SP.SPEAKER: Crac.
SP.P: As delicate a piece of Woman-flesh as ever Mortall laid lip to. O she is all Venus! And, to come close to you, shee wants a Physician. You are one I take it: I am a foole else.

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: I am catch'd? This habite will betray me. What is shee, I say.

LG.L: O she is, she is a matchlesse piece,
Though all the world may wooe her;
Nor golden showre, nor golden fleece,
Is price enough to do her.

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: For what wants she a Physitian?

SP.SPEAKER: Crac.
SP.P:
For what you please, when you come to her. Sir, upon my life, shee's free from any Disease, but the Counterfeits. Will you know all Sir? she wants a wie mans counsell to assist her in getting a Husband. I take hold of you for that wise man, shee relyes upon my Election. Will you go Sir? Tis in an exceeding civill
house; a precise one, indeed. Know you not Mr. Lin∣sey Woolsey?

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: Not at his house?

SP.SPEAKER: Crac.
SP.P: Pardon me Sir. At his very house. All the wise wenches i'the Town will thwack to such Sanctuaries, when the times are troublesome, and Troopers trace the streets in terror.

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: Prithee, what call'st thy Mistres?

SP.SPEAKER: Crac.
SP.P: There she lies Sir, by the name of Mistresse Tryman; a rich young Cornish Widdow; though she was borne in Clearken-well; and was never halfe a dayes Journey from Bride well in her life. Her Father was a Pinn-maker—Sings.

LG.L: Along along, where the Gallants throng
By twenties, away the Widow to carry:
But let them tarry: For shee will carry
Twenty, before that one she will Marry.

SP.P: Will you along Sir?

LG.L: Tis but a weak ingagement: yet Ile goe;
Needlesse are feares, where Fortunes are so low.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: A Widdow! what is shee? or of whence?

SP.SPEAKER: Ruff.
SP.P: A lustie young wench, they say: A Cornish Girle; able to wrastle downe stronger Chines then any of ours.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: But how is she purs'd, Jack? Is she strong that way?

SP.SPEAKER: Ruff.
SP.P: Prettie well for a younger Brother; worth 7 or 8 thousand pound.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: How man!

SP.SPEAKER: Ruff.
SP.P: You are a married man, and cannot Rivall me▪ I would not else be so open to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: I sweare Ile help thee all I can. How didst find her out?

SP.SPEAKER: Ruff.
SP.P: I have intelligence, that never failes me, shee came to town neither but very lately; and lodg'd at Mr. Wolseys.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: Who, Linsy wolsie, the Hermaphroditicall Dra∣per! That's a precious Not-headed Rascall. Hee'll goe neare to ayme at her himselfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruff.
SP.P: Like enough. He may aime at her: But shee will be hit by none but a Gentleman, that I heare Oh shee has a fierce Ambition to a Ladyship, though her late Husband was a Tanner.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: A Tanner, well Jack, cake heed how thou ven∣turst on her to make her a Gentlewoman: She will kill hee at her Husbands occupation before thou wile be able to make her Hide gentle. Thou w find a tough peece of Curriers work on her. Look who here is.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: Truly▪ Mr. Toby Sneakup, me thinks I find an alteration in my selfe already.

SP.SPEAKER: Tob.
SP.P: Nay, I told you; would you but give your Mind to it, you would be a Gentleman quickly.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: How's this? let's stand aside atle.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruff.
SP.P: Sure, hee's about to turne himselfe into a Gentleman to winne to the Widdow!

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: And what a Tutor he has pickt out to instruct him!

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: Me thinks I love the name of a Gentleman a great deale better then I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Tob.
SP.P: But could you find in your heart to lend a Gentleman a score of Angells, Mr. Wolsey, on his word?

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: Uhm—I is not gone so farre upon me yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Tob.
SP.P: Oh, but it mst though, I know it. A Citizen can never be a Gentleman, till he has lent all, or almost all his money to Gentlemen. What a while it was ere the rich Joyners son was a Gentleman? when I my selfe was a Gentleman first, my mony did so burne in my Pockets, that it cost me all that ever I had, or could borrow, or steal from my Mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: But Mr. Toby, a man may be a Countrey Gentleman, and keep his money, may he not?

SP.SPEAKER: Tob.
SP.P: You see Sir, This Widdow is remov'd from the Countrey into the City, to avoyd the multiplicity of Country Gentlemen that were here uitors. Nay you must be a Citty Gallant; or a Courtier.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: I see no Courtiers, but are more apt to borrow, then to end.

SP.SPEAKER: Tob.
SP.P: I, those that were born, or bred Courtiers I grant you, But to come to't at your yeares—

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: I can the sooner learne. Your Courtier Sir, I pray.

SP.SPEAKER: Tob.
SP.P: Ile tell you in a breife character was taught me. Speake nothing that you mean, performe nothing that you promise, pay nothing that you owe, flatter all a∣bove you, scorne all beneath you, deprave all in pri∣vate, praise all in publike; keepe no truth in your mouth, no faith in your heart; no health in your bones, no freindship in your mind, no modesty in your eyes, no Religion in your conscience; but especially, no Money in your Purse.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: O that Article spoyles all.

SP.SPEAKER: Tob.
SP.P: If you do, take heed of spending it on any thing but Panders, Puncks, and Fidlers; for that were most unfashionable.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: I thank you Sir, for your Courtly and Gentle∣manlike instructions, and wish you grace to follow them: I have seen too fearfull an example lately in my neighbour Crasy, whose steps I list not trace; nor lend my Money to be laught at among my Neighbours. Fare you well Sir.—

SP.SPEAKER: Tob.
SP.P: Ha ha ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruff.
SP.P: Mr. Wolsie! Well met. How does your faire Guest at home, Mrs. Tryman?

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: How should he come to the knowledge of her? Some of these Gallants will snatch her up, if I prevent not spee∣dily.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruff.
SP.P: Why speak you not Mr. Wolsie? How does the Widow?

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: Truly not well Sir. Whether it be wearinesse of her journey, change of ayre, or dyet, or what I know not; something has distemperd her.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruff.
SP.P: Or Love, perhaps of you Mr. Wolsie.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: Me? Alasse, I look like no such Gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruff.
SP.P: You may in a short time.
Harke hither Mr. Wolsie.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: We overheard you man: And I guest as much before.

SP.SPEAKER: Tob.
SP.P: Tis very true Sir, shee is worth nine thousand pound: But marry she will not'but a Gentleman: And I think I have beat him off o'th condition, I have put him off o' that scent for ever, with a false character, Heaven and the Court forgive me.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: Thou hast introth Boy: And on purpose to have her thy selfe, I perceive it.

SP.SPEAKER: Tob.
SP.P: He does not. He's an Asse.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: Well, if I were a Batchelor, I should envy thy wit, and thy fortune. Is she very handsome?

SP.SPEAKER: Tob.
SP.P: So so: You shall see wee'll make a shift with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruff.
SP.P: Mr. Wolsie, I would you had her with all my heart; you shall not want my good word and best wishes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: Do you speak this in earnest Sir, or as you are a Courtier:

SP.SPEAKER: Ruff.
SP.P: In earnest I, and as I am a Gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: Then in earnest, and as I am an honest man, I do not beleeve you. Mr. Toby Sneakup has told me what Gentlemen and Courtiers are, too lately.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruff.
SP.P: Mr. Sneakup▪ well met.

SP.SPEAKER: Tob.
SP.P: Good Mr. Rufflit.

LG.L: Now faire Mayds lay downe my Bd,
And draw the Curtaines round:
Tell the World that I am dead,
And who hath given the wound,
Ah me poor Soul!
Alack for love I dye,
Then to the Sexton hie,
And cause the Bell to towle.

SP.SPEAKER: Crac.
SP.P: O here he is! Mr. Wolsie, indeed my Master Wolsie, if ever you will see my Mistres your Sweetheart alive, you must goe home presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: My Sweetheart!

SP.SPEAKER: Crac.
SP.P: I thinke shee is; and that in death she will be so. I speak by what she sayes, and others think.

SP.SPEAKER: Tob.
SP.P: Tis the Widows Boy,

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: Is she sicker then she was.

SP.SPEAKER: Crac.
SP.P: O shee is even speechlesse, and calls for you exceedingly. I fetcht a Doctor to her, and he can do her no good. Master Sarpego has made her Will and all.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: Has shee given me any thing?

SP.SPEAKER: Crac.
SP.P: Quickly goe and see Sir, you will come too late else, I am going to get the Bell to towle for her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: Fare ye well Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Tob.
SP.P: Tic. Ruff. Nay, wee'll along with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Crac.
SP.P: Sing.

LG.L: Did never truer heart
Out of the World depart,
Or cause the Bel to towle.

DIV3.HEAD: Scene I.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter in the Tryman, attended by Isabell, Jone, Crasy, with an Ʋrinall.

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: LOok up Mistres.
Jo. Take a good heart, the worst is past, feare not.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: Ah, ah, ah.

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: Reach the Bottle againe of Doctor Stephens water.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: No no, apply more warme cloaths to her sto∣mack, there the matter lyes which sends this distem∣perature into her braine. Be of good cheer Gentle∣woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: Is Mr Wolsie there?

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: Nothing but Mr. Wolsie ever in her mouth.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Pray Sir, how do you like her? I am much af∣fraid of her.

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: Let me see, to night it will be full Moon. And she scape the turning of the next Tyde, I will give her a gentle Vomit in the morning, that shall ease her sto∣mack of this conflux of venomous humours, and make her able to sit a hunting Nag within this sennight.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: A rare man sure. And, I warrant, well seen in a Woman▪

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: Uh, uh, uh, uh.

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: Well sayd, spit out gently, straine not your selfe too hard.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: Agh—fagh.

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: Tis very well done. La'you. Her colour be∣gins to come. Ile lay all my skill to a messe of Tewks∣bury Mustard, shee sneezes thrice within these three houres—

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: Good Sir want nothing, that your skill shall approve necessary in this time of need. Good Wives and kinde Neighbours, I thanke you for your cares.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: Is Mr. Wolsie there?

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: She does nothing but call for you Sir, pray speak to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: Where's Mr. Wolsie.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: Here Lady. How do you?

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: Then I am even well me thinks—agh—agh—

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: Shee's very farr gone I feare, how do you find her disease Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P:
Dangerous enough Sir. For shee is sicker in minde then in body. For I finde most plainely the ef∣fects of a deep melancholly, falne through her distem∣perature of passion upon her Liver; much disordering, and withall wasting the vitals, leaving scarce matter for Physick to worke on. So that her minde receiving
the first hurt, must receive the first cure.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: Agh agh ah—pagh fagh—

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: So so: Straine not your selfe too hard. No hurt; so so.
Here's melancholly and choller both in plenty.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: He speaks with great reason, me thinks, and to the purpose, I would I understood him.

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: Do you not know▪ Sir, any that has offended her by open injury, or unkindnesse?

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: Alas Sir, no such thing could happen since her coming hither.

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: Then, on my life, tis Love that afflicts her.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: Oh oh uh oh—

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: I have toucht her to the quick. I have found her disease, and that you may prove the abler Doctor in this extremity.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: Who I? Alas I beleeve no such matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: Mr. Wolsie, Mr. Wolsie.

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: Here he is Lady. Pray speak your minde to him. Must I pull you to her? Here he is. What do you say to him? Pray speak.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: Oh no, no no no—

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: She hath something troubles her that con∣cernes onely you. Pray take her by the hand, do as I intreat you. Lady we will go, and leave you in private awhile, if you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: Pray do. O but do not, pray do not.

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: Do you perceive nothing in this passion of hers?
How does she feel your hand?

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: O, she does so quiddle it, shake it, and gripe it!

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: You are then the man Sir, the happy man. For she shall recover suddenly.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: Who I? Alack a day.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: What will you have me dye intestate. Is not my Will made, as I directed?

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.P: Where are you Mr. Sarpego, with the Will.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: Ad manum. Sweet Buds of Generosity, for∣beare you may Admirare, at the abundance here specified: But not find a Legacie bequeath'd among you

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: We expect nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruff.
SP.P: I only wish your health, Lady; and that it may, or might have been my happiness to sue to you for Love; as I do now to the highest power for Life.

SP.SPEAKER: Tob.
SP.P: Would I were married to her, as shee is; and twere but for an hower, I car'd not. Had my mother been but acquainted with her, before shee fell sick, here had been a match!

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: O Dij immortales! A rich Widdow shall have Suiters on her Death-bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: Good Sir, It is too late to speak of these things. I only crave and wish your prayers in your absence: This place can yield no pleasure to you I know. Mr. Wolsey, pray your hand againe: I could be even content to live me thinks, if I had but such a man as you to my Huh, uh, uh, uh.—

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: By your leave. Pray by your leave. Help Women. Beare up her Body a little. Bow it forwards. So, speak to her, Sr. Good Lady drink of this Cordyal.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: How do you now forsooth?

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: What now shee is drinking—Now speake Sir, you or no man must do her good.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: How do you forsooth?

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: Well said Sir, speak chearfully to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: How dee doe? how dee doe, Mistris Tryman How ist now, ha?

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: Very comfortably spoken!

SP.SPEAKER: Ruff.
SP.P: I, was it not?

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: Alas shee cannot speak. I'll call my Neigh∣bour Mistres Sneakup. If any body can make her speak, 'tis shee.

SP.SPEAKER: Tob.
SP.P: I'll call my Mother for you. Shee will make her speak, if shee have but a word left in her belly—Masse here shee comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: How comes it Mr. Wolsey, that you have a Gentlewoman sick in your house, and not send for me? Let me feel her hand. Alasse she is shrewdly distem∣per'd. When had shee a stoole Sir, Prithee Daughter step home to my Closet, and bring the Viall of—my owne Water, which stands next to my blew Vel∣vet Cabinet.

SP.SPEAKER: Ios.
SP.P: That's my Doctor was with me to day

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Shee's a young Gentlewoman; may have many Children yet, let me note her eyes: I finde nothing there. When did you see her water Mr. Doctor?

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: What Devill sent this fury among us?

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: In troth I beshrew you, Mr. Wolsey, you sent not for me, but I hope I come not too late. Pluck up a Womens heart, you shall find a good Neighbour of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: I will thank you in my Will. I shall not live to thank you otherwise.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Alas talk not of your will. You shall have time enough to think of that many yeares hence.

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: I tell her so, Lady, yet shee calls for it still.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: Pray let me see it, that I may signe it. Ʋh Ʋh—

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Lord how my Daughter stayes. Good Sir Andrew Ticket! worthy Mr. Rufflit! My Sonne To∣bias is highly honor'd in your noble Acquaintance, and Courtly conversation.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: We rather hold our selves dignified, in being his indear'd Companions.

SP.SPEAKER: Tob.
SP.P: I assure you Mother, we are the three of the Court.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: I most intirely thank you for him. And I do beseech you make your selves no strangers to my poor house. Wee are alone; can give but light enter∣tainement, my Daughter and I; since my Sonne Cra∣sies misfortune drave him from us—
O welcome Daughter—I beseech you noble Sirs estrange not your selves to us, your Servants.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Pox o'your Complement.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Give me the Viall Daughter. Take up the La∣dy. Tast of this. It is a Composition of mine owne distilling.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: Uh, uh, uh, umh—

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Well done. Nay it will make you break wind, I tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: By the service I owe you sweet Mistres, tis un∣fained. My Wife desires to see you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruff.
SP.P:
As I can best witnesse; And feares you enjoy not the libertie of a Woman, since your Husbands de∣parture.
Your Brother having promis'd too, to con∣duct you to Court.

SP.SPEAKER: To.
SP.P: It is confest, and I will do it.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: Where the best entertainment a poore Ladyes chamber can afford, shall expect you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ios
SP.P: I shall embrace it.

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: Sfoot, tis time to part you—Mistres, I be∣seech your help, joyn'd with your vertuous Mothers.

SP.SPEAKER: Ios.
SP.P: You forget the young man, that can Dance Write, and keep Counsell.

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: I forget you not Lady. But I wish you to be∣ware of these Courtiers, till I tell you what they are:

SP.SPEAKER: Ruff.
SP.P: I'll be hang'd if this Doctor be not of her smock Counsell.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: How is it now, good heart?

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: Much enlightned, I thank Heaven and you. Now, pray, read Sir my Will.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: In Dei nomine. Amen.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: O let us heare the Will.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: I Iane Tryman of Knockers hole, in the County of Cornwall, Widdow, Sick in Body, but whole in Mind, and of perfect memory, do make my last Will and Testament, in Manner and Forme following.

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: As for the Manner and Forme tis no matter. To the Legacies, briefly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: Hum hum. Imprimis, A Dole of Bread to be given to the Poore of this Parish—five pound.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: Stay. This I intreat of you Mr. Wolsey, that whether I live or dye, this Dole may be given to mor∣row. It was the Charge of my Mother to see it done; Saying, it was better to take the Prayers of the Poore with me, then leave them to be sent after.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: It shall be done: and you, I hope, shall see it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P:
To Mr. Sarpego, the Writer hereof, A Mourn∣ing
Gown, and forty pound, to Preach at the Fune∣rall.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: How! forty pound?

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: Di boni! No. Tis forty shillings. Item to my Nephew, Sir Marmaduke Trevaugh an of St. Mine∣ver, one thousand pound in Gold. Item to my Ne∣phew Mr. Francis Trepton, one thousand pound in Gold. Item to my Kinsman, Sir Stephen Leggleden, I do forgive two thousand pound, for which his Lands are Mortgaged to me. Item to his Daughter, my God-daughter Iane Leggleden, five hundred pound in money; my best Bason and Ewer; two silver Flaggon Pots, and three silver and gilt standing Cups. Item to the poore of the Parish of Knockers-hole, ten pound, and forty pound towards the reparation of their Church. Item to Mr. Linsey wolsey the Ring, which was my Wedding Ring, and fifty other Rings, with severall stones in my Trunck, in his house, valued at two hundred and fifty pounds. Item to all his ser∣vants, and to the Women that attended me in my sicknesse, five pound a piece.

SP.SPEAKER: Jone.
SP.P: Now the Lord receive her to his mercy.

SP.SPEAKER: Isa
SP.P: My Legacy will save her life; for never any body dyed yet, that bequeathed me any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: Item, to my Page Jeffery Crack forty pound. And all my other Servants ten pound a peice. Item to my Neece Barbara Tredrite five hundred pound; my second Bason and Ewer, a dozen of silver Dishes, and four dozen of silver Spoones. Lastly, all the rest of my Lands, Jewels, Plate, Money, Debts, Moveables and Unmoveables, to my dear and loving Brother, Sir Gre∣gory Flamsted, whom I make my full Executor. In cujus rei testimonium, &c. This is the briefe of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P:
Tis well. Onely add to it—Ʋh—A Gold Chaine also in my Trunk to this vertuous Gentlewo∣man.
And another Chaine, that is there of Pearle, to her Daughter. To this learned Doctor twenty pound. And to the Gentlemen which have visited me, for them and their freinds an hundred pound to be spent in a Banckquet.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: Hoc nihil refert. I must write all over againe then.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: Do so then. And make your forty shillings five pound.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: Gratias vel ingentes ago. It shall be done—

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: Now Mr. Wolsie, and your vertuous Neighbour here, I intreat, that when I have signed this Will, that you keep it til my Brother comes to Town. This Doctor shall direct you in all. And that he may be the better able so to do, I desire you all that I may a while be private with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.P: With all our hearts.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: Are they all gone?
Now Mr. Doctor, what think you of the sick Widow?
Has she done her part hitherto?

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: Beyond my expectation! Better then I for a Doctor.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: You are right. And I am even the same for a Widow as you for a Doctor. Do not I know you? Yes good Mr. Crasy. I dare trust you, because you must trust me. Therefore know, that I the rich Widow am no better, then a Lady that must live by what I beare about me. The vulgar translation you know, but let them speak their pleasure, I have no Lands, and since I am borne, must be kept, I may make the best of my owne, and if one member maintaine the whole body, what's that to any one?

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: I collected as much by your young Whiskin that brought me hither.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: It was by my direction that he did so. And, by my Instructions, he has had an Eye upon you in all your disguises ever since your pretended ourney out of Towne. Nay startle not, nor muse at my acquain∣tance with you: I have had you in my Purlews, be∣fore you were a Freeman: And will hereafter give you certaine tokens of it. In the mean time, if you comply with me, you can be no loofer by it. I am grown weary of my old course; and would faine, by wiser, do my selfe good, before Age or Diseases make it too late.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: I will work close and friendly with thee. Therefore say, this rich Cockscombe is thine owne. O here comes your Pigg-wiggen.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: He is of Counsell, and one of us. He is indeed my Brother, and has been one of the true blew Boyes of the Hospitall; one of the sweet singers to the City Funeralls with a two penny loafe under his arme.

SP.SPEAKER: Crac.
SP.P: Well: He never sung to the wheele in Saint Brides Nunnery yonder.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: Nay Jeff, be not angry; thou hast sung to the Organs I know, till fearing their downfall, thou be∣tookst thy selfe into my more certaine service. All freinds, good Jeff.

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: Yes, yes, we must all agree, and be linckt in Covenant together.

SP.SPEAKER: Crac.
SP.P: By Indenture Tripartite, and't please you, like Subtle, Doll, and Face.

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: Witty Jeff. I cannot see which can be spar'd from the rest, least the whole trade break.

LG.L: Then let us be freinds, and most freindly agree.
The Pimp and the Punck and the Doctor are three,
That cannot but thrive, when united they be.
The Pimp brings in custome, the Punck shee gets treasure,
Of which the Physitian is sure of his measure,
For work that she makes him in sale of her pleasure.
For which, when she failes by diseases or paine,
The Doctor new Vamps and upsets her againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: Thou art a brave Lad, and in the high way of preferment.

SP.SPEAKER: Crac.
SP.P: Not the high Holborne way, I hope Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: And for you Damsell, as I sayd before, say to your selfe, the Match is yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: I mean to say, and know it shortly. Some three dayes hence all may be compleated. Now draw the Curtaines; and follow your affaires, while I put on my sick Face againe. Ʋh, uh, uh.

DIV3.STAGE: They put in the Bed, and withdraw all. Exeunt.

DIV3.HEAD: Scene II.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: NOw could I Accost that Catlinarian Traytor, that defea∣ted me of my ten pound, I have a precogitated Ora∣tion should make him suspend himselfe. But Abiit, e∣vasit, erupit. Or if the rich Widow would have dyed, there had been a supply. But she is nearer a Nuptiall, then a Funerall: And hopelesse Sarpego, that should wed, has not to furnish him to his intent, Vae mihi mi∣sero nec Aurum, nec Argent—tum! Here comes my Beatitude.

SP.SPEAKER: Bri.
SP.P: O, are you here Sir? I was to seek you. My old Mistresse would speak with you instantly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: My Legitimate Spouse, when is our day of con∣junction?

SP.SPEAKER: Bri.
SP.P: Our day of conjunction? Mary faugh Good∣man Fiste. Our day of conjunction?

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: Did you not once vow you did love me?

SP.SPEAKER: Bri.
SP.P: Did not you once swear you had money?

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: Hic jacet, I am now but a dead man.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Pyannet, Sneakup, Crasie—like a Court-Messenger.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
