SP.P: O where's Mr. Sarpego? Fortunate Mr. Sarpe∣go? Venerable Mr. Sarpego? O Sir, you are made. Never thinke under right worshipfull. Imagine nothing beneath Damasque Gownes, Velvet Jackets, Satten Sleeves, Silk Nightcaps, two Pages and a Footcloth.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: The Son of Phoebus rectifie your Brain-pan.

SP.SPEAKER: Sne.
SP.P: Indeed, and't shall please your Worship, it is—

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: It is! What is it? You will be speaking, will you? And your Wife in presence, will you? you shew your bringing up. Master Sarpego, blesse the time that ever you knew the Progeny of the Sneakups: my wor∣shipfull Son and Heire apparent hath preferred you to be the young Prince his Tutor. Here's Mr. Holywater, a Gentleman; of place, a Courtier; of Office, is sent for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: Right fortunately-learned Sir. So passionate∣ly doth his Grace approve the Language, Literature, and Haviour of your sometimes Pupill, Master To∣bias Sneakup.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: Umh.

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: That I was, with all expedition, commanded to intreat your instant Attendance.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: Umh Umh—

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: 'Tis even so Sir; You are like to possess a Princes eare; you may be in place, where you may scorn your foes; countenance your friends; cherish vertue, controule vice, and despise fortune: Yes sure shall you Sir. And (which I had almost forgot) your old Pupill intreats you to send him by me the ten pound he lent you: An od ten pound, that he may be furnish'd with the more seemly Complements to con∣duct you to his Grace.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: Quid nunc?

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Whist Mr. Sarpego. Let not your poverty be read in your face. Here's ten pieces. Bear it as your own payment: You talk of ten pound for my Son, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: O, an od driblet. Here, Friend, I use not to carry Silver: Convey it in Gold.

SP.SPEAKER: Bri.
SP.P: I hope, dear Love, you will not forget your affection to me now.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: Poor Maid, I will prefer thee to scratch my head; make my Bed; wash my Shirt, pick my toes, and evacuate my Chamberpot. I will instantly procure mee attire, fitting my fortune, and attend the Grace of Court—

SP.SPEAKER: Bri.
SP.P: Now am I but a dead woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: I am much griev'd for't. It was your sonnes much labouring, that Mr. Crasie was sent for, to sell his Grace some Jewells: But since his fortunes are so sunk that he hides his head, I can but lament his losse.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P:
Shall I tell you Sir, (pray you husband stand a∣side;) My Son-in-Law Crasie is not now worth—his very wife. We hop'd he would have prov'd a crafty Merchant, and he prov'd an honest man, a Begger (if I chance to speak above your capacity, I pray tell me of
it) And as I said, when I perceiv'd he began to melt, and that every stranger abused him; I, having some wit, fell too, and most cozen'd him my self. I look'd for my daughters good: And so betwixt us, found the trick to get, or steale from him two Jewells of good deep value, being indeed the main of his rest of Fortune. Now Sir, I come to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: I, now you come to the point.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Right Sir: For there is no woman, though she use never so many by-words, but yet in the end she will come to the point. Now Sir, I having these Jewells, will send them by my husband. A poor easie weak man, as you see; but very obedient in truth—

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: By your husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Yes, do you mark? By my husband. But now note my wit: His Grace knows not Crasie: My hus∣band, habited like a Citizen, shall take the name of Crasie upon him; offer his Jewells to the Prince; you shall present them; praise them and raise them: His Grace payes; my husband returns; and we will share. Do you approve?

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: Nay admire.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Away then. No Complement among good wits; but away. Come your ways hi∣ther, good man; Put off your hat; Make a leg; Look simply. Why so! Pish, ne're tell me: He will make a rare Citizen. I have Jewells for you to carry to the Prince.

SP.SPEAKER: Sneak.
SP.P: Yes forsooth, I'le carry them.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P:
La! you are so quick! I have charg'd you not to shoot your bolt, before you understand your mark. And you shall carry them like a Citizen; call your self Crasie; sell them at my price; and now cast no further. You see the limits of your understanding. Now Sir, how will you bear your self to his Grace?
How behave your selfe at Court?

SP.SPEAKER: Sneak.
SP.P: I hope I am not too wise to learne.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Why, that was well spoken. Modest mistrust is the first step to knowledge. Remember that sen∣tence. Now mark. I will instruct you: When you come at the Court gate, you may neither knocke nor pisse. Do you mark? You go through the Hall co∣ver'd; through the great Chamber cover'd; through the Presence bare; through the Lobby cover'd; through the Privy Chamber bare; through the Privy Lobby cover'd; to the Prince bare.

SP.SPEAKER: Sneak.
SP.P: I'le doe't I warrant you. Let me see. At the Court gate neither knock nor make water. May not a man break wind?

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Umh, yes: but (like the Exchequer payment) somewhat abated.

SP.SPEAKER: Sneak.
SP.P: Through the great Chamber bare.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Cover'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sneak.
SP.P: Cover'd? Well: Through the Presence co∣ver'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Bare.

SP.SPEAKER: Sneak.
SP.P: Bare? I will put all dowe in my Table-book, and con it by the way.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Well thought on. Something he has in him like my husband! But now you come before the brow of Royalty. Now for your carriage there Sir: Sup∣pose me the Prince. Come in, and present. Here sits the Prince. There enters the Jeweller. Make your ho∣nors. Let me see you do it handsomly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sneak.
SP.P: Yes, now I come in; make my three legs—And then—

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Kneele.

SP.SPEAKER: Sneak.
SP.P: Yes; and say—

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: What?

SP.SPEAKER: Sneak.
SP.P: Nay, that I know not.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: An't please your Grace, I have certain Jewells to present to your liking.

SP.SPEAKER: Sneak.
SP.P: An't please your Grace, I have certain Jewels to present to your liking.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Is this Crasie, that had wont to serve me with Jewells? It is that honest man, so please your High∣nesse. That's for M. Holywater, the by-flatterer to speak. You are a Cuekoldly Knave, Sirrah, and have often a∣bused me with false and deceitfull stones.

SP.SPEAKER: Sneak.
SP.P: My stones are right, so please your Ex∣cellence.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Why that was well, Very well. I perceive there is a certain infection taken with lying with a wo∣man that hath a good wit. I finde it by my husband. Come, I'le disguise you, and away to Court in∣stantly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sneak.
SP.P: Truly wife, I fear J shall be discover'd among the Gallants presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: No, no, A fool is never discover'd among mad∣men.

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P:
WEll Dol, (that thou saist is thy name) though J had forgotten thee, J protest. About London-wall was it (saist thou?) Well, J can∣not but highly commend thy wisdom in this, that so
well hast mended thy election; from being a foun∣tain of aches, bald brows, and broad plasters, thus to remember thy Creation.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: I did consider, and I thinke rightly, what I was; and that men that lov'd my use, lov'd it but to loath me: Therefore I chang'd my self into this shape of a demure, innocent Countrey Widdow, that had scarce beauty enough to be tempted, but not wit e∣nough to be naught; and quite forsook the path I trod in, and betook me to this private course of co∣zenage.

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: But all my wonder is at the means, how thou gott'st into this house and reputation. And to be held a woman of such an estate.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: That shall bee made plaine to you here∣after.
Now Brother Geffrey, where left you M Wolsie?

SP.SPEAKER: Crack.
SP.P: Among the Mercers, so troubled, as if all the Sattin in Cheapside were not enough to make you a wedding Gowne. He is over-joy'd that his happy day is at hand; and I over-heard him invite one spe∣ciall friend to his Nuptialls. He cannot contain him∣self. On a sudden he fell a singing, O shee's a dainty Widdow. O are you come Sir, in your new shape? Dos not that beard fit you handsomly? Thank my ac∣quaintance with the Players.

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: I thinke thou art acquainted any way, to set out knavery.

SP.SPEAKER: Crac.
SP.P: If you can perform your part as well, 'tis well. Heark, I hear him coming.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: VVhere are you sweet Widdow? Look you, Look you: How do you like these patterns?

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: Sir, here's a Gentleman has a Letter to you: He tells me it imports the making, or the undo∣ing of his dearest friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: From whom, I pray you?

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Your sometimes neighbor Sir, M: Crasy.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: It shall take effect, doubt not.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: He scratches his head, though.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: He had as liefe part with his blood as his money.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: M. Crasy writes to me for thirty pound; the value of a Ring I had of him. I grant I am to pay threescore at my day of Marriage. But we are all mortall. And who knowes whether I shall live till to morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: If not, Sir, your Bond is due to night: For it is equally payable at your hour of death.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: O, but such payments never trouble a man. What the eye sees not—

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: Are you in Bonds, M. Woolsie, for your day of Marriage?

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: Only for this sixty pound. 'Tis for that Ring you weare, and I gave you upon our Contract. 'Tis worth thirty pound ready mony.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: Then when you are married, you may say you paid the rest for your wife. Pray Sir make even such reckonings before you wed. It will shew nobly in you towards your poor Creditor, and be a speciall argument of your love to me, your wife. Pray dis∣charge it, I shall not think you love me else.

Heark you Sir, if you will take thirty pound in full
payment, and give me in my Bond, here is your mony. 'Tis your best course. Alas, I am an unlikely fellow for wedlock. What woman, thinke you, would bestow her self upon me, a stale Batchellor, unhandsome and poor—not worth above six or seven thousand pound? Do; take thirty pound.

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: If you please to be friend Mr. Crasy but wich thirty pound, Ile set it receiv'd upon the Bond. Here it is. And he shall demand no more till it be due.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: Pray Sir pay it all, and take in your Bond. You shall be married within these two dayes; to morrow, if you please: VVhat use will your money yeeld you for a night? Pray pay it. In truth I'le pay it else. 'Tis but threescore pound.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: Saist thou so, Sweetheart. Come Sir. Come in and tell your money—

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: And thank you too, good M. Linsie VVolsie, that knew so well, a bargaine was a bargaine, and would not part with your money to be laugh'd at a∣mong your neighbours. I would heartily now, if I could intend it. But I must purse your money, and then about my Court affairs. This wench I am in∣finitely beholden to. She remembers some old curte∣sie that I have forgotten. Perhaps I pidled with her when I was Prentice.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: THis is the Presence. I am much amaz'd, or stupified, that Mr. Tobias Sneakup, my quon∣dam Pupill, attends not my Conduct! Ha! So in∣stant was his Grace, his importunity to enjoy me, that although I purchased the loan of Cloaths, yet I had not vacation, nor indeed variety to shift my shirt. And now I come to Court, I feel certain little Cattell of infamous generation about me, that do most inseparably haunt me. Now if (when the Prince surveyes me) any of them being strangers here, should peep to behold strange sights, and his Grace perceive them, what should I answer?—

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: O, my glorified Pedant in his most naturall strut!

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: I will say it was by influence of the heavens; or, to appear the more perfect Courtier at the first dash, I will say, that though my outside were glorious, yet of purpose I left my inside lowsie.
Sed, O Dii! Quem video? nonne Mr. Sneakup?

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: See my worshipfull Father-in-Law! Now the Woodcocks shoot into the glade.

SP.SPEAKER: Sneak.
SP.P: Pray ye peace, you must not know me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: O monstrum horrendum! May not you and I know one another?

SP.SPEAKER: Sneak.
SP.P: Pray go home, and ask my wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: Mr. Crasie. Is not one Mr. Crasie here?

SP.SPEAKER: Sneak.
SP.P: Yes Sir. Here is Mr. Crasie for a need Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: Well done: Be bold Sir. Let not your dissi∣mulation be read in your eyes. You know me; give me the Jewells.

SP.SPEAKER: Sneak.
SP.P: Yes Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: Let me alone to present them to his Grace, and praise them, before you are call'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sneak.
SP.P: Will you do so Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: Yes; For you know I must not seem to in∣deare them before your face: For that would smell rank of correspondency.

SP.SPEAKER: Sneak.
SP.P: You say right Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: But betwixt us both wee'l make a shift to cheat him. Stay you here. I will returne instantly. O Mr. Sarpego! Your Pupill will come and conduct you pre∣sently.

LG.L: Thus sometimes, by deceit, deceit is known:
'Tis honest craft, by wit to get ones own.—

SP.SPEAKER: To.
SP.P: My Quondam Pedagogue!

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: My Nuper Alumnus! Come, present me to the Grace of Greatness. I am ready; behold I am approach'd according to thy intreats, to approve thy praise, and mine own perfection. Set on: His Grace shall see that we can speake true Latin, and construe Ldovicus vives: Go, set on.

SP.SPEAKER: Tob.
SP.P: I cry you mercy Sir. Upon my troth, I tooke you for Mr. Sarpego, my learned Tutor. He is very like him; Is he not Gentlemen? But now I come to my selfe againe, I remember this was never his walke, nor these his cloaths.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: Sent you not a Nuntius, or a Messenger for me, intimating, that it was his Grace his instant desire, to entertain me as his Instructor?

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: Alas, he has over-studied himself! You were best let blood in time Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: Sent I not you, by the same messenger, your ten pound?

SP.SPEAKER: Tob.
SP.P: My ten pound? Ha, ha ha: I would laugh i faith, if you could bob me off with such payment.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruff.
SP.P: Sure Sir, you use some Dormitaries. Best shave your head, and 'noint it with Oyl of Roses.

SP.SPEAKER: Tob.
SP.P: Father! Father!

SP.SPEAKER: Sneak.
SP.P: Pray peace son. The plot will be discover'd else.

SP.SPEAKER: Tob.
SP.P: The plot? what plot?

SP.SPEAKER: Sneak.
SP.P: The Jewells are sent in, What, I am Mr. Cra∣sie now, you know. I shall be sent for in to his Grace instantly.

SP.SPEAKER: Tob.
SP.P: Midsummer Moon! Midsummer Moon!

SP.SPEAKER: Sneak.
SP.P: In very truth son, hit as 'twill, I say we are beholding to Mr. Holywater.

SP.SPEAKER: Tob.
SP.P: Heaven not blesse me, if I understand not the Baboons mumpings better then your speech. You are more dark then Delphos. What Holywater?

SP.SPEAKER: Sneak.
SP.P: Why the Gentleman, you know, you sent to bring M. Crasie to serve his Grace with Jewells.

SP.SPEAKER: Tob.
SP.P: Father, Heaven pardon me: For sure I have a great desire to call you Cockscomb. I sent no man; nor is there any so stiled as Holywater about the Court.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: Do you not want sleep sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Ruff.
SP.P: Or have you not seen a spirit sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: Or have you not over-mus'd, or over-thought your selfe, as wee doubt Mr. Sarpego, here, has done?

SP.SPEAKER: Tob.
SP.P: Or has not my mother over-beaten you, fa∣ther? You may tell me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sneak.
SP.P: Son, I am not so very a foole, but I perceive I am made a stark Asse. Oh sonne, thy father is co∣zen'd; and thy mother will beat me indeed, unlesse your charity conceal me in the Court here, till her fu∣ry be over.

SP.SPEAKER: Ticket.
SP.P: Hee shall stay at my Wives Cham∣ber.

SP.SPEAKER: Rufflit.
SP.P: And there instruct us in the passages of this cozenage.

SP.SPEAKER: Tob.
SP.P: Do not weep father. My Lady Ticket will appease all.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruff.
SP.P: Adieu Mr. Sarpego. Lure your braines backe againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: Sic transit gloria Mundi. The learned is Co∣ny-caught; and the lover of Helicon is laugh'd at. The last six-pence of my fortune is spent; and I will go cry in private.

DIV3.HEAD: Scene I.

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: NOw, whilst my politike Mother-in-Law is in expectation of her great adventure, and my worshipfull Father-in-Law stinks at Court for feare of her; I in this last disguise will pursue my new affairs. Me-thinks these Jewells smile on me now more chear∣fully then when they were mine owne before. First to my honest Punk.

DIV3.STAGE: Crack meets Crasie at the doore.

SP.SPEAKER: Crac.
SP.P: Who would you speak with Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: With thy sister. Dost thou not know mee Jeffrey. Where is she? Look better on me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: O, is it you Sir? Hang me if I knew you in this habit; though I was set here on purpose to watch for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: What's the matter Jeffrey?

SP.SPEAKER: Crac.
SP.P: Sir she is fallen into a new fit of Melancholy. Some new project she has in her noddle. But she de∣sires you to worke upon this, [he gives him a paper.] I dare not be seen to talk with any body.—Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P:
What new device is this? [he reads.] Since I last saw you, your Mother-in-Law, Mrs. Sneakup, has earnestly dealt with me to make me a Bride for her sonne Tobias. If there may be any thing wrought out of it to benefit you, I will suddenly take occasion to
break with the Foole Wolsie; of whom I am heartily weary; and after, be wholly disposed by you. Sure this wench studies nothing but my profit. Well: I have thought already to make the best of her. Now to my new Mistresse. This is the house, and here's her maid.

SP.SPEAKER: Bri.
SP.P: Would you speak with any here Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: With your Mistresse, (I take it) Mristresse Crasie.

SP.SPEAKER: Bri.
SP.P: May not I deliver your mind unto her Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: My business is of weight and secresie: yet you may tell her, here is the Gentleman that her Do∣ctor sent her.

SP.SPEAKER: Bri.
SP.P: O she expects him most impatiently—Pray en∣ter Sir. She's ready for you, there before you Sir—

LG.L: A businesse of mine owne makes me wait here.
I think I saw my learned Love make this way.
But he (alas) though small in fleshly growth,
By reason of his high preferment is
Now growne too great for me.
'Tis hee; I know his stature,
Though not his cloaths, the Ensigns of his greatness,
In which how big he seems, though but a sprawler!
So cloaths can make men greater, but not taller.
He's deep in study; I dare not interrupt him.
I have adventur'd, though with trembling feet,
Unto this Mansion, to exonerate,
At least extenuate my suspirations
For my dear loss. The Lady of this place.
Who had an equall venture, and hath suffer'd
In the same Fate with me, may ease my sorrow.
I of my wrongs, and she of hers shall clamor.
But ecce noster ubi esset Amor.

SP.SPEAKER: Bri.
SP.P: Most worshipfull Sir, welcome from Court, If your poor Handmaid may presume to say so.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar:
SP.P: Where is your Mistresse? I mean your grand Matrona, Mrs. Sneakup.

SP.SPEAKER: Bri.
SP.P: In the first place let me beseech you Sir,
Vouchsafe your answer to a longing Maid,
That can be comforted in nothing more,
Then the good newes of your prosperity;
Of which I hope a part at least to be,
Preferr'd by your late promise to your service.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: I will now breath a most strong and Poeticall execration
Against the Universe. [Bri.] Sir I beseech you—

LG.L: From henceforth Erit Fluvius Deucalionis
The world shall flow with dunces; Regnabitque, and it shall raine
Dogmata Polla Sophon, Dogs and Polecats, and so forth.

SP.SPEAKER: Bri.
SP.P: His Court advancement makes him mad, I fear.

LG.L: From hence let learning be abomination
'Mong the Plebeians, till their ignorance
Shall lead them blinde into the Lake of Lethe.
What pity 'tis that honour and high places
Should make men lose their wits, sometimes their heads!
May Peasantry and Idiotism trample
Upon the heads of Art and Knowledge, till
The world be shuffled in th' pristine Chaos.
Dear Sir, though you are highly dignified,
Forget not the preferment, that you promis'd me,
To scratch your head; to make your bed; to wash
Your shirt; to pick your toes, and to evacuate
Your Chamberpot.
Elephantem ex Musca facit. She takes me for a Mountaine, that am but a Mole-hill.
But when she reads my poverty agen,
And that these Garments must return to th'Gambrels,
Her scorn will be impetuous.
Go finde another room maid for your talk,
Mr. Sarpego, my mother calls for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: Has she receiv'd Aliquid novi, newes from Court?

LG.L: She has now receiv'd a Letter. Pray be gone,
I have more serious business of mine own. Ex. Sar. Brid.
You are the Creature then that my deare
Doctor has sent me, that can dance, read, write, and be secret. I shall use you all in all. And I prithee how faes my Physitian?

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: I can confirm that he is yours protestedly. And to morrow night—

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Peace: Here comes my mother.
I can my Cinquepace friend. But I prithee teach me some tricks. Who would care for a female, that moves after the plain pace? No: Give me the woman of tricks. Teach me some tricks I prethee.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Ha! Tricks of twenty: Your Traverses, Sli∣dings, Falling back, Jumps, Closings, Openings, Shorts, Turns, Pacings, Gracings—As for—Corantoes, Levol∣toes, Jigs, Measures, Pavins, Brawls, Galliards, or Ca∣aries▪ I speak it not swellingly, but I subscribe to no man.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Tis a rare fellow!

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Am I then cheated? my wit begins to be out of countenance. O the Plague that hangs over her head that has a foole to her husband, as thou and I have daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: How now sweet mother? What ill newes chan∣geth your face thus?

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: O deare daughter, my Lady Ticket writes here, that the fool, thy father, is cheated of two rich Jew∣ells, that thou and I stole from the Ideot thy husband Crasie.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: O that Crasy was ever a silly fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: A very Citizen, a very Citizen. How should I call you Sir?.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: One Mr. Footwell, Mother; who teacheth Gen∣tlewomen to doe all things Courtly, to dance Court∣ly, to love their husbands Courtly—

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Your name is Mrs. Pyannet, I take it.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Pyannet Sneakup, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Your husband is cozen'd at Court, I take it.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: So my Lady Ticket writes, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: That Lady Ticket is a cunning creature. I have been inward with her; And such are my private Intel∣ligences, that if equall curtesie might recompence, I could unshale a plot is upon you.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Recompence? Sir command me, command my daughter, my maid, my house, onely tell it I beseech you.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: I pray see wherein we may be gratefull. I pray speak.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P:
So it is, I am a decayed Gentleman, quite out of repaire; fallen for want of means to the use of my feet: Nor have I hope to see better light, but onely that Love and Fortune have put upon me a right wealthy widdow. She lyes at a near neighbours house
here; and here I hover about her: but for want of some good friends countenance, some meanes for cloaths and fit housing, she holds off from consumma∣ting our Marriage. Now Lady—

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: I apprehend you Sir. Bring her to me; lodge her with me; Ile call you Cousen I. Is she very rich? At a neer neighbours, said you,—Not she at Mr. Wol∣sies, is it?

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: The very same.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: (By'r Lady a match for my Esquir'd son and heire. Beare a braine dancer, or I may chance to shew you a crosse caper.) Sir, bring your Widdow. Sweare to your selfe my house is yours. Now the plot, or I burst.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Why then will I disclose who cozen'd you; by what meanes you are injur'd, and how you may be reveng'd, onely you shal vow to conceale the secret-re∣vealer, else you lose the benefit of further Intelli∣gence.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Stand off daughter: I will not trust mine own flesh with a secret; for in truth I have found it fraile. Now speak, I beseech you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Sure, precious Mistresse, very absolute crea∣tures have had Cockscombs to their husbands.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Nay that's indubitable, I know it by my self.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra
SP.P:
Marry to bee made Cuckqueane by such a Cockscombe, to have her Jewells prig'd away, to be∣stow on a Court Mistresse; to have a trick put upon her, as you have, 'twould move (I must confesse) a wo∣man that were not part a Philosopher, and had a strong wit as you have. Why did you not feele the deceit? your husbands unworthinesse, having no meanes to enjoy this Court-Lady but by gifts; and having no course for gifts, but from you, procures some Pander to performe a fam'd message. Your hope of game puts
the weighty trust upon the counterfeit fool your hus∣band; his simplicity seems cozen'd, whilst this Lady excuses all, and keeps all: So that your own Jewells purchase your owne horns; nay, and you were not withall laught at for your purchase, 'twere scarce e∣nough to run mad for.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: 'Tis most plaine: I will have such a revenge, as never woman had.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: Good Mrs. Pyannet, bear't as well as you may: Your losse is heavy, yet under the strength of your constant wisdome—I faith my wife was so carefull lest you should take too deep sense of it, that she im∣portun'd my own presence to comfort you: For sure I know—

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: You are a Wittally Cuckold I know. I com∣mend thy wives modesty yet: She will not doe it a∣fore thy face, but will send thee out of an errand yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: What mean you? you amaze me.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Nay, I look you should seem ignorant: What, to take sense or notice of your horne, as long as it winds you into profit, were most uncourtly. Well, you heare not me rage nor rave: marry I will slit the Drabs nose, crop off her eares, scratch out her eyes—

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: Blesse us!

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Teare off her haire, plucke out her throat, that's all. Come along Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.P: Now they are gone, I prethee M. Footwell stay a little, I will fetch thee some Letters to read for me, which I have not o∣pen'd yet, because I durst trust no body.—

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: These Letters must necessarily come from my Brace of Courtiers, Sir Ticket, and Monsieur Rufflit, which I will read cleane contrary, as if they slighted her, and answer them acrosse from her meaning, as if she slighted them: And so letting my selfe downe in∣to their inwards on both sides, what they can get, or what my wife has, will I pump into mine owne purse.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Now deare M. Footwell, as ever you pitied the use of a poor Gentlewoman, that would faine use her eauty, whilst there is some pleasure in it, read and an∣wer these Letters with commanding eloquence; force them to affect me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha: Will you not be offended, if I read them truly?

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: No: I prethee what is't?

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Stay, it seems you have written to them.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Yes: but I cannot read the answer. Prethee hat ist?

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Faith youle be angry.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Nay, and you love me, what ist?

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Sir Andrew here, he sayes, tis not your broad im'd hat, your tiffeny dresse, Spanish ruffe, and sil∣er bodkin can make him disloyall to his wives bed. Rufflit here, he writes that you have a grosse body, a ll eye, a lowe forehead, a black tooth, a fat hand, d a most lean purse. I there's it: And you could but ve, and you had but to send—

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: A lean purse!

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P:
I, the lean purse. There's the Devill: Were u as bald as Time, as stiffly wrinkled as frozen w'd Lands, more dry then a Fever, more leane then
death; had you ingross'd deformity, yet if you had but to give—

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Why Footwell, though my husband be but a Bankrupt Knave—

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Nay faith, rather a fool, Mistresse.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Well, fool let him be then; yet I have a Mo∣ther will not see me want for necessary ends: And I hope I had the wit to cozen my husband of somewhat against a rainy day. Look you Sir, I kept these for a friend in a corner.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Nay, but I would not wish you to send them now: What, relieve the base wants of prating Skip∣jacks to pay for your damnation?

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Nay thats sure, I will not give them:

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: And yet, i faith, what can a Gentlewoman give too much for her pleasure? Can there be a more heavy disgrace blowne abroad upon any Lady, then that she has not at the least two servants, since many Lovers are the onely noble approvement of beauty?

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.P: Ile send them both, thats sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: But both of them to Mr. Rufflit: Oh, hee's an absolute spirit! He has an English face, a French tongue, a Spanish heart, an Irish hand, a Welch Leg, a Scotch beard, and a Dutch buttock.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: O J: J am wholly his, J will send all to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: O but Sir Andrew, he is a Courtly Lover: He can kisse you courtly, handle you Courtly, lye with you Courtly.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: O yes: he shall have one. J prethee praise me to them both, and commend to each of them one of these Jewells, not that I doe so much care for the use of them, yet because I would not be wonder'd at like an Owle among my neighbors, for living honest in my husbands absence. I prethee work effectually for mee, sweet M. Footwell.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Rufflit, spying her going out.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruf.
SP.P: Mrs. Crasie: Hist Mrs. Crasie.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Peace Sir, forbeare: As you would hope, doe not pursue a woman when she is out of the humor. O, untimely importunity is most distastfull. There are cer∣tain seasons to take the coldest Appetite, when she is pinning a Ruffe, playing with a Monkey, hearing a wanton Song, or half drunk.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruf.
SP.P: O hat are you Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: A private Messenger to you Sir, from the Gen∣tlewoman you pursue. This is your hand, is it not?

SP.SPEAKER: Ruf.
SP.P: Yes:

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: You may keep your Letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruf.
SP.P: But what sayes my utmost hope, the end of my ambition?

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Only that you are poor, a Gallant of a very wanting fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruf.
SP.P: The more honor for her to redeem me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Alas, I think her means are but weak, her hus∣bands sinking hath brought her low.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruf.
SP.P: Her husband! Alas poor fly; onely made to be suck'd and forsaken. His wife has the life-blood of her fortunes in her, and I'le be her cupping-glasse.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: I wonder his wife could nourish so unbelieving a conscience!

SP.SPEAKER: Ruf.
SP.P: Conscience! All things rob one another: Chur∣ches poule the People, Princes pill the Church; Mini∣ons draw from Princes, Mistresses suck Minions; and the Pox undoes Mistresses; Physitians plague their Pa∣tients; Orators their Clients; Courtiers their Suitors, and the Devill all. The water robs the earth, earth choakes the water: fire burns ayre, ayre still consumes the fire.

LG.L: Since Elements themselves do rob each other,
And Phoebe for her light doth rob her Brother,
What ist in man, one man to rob another?

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: You have spoken most edifyingly sir, but for you, of whom I understand Crasy merits the best Of∣fices; for you to corrupt his Wife, and with a cove∣tous sinning expect use for the loan of your Loines!

SP.SPEAKER: Ruff.
SP.P: Death man, they are my Exchecquer, my Rent: Why I have no possession but my Estate taile. And at for Crasy, he has no wit; he was created a foole, to have Knaves work upon him: a fellow made to have some pity, and all wrong; he had ever an open Purse, and now an empty. He made it a common hole, every Gallant had his fingers in it. Every man lov'd his Fortune, squeez'd it, and when it was unjuic'd, farewell kind heart. I confess I owe him a good turn: Ile pay't his Wife. He kept her alwaies exquisitely neat; temptingly gallant, and as a protested Cuckold should do, about his degree and means sumptuously proud. Her Eye artificially spirited, her Cheek surphu∣led, her Teeth blanch'd, her Lip painted, her Neck car∣kanetted, and her Brest bar'd almost to her Belly. And shall a peece, thus put out to sale, stand unattempted, as not worth the purchase.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Yes Sir, if you could compasse her; as sure she may be corrupted: for she is very covetous.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruff.
SP.P: If I could but make shew of a Gift, or pre∣sent one—

SP.SPEAKER: Cra
SP.P: Only not to appeare of so needy a Fortune—Why if you chance to possess her.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruff.
SP.P: Pish, tweare all mine again, and all that she had besides. And troth, I think she is wealthy.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Wealthy! look you Sir, Here are two of her Jewels, I fetcht from an Ant of hers, where they lay hid from her Husband. These are not worth the pursuit.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruff.
SP.P: Nay, tis an easie Female: He, that has her, has all. What should I send? A Gift would do it. Let me think. Tis but a gross-bodyed Wench, with a blackish haire neither.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Oh the better. Your lean No-bodies with yellow Manes have most commonly rotten teeth and wicked breaths. No, your full plump Woman is your only Venus.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruff.
SP.P: A hundred golden peeces I am intrusted with∣all by my elder Brother, to purchase a peece of In∣justice. If I should send them—

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Oh Sir, these both were yours, and they too. She pretends this straine, but onely to explore your strength of means, and to try how far you dare engage them for her enjoying.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruff.
SP.P: I will send them, win her, use her, suck her Purse, recover my own, gain hers, and laugh at the poor Cuckhold her Husband. Commend with thse my lifes blood, and Soules service to my Mistris▪ Fare∣well—

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Sir Andrew Ticket, I take it.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: The same, Sir. Is Mrs. Crasie within? I cannot keep pace with her Mother. O, when jealousie is once set a going, it runs on high speed. But let her make hast to arrive at Court, while I land on her Daughter in the City. Is she privately idle?
What dost thou mean by that?

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: My Vow's discharg'd, and her Revenge is done. I am no Pandar, Sir, and yet I am of Counsell with Smock secrets, Buttock businesse Sir.
Are you so stale a Courtier, and know not the neces∣sity of Gifts?

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: Is that the matter I am rejected by her?

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Why? would it not provoke any Woman to be called foole, and foule-face?

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: I never call'd her so, by the Soule of my Affection, not I.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: No; Do you not intimate she is a foole, when you hope to enjoy her without a Gift? And foule, when your neglect of cost saies she deserves none.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: 'Fore Heaven I was a silly Asse, now I think on't, to send a Sonnet without some rich present.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Why Sir? A man must do as he would be done to. Do you, or any man use to be made Cuck∣hold for nothing?

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: I should have sent a Gift. What, if I enjoy her, she may requite it.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: May; Nay can; nay will. Look you Sir, here's Gold. Here are Jewels. They are hers; they may be yours. I would not seem a Pandar to you though; for you have a Wife Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: Pish, who cares to drink out of a River? What I can command out of duty hath but a dull relish. Had not Danae been kept in her brass Tower, she had never tempted a Gods piercing. I must send, though it be but to shew the ability of my Fortune, and the desert of her Beauty.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: And then to send but a trifle would disgrace both.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: Hold, convey this Carckanet unto her; tis of value, and let her read by this, how much I seek her.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: And how deare you hold her. Sir, I can speak; but I use to take nothing for my paines.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: Yes, receive this little—Nay, I prethee.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Only not to appeare Uncourtly, or uncivill. I protest I abhor Pandarisme; only as a second, or so. As you have beheld two Horses knubbing one ano∣ther; Ka me, Ka thee, an old kind of Courtship.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: I prethee return instantly my success: You shall find me at the Ordinary; come and Dine with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: I have procur'd a private Stable for my Horse: And therefore I my selfe would be loth to stand at Livery.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Dost compare common Stables for Horses, and publick Ordinaries for Gallants together.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Troth yes sir, for as in Stables, here a goodly Gelding of twenty Pounds price, & there a raw-backd Jade of foure Nobles by him. So at Ordinaries, here a worthy Fellow of means and virtue, and there a Cheating Shifter of wants and cosenage. Here a Knight, there a Beggar; Here a Gallant, there a Gull: Here a Courtier, there a Coxcomb; Here a Justice of Peace, and there an Esquire of low Degree. Or, in direct Phrase, a Pandar.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: Such a one as thou art.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Umh, Virtue goes often wetshod, and is forc'd to be cobled up with base means, to hold out water and cold necessity. You command me no further sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: No honest Knave, farewell—
Now Mr. Crasy, will I button up your Cap with a Court-brooch.

You demand Debts, do you? Ile pay you none. Oh twas a notable dull Flat-Cap. He would invite Courtiers; stand bare, say grace, make legs, kiss his hand, serve us in perfum'd linnen, and lend us money upon our words, or bare words. Were't not a sin to
let such a foole passe unsuckt? No, Fortune drest him only for us to feed on, and Ile fall to.

DIV3.HEAD: Scene 11.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Tic.
SP.P: BEE comforted Mr. Sneakup; Re∣member you are in my Chamber. Beare the heart of a Husband, who scorns to tremble at the face of his Wife? Do not feare sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Tob.
SP.P: Stand firm Father, do not sinck before the face of a Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: I have sent my own Husband to satisfie her, and I hope he will do it throughly. Be your selfe therefore; all the Pleasures the Pallace can afford, shall strive to mitigate your feares.

SP.SPEAKER: Sneak.
SP.P: Have you any Pleasures in the Court, can make a man forget he has a Wife?

SP.SPEAKER: To.
SP.P: Sir we have pleasures will make a man forget any thing, even himselfe; therefore necessarily his wife, who is but part of himselfe.

SP.SPEAKER: La. T.
SP.P: Boy, sing your song of the Court de∣lights.

DIV3.STAGE: They sit: Sneakups head in the Ladies lap.
Enter Pyannet with a Truncheon. Sarpego.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Are you lull'd in your delights? No pillow for your Goatish, head, but her Ladyships lap?

SP.SPEAKER: Sneak.
SP.P: O dear! O wife! I did not know you were so nigh truly.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: You are ignorant still, I know: But I will make thy bones suffer as well as my browes. Thou Cullion▪ could not thine own Cellar serve thee, but thou must be sneaking into Court Butteries?

SP.SPEAKER: Sneak.
SP.P: Oh, oh, oh—

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: Vae misero.

SP.SPEAKER: To.
SP.P: Hold deare mother.

SP.SPEAKER: La. T.
SP.P: Sweet Mrs. Pyannet hold.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Art thou there, daughter of an Intelligencer, and strumpet to a Bearward?

SP.SPEAKER: La. T.
SP.P: Now Beauty blesse me, was not thy mother a notorious Tripe-wife, and thy father a profest Hare∣finder? Gip you Flirt.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: How now Madam Tiffany! Will none but my Cock serve to tread you? Give me my Jewells thou Harlot.

SP.SPEAKER: To.
SP.P: Mother—Pray Mother—

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Bestow steeping thy skin in perfumes to kill the stink of thy paintings, and rotten inwards to catch Cockscombs.

SP.SPEAKER: To.
SP.P: Dear mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: But thou shalt not cozen, and Cucquean me▪

SP.SPEAKER: To.
SP.P: Sweet mother—

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: Lupus in fabula. The Devill's in the womans tongue.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: A whip on her; rotten eggs and kennell dirt on her silken Whoreship.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: Nil tam difficile. Nothing can lay her.

SP.SPEAKER: La. T.
SP.P: Nay, let the Countrey Gentlewoman bee mad and rave on; she knowes I know my Countrey Gentlewoman had a Bastard before shee was mar∣ried.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Did um so? The Countrey Gentlewoman was more chaste in a Bastard, then the Court Madam in her barrennesse. You understand me; you have no Green-sicknesse there, yet (I hope) you have few Christ'nings; you have trickes for that, have you?

SP.SPEAKER: To.
SP.P: Nay mother—

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: You have your Kickshaws, your Players March∣paines; all shew and no meat.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: Nulli penetrabilis Astro. Shee'l heare no reason.

SP.SPEAKER: La. T.
SP.P: Go to; you know how in private you com∣mended your Horse-keeper to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Well: And didst not thou in as much privacy counsell me to contemn my husband, and use an Itali∣an trick that thou wouldst teach me?

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: Quid faciendum? Best stop their mouths?

SP.SPEAKER: La. T.
SP.P: Out you bawble; you trifle; you burden smock'd sweaty sluttery, that couldst love a fellow that wore worsted stockins footed, and fed in Cooks shops.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: Jaculis & Arcu. Thunder and Lightning.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Ods my precious—▪

SP.SPEAKER: Sneak.
SP.P: Nay dear, sweet wife—

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: How's this—

SP.SPEAKER: To.
SP.P: Honey Mother—

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P:
Take this, and take all. Why goody Com∣plexion, thou Rammy Nastinesse, thou knowest where∣fore
thy Gentlewoman left thee; did she not sweare that she—

SP.SPEAKER: To.
SP.P: For modesties sake—

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Had rather be at the opening of a dead old man, then stand dressing thy head in a morning. Remember the Page that wore thy picture, and the song which thou hadst in the praise of the male Baboon.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: Tacete parvuli: You have said too much.

SP.SPEAKER: To.
SP.P: Indeed mother you will be sorry, when you know how much you mistake; some crafty fellow has put a trick upon you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sneak.
SP.P: Me-thinkes sweet wife you should rather condole our losse with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Hold you your peace; do not you prate.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: Redde te Harpocratem: The man is wise e∣nough.

SP.SPEAKER: To.
SP.P: 'Tis true; misfortune hath wrought the Iew∣ells from my father.

SP.SPEAKER: Sneak.
SP.P: Indeed wife, truly, truly, I am Cony∣catch'd—

SP.SPEAKER: To.
SP.P: But for my father, or this Ladies wronging you, as I am your son, I assure you I have been an eye-wit∣ness of all fair respect towards you.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Is it even so?

SP.SPEAKER: To.
SP.P: Mother, as I respect your blessing it is perfect truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: I humbly beseech you sweet Madam, that my earnest and hearty sorrow may procure remission for my inconsiderate and causelesse Invectives. Let my confession seem satisfactory, and my contrition win in∣dulgency to my forgetfull delinquency. I pray you let us kisse and be friends.

SP.SPEAKER: La. T.
SP.P: Alas sweet friend, you and I have been inward a great while, and for us to fall out, and bare one a∣nothers secrets—

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: VVell, 'twas mine error, not malice; but as for the procurer of it, if I pay not him in his owne Coyne—Mr. Footwell! Ile shew you a trick of twenty. Come son, I have a wife for thee.

SP.SPEAKER: To.
SP.P: A Wife! a Wife, Mother! O where is shee?

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: I, my boy, a Wife—

SP.SPEAKER: To.
SP.P: O ho.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: And such a one as thou shalt blesse me for pro∣curing. Curteously farewell, sweet Madam: Where's my Fool? Come, leave the Court sirrah, and man your owne wife into the City—

SP.SPEAKER: Jo
SP.P: BUt I prethee satisfie me: What returne they? Received they my Jewells?

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Yes, they prov'd acceptive,

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: And what said they? Can they affect?

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Can they be damn'd? Before I will undergoe againe such a business—fore Heaven I do as little dif∣fer from a Pander! only I have nothing for my pains, or else—

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Thou shalt have. Are thy news happy?

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Are your own wishes happy?

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Hold, spend this ten pound for me, Footwel.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P:
Will you make me a Bawde. What a Bawde?
And yet introth, what would not a man be for your sake, that have such wit and such bounty!
I cannot refuse, but suffer your Virtue to be exer∣cis'd upon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Now, prethee speak; what's their answer?

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Why, Ile tell you, they are both your own.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Both Footwell: I prethee how?

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Why, no more but this; they are both yours; only you know, but one hand in a Glove at once. But I had so much to do with one of them; such a coyle to draw him to it—

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Which, I prethee? Sir Andrew?

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: Even he: He saies, he understands that you affect a Mountebanck. Sure, your Doctor is but some base bragging Rascall.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Do you think so?

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: How should Sir Andrew know else that he is come to embrace you to night?

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Does he know that too?

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Yes marry does he, which the worthy Knight takes so contemptuously, suffering so base a Rivall, that he vowes, unless you beat him, bastinado him soundly when he comes, he will loath you most con∣stantly.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Enough, if I do not make him an Example to all the bawdy Quacks in the Kingdome; say there is no virtue in Cudgels, and Bedaves. Ile charm him for opening any more secrets of mine, Ile warrant him. And so write to Sir Andrew.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Welsaid Mistress, be resolute. I mean to help you my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Ile cast about for weapons —

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Yes, I will write to Sir Andrw that, which he shall have small cause to thank me for. I wil write for him to come in the habit of this Doctor. My

DIV3.HEAD: Scene IV.
DIV3.STAGE: Linsie Wolsie, Crack with a Lute, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: SHee's gone, shee's gone: Was ever man so cheated? Threescore pound for a Ring; and the Ring gone too, for which I paid it: A moneths dyet and lodging, besides the charge of Physick and attendance. Five pound in dole bread, would have serv'd my house a twelve moneth. I am undone; broke, Bankrupt: But thou Rogue shalt smart for all, now I have caught thee,

SP.SPEAKER: Crac.
SP.P: Mercy, dear Sir, mercy.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: Were you making up your packe to bee gone too?

SP.SPEAKER: Crac.
SP.P: Nothing but my own Sir, my Lute, and a few Musick-books.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: You and your Mistresse have made sweet Mu∣sick of me: Therefore sirrah quickly—Are the Beadles gone for?

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: Therefore quickly, I say, as you were an Acter in the Cosenage, bring her to light, or—

SP.SPEAKER: Crac.
SP.P: Shee's light enough her self: But a very Inno∣cent I, Sir. She has cozen'd me of halfe a years service, wrought me off o'my leggs, strain'd my backe, crack'd my voyce, done me to my utter undoing; and can you think I knew of her running away?

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: I'le make you sing another song sirrah: Are the Beadles come?

SP.SPEAKER: Crac.
SP.P: Any song Sir, or as many as you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: Pretty I confesse. But that's not the song must do it; nor can any song please me at this time. Are the Beadles come?

DIV3.STAGE: Serv. within. Yes Sir, they are here.

SP.SPEAKER: Crac.
SP.P: Deare Sir, let 'em forbeare a little. And if I cannot please you with a song, commit me to their fury.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: 'Tis but to trifle time: yet sing be∣fore you suffer. Worse then t'other this; you shall sing in another place, to the whip, to the whip, Sir? Bring in the Beadles, and a∣way with him to Bridewell.

SP.SPEAKER: Crac.
SP.P: Yet once more, good Sir, try me this last time, and but promise me, if I can sing a song that you shall like, to forgive and free me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: Sing a song that I shall like, and I will free thee.

LG.L: Then shall a present course be found
For M. Wolsies threescore pound;
And his Ring,
And the thing
That has given him the slip—

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: I marry, that I like well.

SP.SPEAKER: Crac.
SP.P: Then I have 'scap'd the whip.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: Think you so Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Crac.
SP.P: Yes: For you like the song well, you say, and I am free; I hope you will make good your noble Ci∣ty word, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P:
City words use not to passe for songs Sir▪ Make you good the words of your song, Sir, and I
shall make my word good Sir: Come away Bea∣dles.

SP.SPEAKER: Crac.
SP.P: O stay Sir, I beseech you, and let your Ju∣stice fall on the right shoulders. I'le confesse all.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: O will you so Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Crack.
SP.P: 'Tis most true Sir, that the Gentlewoman; whom I call'd Mistress, is a most cunning whore, and a notorious cheat.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: These are good words indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Crac.
SP.P: Shee came to your house with foure men in Liveries; they were all but hired Pandars.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: Yes, and divers Trunks of supposed Treasure, which I finde to bee Baggs of Nailes, and other old Iron, and all the Rings and Stones shee boasted in her Will are but Curtaine Rings, and Bricke∣bats.

SP.SPEAKER: Crac.
SP.P: Your owne covetousness cozen'd you Sir: But if I now bring you not where you shall see how shee is since bestowed, and that you finde not hear∣ty cause to rejoyce that you were cozen'd of her, let me be whipp'd to death, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: Well, come along Sir: But I will have a Guard upon you.

SP.SPEAKER: Crac.
SP.P: What Guard you please Sir, so my poore skin may scape the Lash-guards.—

DIV2.HEAD: ACT. V.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: O thou Varlet, thou unconscionable Unbelie∣ver, ungodly Miscreant! Hast thou cozen'd my easie Credulity? And wouldst have undone and mar∣ried me, like a Cony-catching companion, as thou art? Didst not thou tell me, thou hadst moderate means of life, friends of fashion, and civil reputation? And now this vertuous, religious Gentlewoman tells me, thou art an arrant Skipjack.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Nay, and has not a hole to put thy head in, but upon my curtesie.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: But I thank this Matrons worship, her pity will not permit my easie Nature to suffer under thy Co∣senage: But bestowes her generous Son and Heire here upon me.—

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: A Gentleman of another spheare, another anck then you are Sirrah; that shall have three hun∣dred yeare in Esse, and five in Posse.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: That is acquainted with young Lords; has had the honour to make a Hunting match.

SP.SPEAKER: To.
SP.P: I, and a challenge to ride the wilde Goose hase.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: That hath made Ladies Posies for Cheese tren∣chers.

SP.SPEAKER: To.
SP.P: And play'd with Countesses at Shuttle-cock.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: And to this Elegant Spirit and choice hope am I, and my Fortunes contracted.

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: How! contracted.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: Yes Sir, contracted. Look you, I dare seale it before your face.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Are you so.

SP.SPEAKER: To.
SP.P: She is mine sir, mine sir. Do you mark, I dare likewise seale it sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Is there honesty in this dealing?

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Yes sir, Is there not profit in this dealing?

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Tis very well. If there be no Law upon words, Oathes and Pre-contracts, and Witness. If a man may spend a hundred Angels upon a Widdow; have her affied before Witness, and then have his Nose wip'd of her. Why, Tis very well.

DIV2.STAGE: Tryman takes Pyannet and Toby aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: Intruth deare heart, and sweet Mother in ex∣pectation, to speak equally, there have some words of course past betwixt us, which may seem to impart some Ingagement. Surely I have been too liberall of some speech of advantage. Truly it would not be amiss, (considering his Expence and Interest) to fall to some slight Composition. Some hundred Pounds would make the poor Knave do any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: To.
SP.P: Mother, let's be wise. Let's be wise Mother; fetch a hundred peeces presently: That even upon his first consent, he may be satisfy'd and silenc'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: For if he chance but to be delay'd till he ask Counsell, then—

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Mum. A word to the wise.—

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Nay, I hope as long as I am a Subject, I shall have Law: I doubt not but I shall have Law.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: Come Sir, you shall not deservedly exclaim of my neglecting you.
For our sometimes Love, I have procured you a hun∣dred Pounds.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: To disclaim my right in you, Ile take't. Here's my hand, Ile take it.

SP.SPEAKER: To.
SP.P: Pox, how my Mother staies.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Scorn my Poverty! Come, where ist? Because I have not the Muck of the World. Come, the mo∣ney.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Here sir, upon this consideration, that you dis∣claim and renounce all interest—

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Yes most freely.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: In this Gentlewoman; and do vow, never to pretend future claim to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: I do, marry.—

SP.SPEAKER: To.
SP.P: Nay, no marries sir, you have receiv'd the mo∣ney. You shall make no more marries here. Come my betrothed Spouse, bid a Fice for him, Say black's thine Eye who dares. Mother Ile be married to night, and to bed presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: This night, Son; tis very late.

SP.SPEAKER: To.
SP.P: never to late to be wise. I hope I am your Son; and must beare a Brain.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Indeed, he that deales with Woman, must take occasion by the fore Lock. Away—

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P:
Why! I am weary of money now: I have got∣ten more in a weeks Cosenage, then in all my daies of Honesty. VVhat an easie coole thing it is to be a rich Knave! Gramercy Punck. A witty VVench is an excel∣lent help at a dead lift. But in despite of the Justice that provok'd me, my Conscience a little turns at these
brain-tricks. But they have all been ungratefull; un∣gratefull! Tis a sin that should have no mercy: tis the Plague-spot; who has it should not live.

LG.L: If holy wisdome from the thundring Cloud
Had given more Lawes then ten, this had ensu'd:
Avoid, O man, mans Shame, Ingratitude.
For my poor Lot, I could have sweetly slept
In quiet want, with resolute content,
Had not defect of wit, uncurteous scorn
Been thrust upon me. Now they all shall feele,
VVhen honest men revenge, their whips are steele.

SP.P: My Courtiers are the next that I must exercise up∣on. This night my wife expects the embraces of one of them at least, if this hasty Marriage call her not from her Chamber. But she being a right woman may pre∣vent that with a fained sicknesse, or so. Let me remem∣ber, J wrote to Rufflit to come like her Doctor Pulse∣feele, to minister to her. This will jump right with a counterfeit sickness: It may, perhaps, break a Urinall about his Coxcomb.
How now! O perceive this great Wedding goes forward.

DIV2.STAGE: Musick. Torches. Sarpego. Toby and Tryman. Sneakup and La. Ticket, Pyannet. Josina in night attire. Brid∣get. They passe as to the VVedding with Rosemary. Crasy whispers Josina. She takes leave of her Mo∣ther, seeming to complain of being sick; and so re∣turnes with Bridget.
DIV2.P: Then enter Rufflit like a Doctor.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: So, this falls out pat. She is no sooner gone Sick to her Chamber, but here comes her Physitian, to cover and recover her in a trice.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruf.
SP.P: Hist, Footwell, Footwell.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Seignor Rufflit; J am a foole if J took you not for a Physitian.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruf.
SP.P: She wrote to me, that J should come in this ha∣bit.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Right Sir, to avoid suspect: For which cause she has counterfeited herselfe sick, and lies longing and languishing till you minister to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruf.
SP.P: And am J come pat? am J come i'the nick?

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Your Fortune sings in the right Cliff, sir, a wench as tender as a City Pullet.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruf.
SP.P: But not so rotten.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Oh sir, health it selfe; a very Restorative. VVill you in? The way lies open before you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruf.
SP.P: Hold Footwell, tel that till J return—from branching the most meritted Cuckold Crasy. Poor Snake, that I must force thee to cast thy Skin. And he were not a Citizen J could pity him: He is undone for ever. Methinks J see him all ready make earnest suite, to weare a red Cap, and a blew Gown; comely to carry a Staff-torch before my Lord Mayor upon Alhalloune night. Watch Footwell, J mount.—

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: But now, if the agitation of my Braines should work through my Browes. If my Wives pitifull hand should fall to composition with my Doctors Pate, and my deceit be discovered before the Bastinado had gi∣ven charge to his Shoulders, were not my Forehead in apparant danger. Tis done in three minutes. Death, my Courtier has a sanguine Complexion: He is like a Cock sparrow, Chit, Chit, and away. Heart o' man! And I should be blown up in mine own Mine now! Ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruf.
SP.P: within▪ Hold Mrs. Crasy. Deare Bridget. Help Footwell.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Ho the hubbub's rays'd, and my feare's vanisht.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Josina, and Bridget beating Rufflit: Crasy takes Bridgets Cudgell, and laies on.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Out you Pispot-caster.

SP.SPEAKER: Bri.
SP.P: You Suppository.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: You Glister-pipe, thinkst to dishonest me?

SP.SPEAKER: Ruf.
SP.P: Hold, deare Lady—I am—

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: A stincking saucy Rascall thou art, take this remembrance.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Hold, sweet Mistress.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruf.
SP.P: Oh I thank you good Mr. Footwell.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Oh, it is not so much worth verily.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruff.
SP.P: Oh, but tis sir.
SP.STAGE: He draws his Sword from un∣der his Gowne. Crasy closes with, and disarmes him.
SP.P: Rogue. Rogue.

Nay prethee sweet Rascall, Pox on you, I did not mean to hurt you, my honest Vagabond, tell me, tell me: Come, who was't put this Trick upon me. Thou art a precious Villain: Come, whose devise was it? Whose plot. At whose Suit was I Cudgel'd? Who made me feigne my selfe a Physitian, till I must be forc'd to go to the Surgeon? And dare'st tell me?

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Nay, then I will tell you. Dare! why twas your Friend and Rivall, Sir Andrew Ticket.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruff.
SP.P: Ticket.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Even he sir. His Gold hir'd me to gull you. And this brain procur'd your beating. Yes faith sir, Envie, bribes, and wit have wrong upon you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruff.
SP.P: Well, if I revenge not—

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: But how sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruff.
SP.P: I, afore Heaven, that's well thought on. Give me but the meanes, and I will not only forgive, but reward thee richly.

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: Come faith, because I would have both your Shoulders, go in one Livery, I must disclose. Why sir, Knavery is restorative to me, as Spiders to Mon∣keys. The poyson of wit eeds me.

Look you sir, he's come. Stand close, take this Cud∣gell, grasp it strongly, stretch your Sinewes lustily; And when you see him hang by the middle in a Rope, let your Fist fall thick, and your Cudgell nimbly.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruf.
SP.P: And soundly. My ambitious blowes shall strive which shall go formost.

SP.SPEAKER: Cras.
SP.P: Good sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruf.
SP.P: draw him up but halfe way.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: So sir, I must up to receive.—

SP.SPEAKER: Ruf.
SP.P: Do so: I shall be so reveng'd now! He had been better ha' been taken in Bed with another mans Wife, then have prevented me thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: Vanish Sirrah with the Light. This I am sure is the Window which her Letters call'd me to.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruf.
SP.P: I would you would begin once, that I might be at work. I do not love to stand idle in the Cold thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: Hist, Footwell, Footwell.

SP.SPEAKER: Crasy
SP.P: above: Here sir, here. O I watcht to do you a good turn. Will you mount sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P:
I will mount, remount, and surmount. I won∣der that there is not a solemne Statute made, that no Citizen should marry a handsome Woman; Or if he did, not to lye with her. For and twere not for Gal∣lants
help, they would beget nothing but Fooles.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Right sir, right sir. Take the Rope, and fasten it about your middle sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: Why, that's Crasy; a very Coxcomb.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: An Asse, an Asse.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: A meer Citizen. Were't not a shame his wife should be honest? Or is't not pity that my own man should wholly enjoy a rare excellent proper woman▪ when a whole Corporation scarce affords two of them.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Most true sir. Now mount sir. I pluck courage∣ously. Pray Hercules my strength faile me not.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruf.
SP.P: Up sir, up sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: Pox, and pain! Hold Doctor.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruf.
SP.P: Save you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: I am most sensible of your Salutation. Pluck Footwell.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Alas the Cord sticks-sir; Ile call some help sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: Death and Devils!

SP.SPEAKER: Ruf.
SP.P: Fists and Cudgels.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: Heart, Lungs, Lights.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruf.
SP.P: Armes, Shoulders, Sides.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: Help, help, help.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Passion of Heaven Doctor: Ile Doctor you a∣way.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: Redeem me deare Footwell

SP.SPEAKER: Tra.
SP.P: Yes sir I come for the same purpose. Alas sir, me thinks I even feele your blowes. Are you not sore ie?

SP.SPEAKER: Tick.
SP.P: Sore? Couldst thou not pluck?

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Sure I was Planet-struck; the rope stuck in a slit Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: A Pox o'the lit, say I.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Know you this mad Doctor? Or do you owe any Doctor any thing?

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: I know him not; nor do I owe any Doctor any thing; I onely owe my Barber-Surgeon for a dyet∣drink.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Speedily make up your face Sir, here comes company: M. Rufflit!

DIV2.STAGE: Ent. Rufflit in his owne shape. He hugs and shakes him.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruf.
SP.P: Honest Footwel▪ how dost? Sir Andrew! Heartily how is't?—

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: As heartily as thou wilt; but not so hard I prethee.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruf.
SP.P: Why what's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: I bruis'd my side e'en now against a formes edge.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruf.
SP.P: Parmaty, Sir, is very good, or the fresh skin of a flead Cat?

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: Flead Cat?

SP.SPEAKER: Ruf.
SP.P: The fly-blowes of a dead dog, made into oyl, and spread upon the kell of a meazell hog.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Hark Gentlemen, the Wedding comes, forget old bruises, and put on sense of the lightest colour: for this house to night vowes to run giddy with mirth and laughter.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Lights: Sarpego, Toby, Tryman, La. Ticket, Pyannet, Snerkup.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruf.
SP.P: Joy, health, love and children to this happy union.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: Unbruis'd bones, and smooth foreheads to you both.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: What shall no device, no mirth solemnize my sons match? Go Sneakup, call downe our daughter.
In despight of sicknesse, mirth and joy shall make this night healthfull.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: O mother, cold sobriety and modest melancho∣ly becomes the face of the Matron; unedifying gawdes are Prophane vanities. Mirth is the fat of fools, onely vertue is the nourishment of purity and unsinning sin∣cerity.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: By the leave of your wisdome daughter, wee'l take the wall of your precisenesse: for Mr. Sarpego has told me of a learned subject for a Ballet, which wee shall see acted presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: What is it, some Heathenish Play?

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: No certes, but a very religious Dialogue, full of nothing, but morall conceits betwixt Lady Luxury, a Prodigall and a Fool.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: But who should act and personate these?

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: Why in that lies the nobility of the device; it should be done after the fashion of Italy by our selves, only the plot premeditated to what our aim must tend: Marry the Speeches must be extempore. Mrs. Bride would I have to play Dame Luxury, and Mr. Footwell here the Prodigall.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: And my husband the Fool.

SP.SPEAKER: Sneak.
SP.P: I, and't please you wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: Ile play the Inductor, and then we are all fit∣ted.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: I pray you what is Lady Luxury? A woman regenerative.

SP.SPEAKER: Tob.
SP.P: A Whore, wife:

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: In sincerity not much better then a Curtezan; a kind of open Creature.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: And do you think me fit to represent an open Creature? Saving your modesties, a Whore. Can I play the Strumpet, think yee?

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Trust me Sister, as long as it is done in private, in ones own House, and for some few selected Gentle∣mens pleasure; Me-thinks the part is not altogether the displeasingst.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: Modesty defend me! you think tis nothing to play the Strumpet.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: Why surely religious Lady, it can be no dis∣grace to you to figure out the part: For she that can∣not play the Strumpet if she would, can claim no great honour to be chast.

SP.SPEAKER: Bri.
SP.P: How gravely and sententiously he speaks.

SP.SPEAKER: Tob.
SP.P: Wife, it shall be so: It is my first Injunction; you shall do it, or disobey me. You must play it.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: What, the Whore sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Tob.
SP.P: I, in jest: What hurt is't? And Mother, you shall excuse my Father for this once: For since my wife plaies the Whore, Ile play the Foole my selfe. Though, I know, you had rather see him do it, you shall see for a need, I can make shift to perform it as well as he; as naturally, and to the Life.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: Exceeding well thought on, I pray you, Lady, approve of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Let learning direct, I am not to prescribe to the Muses.

SP.SPEAKER: To.
SP.P: Come sweet heart, let's in and tire us, and be ready to enter presently.

LG.L: I fausto pede— Ex. Tob. Try.
Now for the Prodigall.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P:
O doubt not, Mr. Sarpego: For know Sir, I am but a poor serving creature, that lives upon expe∣ctation;
Oh Sir my end must be husks. Feare not my discharge of the Prodigall—

LG.L: To entertaine ye, while we attire our selves.
We want but now some Musick, or a Song,
But thinke you have it. Sit: wee'l not be long.—

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Seat you Gallants▪ Sit, sweet Sir Andrew, Ma∣dam▪ and the rest, and wee'le imagine Musick, as M. Sarpego bids us.
SP.STAGE: Enter Linsle Wolsie, and Crack with his Lute.
SP.P: How now! By what misrule comes he to trou∣ble us?

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: By your leave, Gallants, I have brought you Musick.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: You Sir, I know your purpose, and it is preven∣ted; you come after the Marriage to forbid the banes. Ha ha ha—you are short, M. Wolsie, you are short.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: Good Mrs. Sneakup you are wide. I come to wish joy to the match, and to tell you I rejoyce, that I mist a Bridegrooms part.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: How's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: You see I wear no Willow, and am merry▪ All's true you told me, boy?

SP.SPEAKER: Crac.
SP.P: Yes by my detestation to Bridewell Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: Sing boy that song, If I have any griefe, it shall be all vented in a Hymeneall Song.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: I have not known him in this humor.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruf.
SP.P: Sure 'tis a merry madnesse for the losse of the widdow,

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Since you come friendly, you are welcome, M. Wolsie. Pray sit with us, and heare your Hymene∣all Song.

LG.L: Jo Hymen, Jo Hymen, Jo Hymen Py. This begins well.
Was wont to be still the old song
At high Nuptiall Feasts
Where the merry merry guests
With joy and good wishes did throng:
But to this new Wedding new notes do I bring,
To raile at thee Hymen, while sadly I sing.
Fye ô Hymen, fye ô Hymen, fye ô Hymen,
What hands, and what hearts dost thou knit?
A Widdow that's prre,
And a very very Whore,
To an Heire that wants nothing but wit▪
Yet thus far, O Hymen, thy answer is made,
When his ns are spent, they may live by her trade.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: He sings Hymen and Hymen; but me-thinkes the song is scandalous to the Marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: Excuse me Lady, though I was cozen'd of the Bride, I have no such malice; 'tis a song that the boy could sing by chance, and made by a couple that were lately married in Crooked-Lane.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: O, is it so Sir? I knew not what to make of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: Let us attend I pray; the Prologue enters.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.

LG.L: Right Country Dame, and Courtly Lady,
Look for sense as sall as may be;
But, if wit deceive your thinkings,
Know our Muse disdaines base shrinkings.
Hold a while your Verdicts bridle,
Judge not yet our Project idle,
Till at length the close may show it,
If we act the part of Poet.

SP.STAGE: Enter Tryman and Toby. She loosely drest like a Curte∣zan, a bowle of wine in her hand. He in a fools Cap and Coat.

LG.L: Speak Lechery and Folly, Luxury I would say;
I need not prompt them, they know what they should say.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: Out you base Rascall, you muddy Slave; thou hast married me, and I will drink a health to thy Cuc∣koldmaker.—

SP.SPEAKER: To.
SP.P: Sfoot I am afraid shee'l play the whore better then I shall act the fool.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: Thou under-hearted, dull-blooded Pantaloon▪ thou whose utmost honour is to be made so good thing as a Cuckold; thou sonne of a Copy-holder▪ and the Pudding-pye womans daughter, dost tho think, dar'st thou but imagine, that I shall ever vouch∣safe to love to doe any thing, but laugh at thee? Hence you Poultroon; thy voyce sounds not so farre as thy breath stinks—Kicks him▪

SP.SPEAKER: To.
SP.P: Nay but, nay but do you heare wife? I do not very well like this; me-thinks you play too much in earnest.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: In earnest? Why Goodman Fool, you Cock▪ comb, you Ninnihammer, you Clotpold Countrey Gentleman, thou dirty greediness.—

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Why how now daughter? Are you well? Me▪ thinks you over-do it too much.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P:
Thou dream'st my good husband, that thou
hast married the rich widdow, ha ha ha—

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: Now enters Prodigality.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Crasy in his own habit, all hung with Chaines, Jewells, Bags of Money, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: When the troth is, deare brother, you have married the rank whore. Ha ha ha.

SP.SPEAKER: To.
SP.P: Sir!—who, brother Crasy?

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Sweet husband!

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: Dear son!

SP.SPEAKER: Tic. Ruff.
SP.P: Precious friend!

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: Neighbour Crasie!

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: Dij boni! Domine Crasie!

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: And how doe you wife? When comes your Doctor Pulsfeel? But a kisse and so forth? And would not one of these free Gallants, these proper youths have serv'd the turne? I pray pardon mine incivility, Mother; I was bold to retaine mine owne Jewells. Ha' you not forgot your singles and your doubles, your fallings back, and your turnings up wife?

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Why ifaith, dear heart, dost thinke me so simple, that I did not know thee all the while? Alas man, I did but counterfeit, as you did, to maintaine the jest; kisse me sweet duck—onely to maintaine the jest ifaith.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Yes, yes, yes, we are Friends. I heartily thank these kind Gentlemen for their loves to you, yes saith, heartily: I am better by it five hundred at least. Be not you jealous Madame, they had nothing for it; not a bit by this Light.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruff.
SP.P: Death o'my Fortune! that was my Gold.

SP.SPEAKER: Tic.
SP.P: Plague of a Villain, that was my Jewell.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: True Gentlemen; and your bounty likewise lies in this Bag.

SP.SPEAKER: La. T.
SP.P: Sir, we sent these things to your Wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: I thank you for it; we have but one Capacity in the Law, you know: What's hers must be mine. I know thou wouldst have it so sweet-heart. I am onely sorry Gentlemen, that you were so well favourdly bea∣ten. That the Foole Citizen, the Asse Citizen, the Cuckold Citizen should procure such a sound swadling to your wise, valiant and substantiall Shoulders. Is't not a sore matter? But rest, Salves and warm Oyles may in time recover it.

How do you kind Mother? Gentlemen, if any of you want Money Gentlemen, here stands a City-wit that has it. I have it, if you want any; speak, I have it, and will keep it. How does your Costard Sir? A Pox o'th Slit, Sir. Belov'd of Phoebus, Minion of the Muses; deare water bayly of Helicon, be not proud of your Preferment, though you are his Highnesse tutor. Mo∣ther, J take the restoring of my rich Jewels very kindly. O my kind Brother, you have got the rich Widdow; and you have borne a brain Mother. Your hundred pound, brother, was most thristily and opportunely be∣stow'd. J could ha' procur'd her to you at an easier rate, Mother. J am onely sorry for you Mr. Wolsy, that you had her not: Because you very honourably releast me of your Bond before it was due; and are in shrewd danger to be laught at among your Neighbours.
How does good Mr. Crasy, the Princes Jeweller? Mother, did not my Father look too wise for a Citizen? How dost honest Punck? I am as much beholden to thee, as to the rest o' them.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: My sonne and my heir is utterly undone.

SP.SPEAKER: To.
SP.P: O! I am quite cast away.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: O no, you shall be no loser by me; you shall be a gainer by me Brother: Get wit Brother (marke you) wit. Good faith I pity the poore Citizen, hee has no wit; a handsome young fellow, with a pretty beard, and a proper bodied woman to his wife, and cannot beare a brain!

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: Why dost heare, modestly mumping Mother∣in-Law, with thy French-hood, gold-chain, and flag∣gon-bracelets, advance thy snout. If the foole thy son, the Ideot my husband here, have but as much brains as a Battledore, he may make a faire revenue of me: Has he not a place at Court? Can he not lodge me there, and prove weak-sighted, thick of hea∣ring, sleepie after dinner, and snort when others enter∣taine and Court me? Can he not survey the hang∣ings, read Cupids Conybery, the Park of pleasure, Christian Love-Letters, or some other Pamphlet, or faine some errand into the Town, whilst his browes are turning into gold?

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: O impudence beyond womans apprehension! Sonne Crasie, we have all wrong'd thee, thou know'st it; thou hast reveng'd it, we feel it; only do not un∣do my heire, save him, bring him but off o'this match with any loss.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Why mother, is your son grown such a sawcy Knave, as he thinkes scorne to be a Cuckold? I cannot cleare him; in truth I cannot: He has paid for her deeply, and 'tis pity they should be parted, yes faith is't.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P:
Woman, we do pray thee, we do beseech thee, even upon our knees—have pity on the house of the Sneakups: quit my son, re∣linquish
thy right, make frustrate this marriage, and look thee, before these able witnesses, we heartily for∣give all, and forget: And withall, freely bestow this chaine upon thee—

DIV2.STAGE: Pulls off her chain and gives it.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: I do receive it.

SP.SPEAKER: To.
SP.P: She does receive it, beare witness all, she does receive it.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: Marry on this condition—

SP.SPEAKER: To.
SP.P: No I'le no more marries nor conditions, you have receiv'd it.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: I, you must make frustrate the Marriage; for look you, you have receiv'd it.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: I will, and freely do; only the condition I would have made, is this, That if you intend longer to be Master of your husband, now that you have seen how well it became me, you will henceforward do as I do—Look you, wear breeches.

DIV2.STAGE: Puls the coats up, and shews the breeches.

SP.SPEAKER: Py.
SP.P: O horrible!

SP.SPEAKER: To.
SP.P: How! do you wear breeches?

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: Yes Sir, breeches; and as good lining and stuffing in them, I hope, as yours have, though they be of Sattin.

SP.SPEAKER: To.
SP.P: I'le feel that: Sfoot mother this is a man. Come and feel else.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: A young one Sir.
See Master your poor servant Jeremy, if he has per∣form'd his part, desires to be admitted into the Livery of wit, and to wear this chaine as his ensigne of Free∣dome.

SP.SPEAKER: To.
SP.P: Jeremy! O Jeremy! thou wer't ever too hard for—

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: Except at spoonmeat, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Ieremy!

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: Yes, Mistress: Indeed forsooth.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Well, give me thy hand: I will love thee as long as there is swiftnesse in meditation, smoothnesse in flattery, or constancy in malice.

LG.L: And for the cure that he has wrought on me,
I will applaud his wit; and blesse the light
It gave me to discover my foule error:
Which by his demonstration shew'd so monstrous,
That I must loath my self, till I bee purg'd.
Sir, by your fair forgivenesse, which I kneel for—
Heaven make me thankfull: Wife I have no words
To shew how I rejoyce: Rise, let me kisse thee—
Tempora mutantur. The towne's ours again.
Only, to fill the Scene with joy, may wee
Conjoyn sweet maid, in the Catastrophe.

SP.SPEAKER: Bri.
SP.P: Would you that have taught Greeke, and whip't great boyes, come backe to your Horn-book, and let down your Gascoines to me, that would, if I had you, bee more tyrannous then any Pedant that e∣ver reign'd since the dayes of Dionysius: Besides here is my choice, with my Master and Mistresses leave, Je∣remies brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: But is hee seriously thy brother?

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: Yes, and no more a Pimp Sir, then I am a Wench.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Well, Mr. Sarpego, I'le help you to a fitter match, and Crack I will give thee something with her: Take the security of my hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Crac.
SP.P: I only desire to be secure from this mans fu∣ry, and so consequently from Bridewell.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: He shall have nothing to say to thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Lin.
SP.P: I will have nothing to say to man, woman, or child, while I live againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: Fortuna nihil aufert sapienti: Fools and Fid∣lers are her Favourites.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.P: Let us make this a merry night.

LG.L: Think of no losses. Sirs, you shall have none;
My honest care being but to keep mine owne.
What, by my slights, I got more then my due,
I timely will restore again to you.

SP.P: Omnes, Thanks kind Mr. Crasy, thanks.

SP.SPEAKER: Sar.
SP.P: Gratias vel ingentes Domine Crasy.

LG.L: NOw let me Scholastikewise
For us all Epiloguise:
If these slender Scenes of Wit
